I haven't set up pppoE, mine is in bridging mode.  When Qwest sent my
router, they also included a manual that had step by step instructions
for setting up the 2 different modes, if you didn't get the manual, then
Qwest tech support may be your best bet, they don't support linux fully,
but they don't hang up on you either.  It is their job to make sure that
the equipment they sent you is working and connecting to your ISP.  Let
them know that you can connect to the Cisco management port with a
terminal emulator and that you need help with the settings. 

BTW, make sure that you let them know that you NEVER want to be
transfered to MSN tech support.

Good Luck

That sounds good!  You wouldn't require a line upgrade, then?  I
shouldn't think so, but I thought I'd offer it as an incentive.  So
besides the $10, what's it worth to you, considering power consumption
(minimal), the possibility of a manual reboot or two, physical space
(?), etc?  I have a friend who said he'd do it for a couple extra IPs
(one for him), but yours appears to be a superior connection.

Here are some other questions:  about where are you located, and is this
your house, apartment?  Have you had any issues with your connection or
your power?  What are the chances of your relocating in the next year or
two?  Do you have a cap on your throughput (shouldn't be an issue with
this machine, but it's worth considering)?  Does your space keep
reasonably cool in the summer?

Thanks,

Jason Van Cleve

good AVI player that installs in one shot. Is anything out there ready for 
prime-time?

Wishful-thinking Procedure:
1. Go to Best Buy or Fry's.
2. Pay $19 or so for a box with a CD in it. Name on the box is irrelevant.
3. Slot the CD in a drive, go to KDE file mangler, and double click a file on 
the CD with a gear on it and a likely sounding name, like 'install.'
4. Press "OK" until all the dialog boxes go away. (Note: You do not have to 
actually *read* any of the dialog boxes. Think of playing 'Whack-a-mole,' but 
with your mouse pointer - the faster you hit those "OKs," the sooner you get 
to watch your AVI's. The fewer that appear, the better the program is.)
5. Double-click on my AVI files and have a few beers.

Desired (more realistic) procedure:
1. Download -One- rpm file from somewhere. Two rpm's max.
2. Double-click on it/them in KDE. (Command line? You must be joking. A 
double click -IS- a command: It means 'Computer, go and do your job 
correctly, and let me know when you're done!')
3. Make any/all dialog boxes go away (see 4. above.)
4. Same as 5. above.

Tell-me-it-ain't so: (any one of these is a show-stopper)
1. Download a tar.gz instead of an rpm.
2. Find out you need x-whatever, but that that in turn needs dll's which you 
have NO way of knowing whether you already have or not, or where they are.
3. Anything with the word 'Woody' in it.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul 11 23:05:05 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 11 Jul 2002 23:05:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] duplicating an audio CD
In-Reply-To: <20020712044626.E649110E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207112252080.29157-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

I'm not the expert on this stuff, but I've done it, so I'll write what I
know.

On Thu, 11 Jul 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:
> I've only got one CD-RW device right now so I presume I'm going to have
> to "rip" the entire CD to disk then write it back to the blank.

Yes.  But you can rip the tracks individually and then write them back to
the disc in any order.

> My question: what format do I pull the data off in?  I see from the
> cdparanoia man page that there's a so-called "raw" format.  Is that
> what I use?  Do I need the entire CD image in one file for DAO?

The so-called "raw" format is, in fact, raw PCM audio with stereo channel
separation and at the appropriate sampling frequency.

It's basically a 16-bit 44.1Khz Stereo WAV, but without the WAV headers.

cdparanoia assumes you want file in WAV format, unless you specify
otherwise.

That's totally cool because cdrecord will recognize the .wav extension and
skip over the non-audio header stuff.

> Ok, as you can see, I know nothing.  A quick explaination of the
> specifics would be greatly appreciated.

Actually, now that I think about it, I don't know that I've ever ripped a
CD directly into raw PCM audio.  I usually assemble CDs from MP3s,
normalize the audio, use mpg123 to dump to raw PCM and then write that to
disc.

However, you can do this, too:
cdparanoia -B
(switch discs when done)
cdrecord -speed=8 -dev=0,0,0 -audio track1.wav track2.wav (...)

And that's all there should be to it.

If you have some funny hardware, I can imagine having to twiddle
endianness, but try it straight first.

The files will literally be called track1.wav and so on.  If you use a
front-end to cdparanoia that does cddb lookups or something (I often use
grip), then your track names might be different.  I would recommend using
something like that and setting your filenames to start with the track
number (rather than having it inside the name somewhere) like this:
02-Track_Name.wav

That way, you can just do something like this with your cdrecord command
line:
cdrecord -speed=8 -dev=0,0,0 -audio *.wav

Neater.  Oh, and you don't need to specify speed and device if you've
already got a working config file for cdrecord.

I hope that's useful.  Somebody with more knowledge and experience with
audio will probably answer this, but I thought I'd answer now since
there's no answer on the list right this second and you might want to roll
up them shirtsleeves right now.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

On Thu, 11 Jul 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> One thing you might try is using SpamCop. www.spamcop.net. It will do the 
> traces and reverse lookups for you, then you can study what it did. Then you 
> can even use it to send abuse reports for you, if you like. I use the Web 
> form, rather than forwarding emails, to see an analysis of the headers right 
> away.

  I will second this suggestion with two caveats. First, sometimes spamcop
gets it wrong; not often, but sometimes. Second, the more important drawback
is that some providers refuse to accept the munged reports spamcop sends;
others just refuse spamcop reports.

  Here I use spamcop when it looks like tracing the correct source will take
more time than I wish to spend on the effort. Otherwise, I trace the source
and send them a canned request to shut down the spammer. For the known spam
factories or relayers, I just add their IP address or domain name to the
appropriate postfix filter.

  I have a couple of related questions for the group, but I'll put them in a
separate thread.

At 08:02 PM 7/11/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>4. Press "OK" until all the dialog boxes go away. (Note: You do not have to
>actually *read* any of the dialog boxes. Think of playing 'Whack-a-mole,' but
>with your mouse pointer - the faster you hit those "OKs," the sooner you get
>to watch your AVI's. The fewer that appear, the better the program is.)

<soapbox>

Having been a technical support engineer for a large software firm, I 
cringe when I read something like this.

Expect software to work like a Kleenex (pull it out of the box and it's 
ready to use) and it will last about as long as a Kleenex.

Why do I say that?

Because software is not simple. It never has been. Software Engineers (I 
work with those still) can only anticipate so many permutations of the 
available hardware and software out there. There are literally millions, 
possibly billions of possible combinations. Many that aren't compatible in 
one way or another.

I'd say that reading the installation dialogs, or the README file, is every 
bit as important as reading the fine print that comes with your 
prescription medicine. One goes to your health, the other, to your PC.

If someone clicks 'OK' as fast as they can, and then it doesn't work as 
they expect, well, I have no sympathy for them.

</soapbox>

 :: double click -IS- a command: It means 'Computer, go and do your job 
 :: correctly, and let me know when you're done!')
 :: 3. Make any/all dialog boxes go away (see 4. above.)
 :: 4. Same as 5. above.

Desiring to not ever use the command line, especially when dealing
with installing anything "video" related is usually a pipedream.
Too many libraries involved.

Besides, how hard is it to type `rpm -Uvh foo.rpm' ?  Also the big
disadvantage of the Gooey method is that you often don't see what
errors occurred, so you can't even begin to address the problems.

Anyway I just did `rpm -q xanim' on my Mdk 8.2 machine and it returned
                                           ^^^

2001 medulla: deanm=>rpm -q xanim
xanim-28010-16mdk

I'm currently runnning six simutaneous .avi files for a research demo
so I know that that version of xanim will play (some) .avi's.

I say "some"  because .avi is not a single format but a family of formats.
Some are mpeg-2 encoded internally, some are coded in other ways.
I have no idea of all the capabilities of xanim.  I simply did
`xanim foo.avi &' (from the commandline :-) and it played (and I was
a happy camper).

My suggestion is to go to a mandrake mirror, download the .src.rpm
(not the binary .rpm).  I'm currently seeing the .src.rpm package in:

/pub/unix/Linux/Mandrake/Mandrake/8.2/SRPMS/xanim-28010-16mdk.src.rpm

on the machine sunsite.uio.no

which you get into  via anonymous ftp.


Put it somewhere (it does not matter),  say /tmp,
and follow these steps (mutatis mutandis):

1) rpm -i /tmp/foo.src.rpm
2) cd /usr/src/RPM/SPECS
3) rpm -bb foo.spec

At this point the .src.rpm will either unpack, compile, and generate
a binary .rpm for _your_ system with _your_ libraries, or you'll
get some sort of "missing  library" error upon which you get to start
treading the "dependency treadmill".  I hope it's the former but the latter
is not the end of the world and I will try to help you if you will wish.

4) cd usr/src/RPM/RPMS/<arch>
   where <arch> is i686 or whatever machine architecture you have.

5) rpm -Uvh foo.rpm

Again if all goes well you'll have xanim (or any other .rpm you wish
to build) installed on your system and you're on your way.  If not,
give us a yell and tell us what errors occured.

 :: Tell-me-it-ain't so: (any one of these is a show-stopper)
 :: 1. Download a tar.gz instead of an rpm.
 :: 2. Find out you need x-whatever, but that that in turn needs dll's which you 
You should not need a tar.gz but (sorry to be so blunt) if this is your
attitude then linux probably isn't for you.

 :: have NO way of knowing whether you already have or not, or where they are.
 :: 3. Anything with the word 'Woody' in it.
 :: 
 :: GLL

From John at JohnTelford.com  Fri Jul 12 09:53:29 2002
From: John at JohnTelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 09:53:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hire the Best
Message-ID: <20020712165328.GA15685@lnx2.labnet>

Linux, UNIX, and network professionals seeking work in the Portland are
are running into the "buyers" market mentality.

This is illustrated by a recent Portland Area Cisco Users Group mailing
list posting by a hiring manager, containing the following statement:

"..you are only worth what the market will bear, and what someone is
willing to pay you."

Below is a lightly edited version of my response to that posting.

==========

Most successful managers know, or learn by experience, that hiring the
best people for $X pays off *much* better than hiring less than the best
for $<X.  Usually the best people are insulted by offers of $<X.  The
manager and company making the offer soon earn the reputation of being
cheap.  This is a liability in a "small town" like Portland where the
word quickly get around.

Some managers suffering from magical thinking are applying a mythical
man-month principle by thinking that hiring two for the price of one
produces twice the work.  The fallacy of this thinking was exposed more
than 25 years ago by Frederick P. Brooks in the classic "The Mythical
Man-Month."  Twenty years later, the first revised edition of this book
reaffirms the original principles.

The best people bring a wealth of experience and depth of understanding
to a job that lesser experienced people are lacking.  It's wishful
thinking that sending a lesser experienced person off to training will
close the gap.

Anyone sent off to training may return with some more experience and a
better depth of understanding.  But even this incremental improvement
doesn't come close to closing the experience gap, and the ability to
solve difficult problems.

There's no substitute for experience and depth of understanding.  Paying
the price is a bargain.  First rate managers know this.  They know that
the best people usually out performs several lesser experienced people
combined.  What a bargain!

Being a hiring manager for several years, one phenomena that ceases to
amaze me is first rate managers hire first rate people, and second rate
managers hire third rate people.

Food for thought.

...John

-- 
John Telford - Owner
JohnTelford.com LLC
503-292-6865 - fax:503-292-3094
john at johntelford.com - www.johntelford.com

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 12 10:22:05 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 10:22:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hire the Best
Message-ID: <210504807.1026494508998.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Good discussion, John!

More comments below.

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, John Telford John at JohnTelford.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Linux, UNIX, and network professionals seeking work in the Portland are
> are running into the "buyers" market mentality.
> 
> This is illustrated by a recent Portland Area Cisco Users Group mailing
> list posting by a hiring manager, containing the following statement:
> 
> "..you are only worth what the market will bear, and what someone is
> willing to pay you."

Unfortunately, this is fairly true and does not invalidate the rest of
your argument.  It really is simple supply and demand.

If there are only a few top-level engineers available then a bidding war
erupts as people compete to bribe these folks out of their
positions.  Basic economics says when demand vastly exceeds the supply of
a "widget" (no, not X11... ;-) the equilibrium price will be quite high.

If the reverse is true and there are lots of top-level engineers looking
for work, there is no need for a bidding war and in fact after some months
many of these top engineers will be getting desperate and will be working
for much less than they would normally do.  Again basic econ, supply
exceeds demand and the equilibrium price will be quite low.

This defines "what the market will bear".

Now we get into the fun part "what someone is willing to pay you".

Companies generally spend lots of money to identify the above market
equilibrium prices on a semi-regular basis.  Once that is accomplished,
it's ususally up to to the hiring manager or his boss(es) to decide if
they want to pay above or below that rate based on what they presently
have and what they need.

For example, if a company is lucky enough to have several senior people
and just needs to round out their workforce, they may only offer a small
amount of money on the understanding that the first couple of people might
get shooed out after only a couple of months.

If they need to get someone in who will hit the ground running, and don't
want to deal with re-hiring later, then they should offer above that
equilibrium (market) price.

> Most successful managers know, or learn by experience, that hiring the
> best people for $X pays off *much* better than hiring less than the
> best for $<X.  Usually the best people are insulted by offers of $<X.  
> The manager and company making the offer soon earn the reputation of
> being cheap.  This is a liability in a "small town" like Portland
> where the word quickly get around.

Some companies know this and will hire above market rates, hoping to find
good people.  Generally these same smart companies are vicious when it
comes to firing people who do not perform.  (If not, they'll quickly find
themselves in a bad situation-- spending lots more than they need to for
inferior people.)

Cheapskate companies looking for a deal generally have to suffer enormous
turnover and a bad reputation.  They will only find people who have been
unable to get hired or stay hired at the other companies.

> Some managers suffering from magical thinking are applying a mythical
> man-month principle by thinking that hiring two for the price of one
> produces twice the work.  The fallacy of this thinking was exposed
> more than 25 years ago by Frederick P. Brooks in the classic "The
> Mythical Man-Month."  Twenty years later, the first revised edition of
> this book reaffirms the original principles.

I wish more people would read and believe that book.  Unfortunately, most
project managers like to apply simple division to tough projects.  This is
the same flawed logic that leads to PMs figuring if one woman can have a
baby in nine months, then nine should be able to do it in one month.

> The best people bring a wealth of experience and depth of
> understanding to a job that lesser experienced people are lacking.  
> It's wishful thinking that sending a lesser experienced person off to
> training will close the gap.

If you can find the right junior people this can actually work out-- but
it's no substitute for good mentoring from a senior person or two.

The problem is finding smart, motivated junior folks who will actually
learn.  There's no way to find this on a resume.

> There's no substitute for experience and depth of understanding.  
> Paying the price is a bargain.  First rate managers know this.  They
> know that the best people usually out performs several lesser
> experienced people combined.  What a bargain!

Yes, junior folks should be thought of as a supplement to shed "busy
work" load from the senior folks-- not as a replacement.

Fun discussion.  Maybe I should go look for that other list. ;-)

  -- Steve





From shahms at shahms.com  Fri Jul 12 10:22:11 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 12 Jul 2002 10:22:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] duplicating an audio CD
In-Reply-To: <20020712170058.A43A410E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207112252080.29157-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20020712170058.A43A410E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <1026494531.16828.12.camel@shahms>

<lot's o' stuff snipped>
> 
> But from what I've read (I may just have a mis-understanding) this
> will record the tracks in "TAO" mode which, (from the HOWTO) can cause
> funny clicks and other audio junk in between the tracks.  They
> recommend DAO mode where (I gather) the whole load is recorded at once
> and you use a config file to specify track number &c.  It's not too
> clear to me.
> 
>  :: I hope that's useful.
> 
> Yes this is useful.  Thanks, Jeme.
> 
> So I now undertand the "raw data" part of my question.  But I still need
> help with the DAO part.

DAO: disk at once
TAO: track at once

The differences (in summary) are basically in track at once mode, you
can record multiple audio tracks at different times, so long as you
don't "fixate" the CD (although, it must be fixated to actually play in
anything).  In dao mode you have to write the entire disc at once (um,
well, yeah ;-)) How this translates into the real world:
Track at once discs have some requirements, such as the pregaps of all
the tracks are 2 seconds (spacing between songs, when you hit play on
most CD players this is the stuff that shows up as negative and counts
down to zero, when the actual track starts playing).  In dao mode, the
pregap is adjustable from 0 up to some limit I'm sure.  I missed the
first part of your question, but basically this means that for recording
live music, copying Dark Side of The Moon, etc. you don't want TAO
'cause you get breaks in between tracks which is disconcerting if there
are no breaks in the actual music.  And now on to the "HOWTO" of dao:

cdrecord will let you record in DAO mode with the -dao option, done and
done.
OR you can use cdrdao which is more complicated by a few orders of
magnitude.  It requires a config file specifying all the lengths of the
various tracks pregaps, etc.  In short, it tends to be a PITA and I much
prefer using cdrecord for doing this, even though it's not as flexible,
I don't care (I just want it to write songs with no breaks between them,
usually), and I suspect you don't either (unless you want to do silly
things like have tracks overlap, different pregaps for different tracks,
etc.  DAO can do a LOT of things if you bother to specify them in the
toc file to cdrdao).

In fact, dao mode USED to be labeled as "may be removed in the future,
don't depend on it" or some such, but it appears to be around for the
long haul as the man page now states:
       
-dao   Set  Disk  At  Once  mode.  This currently only works with MMC
drives that support non raw Session At Once mode.

I don't know about the requirements of cdrdao drives, though I suspect
they are comparable.

Again from the cdrecord man page (which will probably answer your
question in the most succinct way possible, which I obviously have not
;-)):
To copy an audio CD in the most accurate way, first run

           cdda2wav -v255 -D2,0 -B -Owav

       and then run

           cdrecord -v dev=2,0 -dao -useinfo  *.wav

(replacing -D2,0 and dev=2,0 with the appropriate device of course)
cdrdao actually has a "copy" command that will do this for you, but it
is, like I said before, just a "wee bit" more coplicated than just:
cdrdao copy <srcdevice> <destdevice>

Hope this helps,
--Shahms

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Jul 12 10:33:30 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 12 Jul 2002 10:33:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] duplicating an audio CD
In-Reply-To: <20020712044626.E649110E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
References: <20020712044626.E649110E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <1026495211.5965.241.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Dean,


On Thu, 2002-07-11 at 21:46, Dean S. Messing wrote:
> 
> I've never "dupped" an audio CD before so I have some questions.  From
> reading the (rather old) HOWTO it appears that I want to write in
> so-called DAO mode rather than TAO mode.
> 
> I've only got one CD-RW device right now so I presume I'm going to have
> to "rip" the entire CD to disk then write it back to the blank.
> 
> My question: what format do I pull the data off in?  I see from the
> cdparanoia man page that there's a so-called "raw" format.  Is that
> what I use?  Do I need the entire CD image in one file for DAO?
> 
> Ok, as you can see, I know nothing.  A quick explaination of the specifics
> would be greatly appreciated.

For just duplicating CD's, cdrdao is probably the best one available. 
It only reads and writes whole CD images in binary form (the images can
be mounted in a loopback device and then played) and it extracts the
TOC, stores it in a separate file, and writes it back, unchanged.  The
man page does a good job of explaining what it can do and how.  It also
has a "raw-read" option, but that is only needed for trying to duplicate
copy-protected CD's (for backup purposes only, of course).  The strange
thing is that this program obviously was designed for audio CD's, but it
works very well on data CD's too, you just ignore the TOC that it
extracts and use the binary image, which turns out to be just an ISO
image.

HTH 

Derek Loree

From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Jul 12 10:46:18 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 11:46:18 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam tracing questions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207120834460.18857-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121050360.23929-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   This is a postfix question that was not answered on the mailhelp mail
> list. Perhaps someone here has the answer.
>
>   When postfix checks the headers for an incoming message against the access
> and smptd_client_restrictions files, it appears to look at only the topmost
> received from line and ignore everything below. Here's the scenario: a
> repeat spammer addresses the message to my secondary MX address rather than
> the primary MX address. This means that the message goes to Aracnet's mail
> server before plopping down here in my inbox. The originating IP address or
> domain name are in the spam filters but not seen. Is this normal behavior?
> Are there any changes I can make to catch and reject these messages?


Why would the smptd_client_restrictions care anything about the
header?  The header is a part of the message, not the envelope
data.

The smtp client restriction is based off of the mailserver that
connects to you, its IP address, name, etc...  *Not* anything in the
header (should postfix accepts the message a new line is added to the
header based on this info).


The problem really needs to be tackled on the backup MX, not on your
box.  The only real way to filter these things is when they are being
sent by the untrusted system.  Once they reach something trusted what
is your mailserver to do?  I mean the message is coming from a trusted
SMTP source (your backup MX).  SPAM filters can *only* be applied to
the current remote system, any previous hops are just text data in the
header.

That being said, if it is impossible to fix the backup MX, look into
postfix header_checks.  You can do a rexexp against the header for the
offending system.  Not exactly a preferred method, but if the message
is already on a trusted system not much else you can do short of a
procmail filter that does the same thing.  Postfix header_checks and
body_check are the equiv of :H and :B in procmail, but done before the
message is accepted into the delivery queue.  Not something to go wild
with, text searching is expensive cpu cycle wise, but useful at times.
Less costly to do these filters on a system wide basis inside postfix
than via procmail.  (For a single user procmail is the better
filtering place though).


-- 
I route, therefore you are.

From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Jul 12 11:12:31 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 12:12:31 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Odd Installation Problem
In-Reply-To: <1026496779.6088.265.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121206380.24135-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On 12 Jul 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

> Hi Dennis,
> >
> Yes, I have, many times.  The reasons (and fixes) are varied, some were
> hardware related, some were lilo.conf related.  What is your hardware
> configuration?  What is the lilo.conf that you've tried (particularly
> the one to create the boot floppy)?  Does lilo spit out any errors or
> warnings when you run it?
>
> Derek Loree


In most cases it relates to BIOS using an odd LBA or similar large
disk mapping scheme.  It can also be caused by an improperly detected
disk geometry, or manually specced geometry.


Basicly, the disk translation active when lilo does its boot mapping
and writes the MBR is substantially different than the one in use when
BIOS is doing the initial load. Sooo, the first few pages of LILO get
started, but it cannot complete the load. (Initial forst stage is
pulled from the boot loader, but when the first stage jumps to another
sector to load the second stage (the actual loader that reads in the
kernel) it end up reading the wrong location.

keymaps 0-2,4-6,8-9,12

It's  worked on every linux PC  I've used in the past 5 years.

I answered too quickly.  Try my suggestion anyway, but be sure
to reboot or, in some way, make sure you are starting out with
the right initial condx.  If you had run loadkeys and then run dumpkeys
I would expect to see what  you saw in your third paragraph.

Sorry, don't know too much about keyboard stuff.  However:

 ::   I've swapped the two keys in X on both my workstation and notebook by
 :: creating a ~/.xmodmap from the examples in the man page. Works just fine.
 :: Now I want to do the same thing, especially on the notebook. On that machine
 :: I constantly press the caps lock key when reaching for the tab key. By
 :: swapping the control and caps lock keys I'll both eliminate that problem and
 :: put the control key where it's more easily reached while typing.

putting:

# If you'd like to switch the positions of your capslock and
# control keys, use:
    XkbOptions  "ctrl:swapcaps"

in your /etc/X11/XF86Config file if you run X 3.3.x

(or if you run X 4.x.x use

    Option "XkbOptions" "ctrl:swapcaps"

in your /etc/X11/XF86Config-4 file)

will obviate (love dem $5 words) the need for the .xmodmap hokus-pokus.

I don't exactly know what MMC is myself, but the odds are your drive is
MMC (I *think* almost all newer drives are, I'm pretty sure the only
drives that aren't were some early recorders).  All of the ones I have
come across in recent years have been.

> So now my next question is, can I use cdparanoia instead of cdda2wav
> to extract in exactly the same format I need above.  I think cdparanoia
> does a better job of error detection/correction;  if I can use it I'd

Yes. Except, cdparanoia doesn't write out the .inf and .cddb files.

> 2) is whatever info that -useinfo uses get provided if I use cdparanoia?

No. That command uses the .inf file associated with the track to
determine the pregap on that track.

> Dean

cdparanoia does *much* better error detection and correction, but I
rarely have problems with cdda2wav when forced to use it for something
(like a cd cdparanoia can't handle, and I've come across a few, don't
ask me why). The one serious drawback for cdrdao for me is that it
doesn't support burnPROOF :-( and for the newer, faster, and largely IDE
drives, it really is necessary to actually get a burn AND continue using
your computer (why aren't CDR makers making SCSI drives anymore?!?!?!
WHY!!!)

  * BURN Proof support added by ITOH Yasufumi/Martin Buck

it looks like using cdrdao to copy a cd is as simple as:
cdrdao copy --device <bus,id,lun>

it will then prompt you to insert the CD-R after it's read the data from
the device (or you can do cdrdao copy --device <yadda> --source-device
<yadda>)

--Shahms



From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Jul 12 12:06:57 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 13:06:57 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam tracing questions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121128140.19185-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121259540.24135-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Christopher E. Brown wrote:
>
> > The smtp client restriction is based off of the mailserver that
> > connects to you, its IP address, name, etc...  *Not* anything in the
> > header (should postfix accepts the message a new line is added to the
> > header based on this info).
>
>   Ah! _Now_ I understand. Makes sense now.
>
> > That being said, if it is impossible to fix the backup MX, look into
> > postfix header_checks.  You can do a rexexp against the header for the
> > offending system.
>
>   Yup, that's just what I'll do.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Rich

I would suggest running for a while with a WARN target rather than
REJECT on your new rule for at least a few days.  It is easy to write
to permissive a regexp.

Make sure of how you set it up, postfix (depending on config and
compile options) supports egrep style regexp as well as PCRE.

Try to write a tuned regexp,

/^Received: from drizzle\.pdxlinux\.org/

is alot lower overhead than

/drizzle\.pdxlinux\.org/

or

/^Received:.*drizzle\.pdxlinux\.org/

(bind to start or end of line and minimize drifting matches).

You can burn *alot* of CPU here, as the regexps are run against *all*
messages.  header_checks is not to bad, body_checks is an easy way to
overload the system (think drift matching against a 5MB mime64
encode...)

Chris

I route, therefore you are.

> # control keys, use:

>

> 
> in your /etc/X11/XF86Config-4 file)
>

Here's some real food for thought: where do all these magically experienced, 
skilled people come from? This bullshit of abusing 'permatemps', H1B workers, 
and other dodges to avoid mentoring and training real honest-to-gosh 
employees is very old and very wrong. Or perhaps there is a secret foundry 
where these top-flight people are produced?

Carla

On Friday 12 July 2002 04:53 pm, you wrote:
> Linux, UNIX, and network professionals seeking work in the Portland are
> are running into the "buyers" market mentality.
>
> This is illustrated by a recent Portland Area Cisco Users Group mailing
> list posting by a hiring manager, containing the following statement:
>
> "..you are only worth what the market will bear, and what someone is
> willing to pay you."
>
> Below is a lightly edited version of my response to that posting.
>
> ==========
>
> Most successful managers know, or learn by experience, that hiring the
> best people for $X pays off *much* better than hiring less than the best
> for $<X.  Usually the best people are insulted by offers of $<X.  The
> manager and company making the offer soon earn the reputation of being
> cheap.  This is a liability in a "small town" like Portland where the
> word quickly get around.
>
> Some managers suffering from magical thinking are applying a mythical
> man-month principle by thinking that hiring two for the price of one
> produces twice the work.  The fallacy of this thinking was exposed more
> than 25 years ago by Frederick P. Brooks in the classic "The Mythical
> Man-Month."  Twenty years later, the first revised edition of this book
> reaffirms the original principles.
>
> The best people bring a wealth of experience and depth of understanding
> to a job that lesser experienced people are lacking.  It's wishful
> thinking that sending a lesser experienced person off to training will
> close the gap.
>
> Anyone sent off to training may return with some more experience and a
> better depth of understanding.  But even this incremental improvement
> doesn't come close to closing the experience gap, and the ability to
> solve difficult problems.
>
> There's no substitute for experience and depth of understanding.  Paying
> the price is a bargain.  First rate managers know this.  They know that
> the best people usually out performs several lesser experienced people
> combined.  What a bargain!
>
> Being a hiring manager for several years, one phenomena that ceases to
> amaze me is first rate managers hire first rate people, and second rate
> managers hire third rate people.
>
> Food for thought.
>
> ...John

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Here's some real food for thought: where do all these magically experienced,
> skilled people come from? This bullshit of abusing 'permatemps', H1B workers,
> and other dodges to avoid mentoring and training real honest-to-gosh
> employees is very old and very wrong. Or perhaps there is a secret foundry
> where these top-flight people are produced?
[snip]

Yes, there is a secret foundry of sorts, it's called a word processor, all
I have to do is type in the following lines:

   Skills:  12 years Java/J2EE experience
            27 years MC68000 assembly

and magically I am an expert! :-)  Of course the fact that neither of
these technologies have been around for the length of time given goes
right past the hiring managers, and what's worse, often the engineering
managers miss it to.

This is why so many of the companies that use permatemps and H1B at
extremely low rates either fold or get all their money from government
contracts (the only organization I know that pays whether or not you
deliver the goods), people who are willing to work that cheap often don't
have any experience with many of the skills listed on their resumes (HTML
and Javascript skills certainly can't be what is often claimed given how
broken most web sites are).  Reports that I have seen over the last few
years indicate that resume fraud is massive these days because no one
bothers to check anything.  I guess I shouldn't be surprized, I've been
doing contract work for 14 years, and despite the fact that many companies
I have worked for require references, not once in the last 12 years has
anyone actually contacted one of my references.

Anyone need a consultant with 20 years of Linux kernel experience? :-)

Subject: [PLUG] Next: ppp via the cell phone

  We're on a roll here today. Solved the key mapping problems in both CLI
and X, so let's try for the Big One: connecting to my ISP from my notebook
via the cell phone. The connection works just fine with the pcmcia modem and
a land line, by the way.

  Here's where I am: /etc/ppp/options, /etc/ppp/net-chat and
/etc/ppp/ppp-secrets all correct to invoke PAP upon login. When I try to
dial in using 'ifup ppp0', the connection is made up to the point of the LCP
(link control protocol) establishment; that's when the connection times out.
So, back to the PPP-HOWTO.

  Working my way through to check that I have everything correct, I get to
Chapter 17: Setting up the PPP connection manually. As root, I invoke
minicom with the phone on, configured for data/fax operation and the cable
connecting the two devices. Minicom reports that I'm online. Can't hang up.
Always online. Anyway, by entering the phone number after 'atdt ', I get the
login prompt, so I do. Few seconds later, I see the ppp gibberish and I know
that the connection's established.

  According to the HOWTO, I now exit minicom without resetting (by pressing
ctrl-a q). Do that. Then I enter the string, 'pppd -d -detach /dev/ttyS1
19200 &'. I'm supposed to see modem lights flashing, but of course there are
no such lights on the cell phone. So I just type 'ifconfig' looking to see
the ppp connection come up. It never does. Eventually the attempt times out.
According to /var/log/messages, the following (abreviated) entries are
recorded:
	send (AT ...)
	expect (OK)
	^M
	NO CARRIER
	 -- failed
	Failed (NO CARRIER)
	Connect script failed.
	Exit

  The cell phone is still on so I don't know why the carrier was dropped.

  What shall I do to try to debug this?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jul 12 15:53:06 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 15:53:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Scheduling the Space-Time Continuum with Minkowsky (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121551410.19569-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  FYI.

Rich

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Scheduling the Space-Time Continuum with Minkowsky
By Eric Foster-Johnson

Billed as the Space/Time manager, Minkowsky uses a client-server approach to
allow group members to share and manage their schedules together. The
Minkowsky server manages the data for all users while allowing them to
access the schedule data from the Minkowsky client running on the users'
desktop PCs.

Within Minkowsky, you can schedule meetings when everyone is free, avoid
conflicts for meeting rooms, send out email invitations to meeting
participants as well as reminder messages closer to the meeting time.
Minkowsky sends email messages to the registered email address, which is
stored in the Minkowsky address book rather than the local user address
books, for each user invited to the meeting. This feature specifically
allows you to add outside participants, such as non-employees, to meetings.

The Minkowsky user interface allows you to view group schedules and see, for
example, how many meetings are going on each month (generally, too many).
The user interface seems nicely laid out and easy to follow.

The name Minkowsky comes from a play on words in German, where scheduling
software can be described as managing space/time -- as in the space-time
continuum. In physics, Minkowsky diagrams are used to display the space-time
continuum. All this makes for a memorable name and fun play on words.

Written in the Tcl scripting language with the Tix extensions as well as
addition extensions written in C++, Minkowsky should run on most Linux
systems. It does not depend on a database, instead using built-in
database-like functionality.

You can download versions for Intel and PowerPC versions of Linux from
http://itw.itworld.com/GoNow/a14724a60952a76073993a5 Minkowsky should also
work on most other versions of UNIX and a MacOS X port also is in the works.

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 12 17:03:15 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 17:03:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hire the Best
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207121339170.9959-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121559400.15721-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> The natural question on my mind, is there any hope for honest resumes?

When the economy is good, there is certainly hope for the honest ones,
because demand is greater than the supply.  With the current economy, I
think honest resumes don't fare as well because companies tend to only
look at the "best" resumes.  Of course, people who lie on their resumes do
get caught, sometimes companies check with past employers, some companies
make prospective employees take tests of their skills, and of course,
sometimes they will get caught after they are hired when fellow employees
find they aren't able to do the work with any degree of competence.

> And the next question, how should I benchmark my abilities so that I don't
> claim too much?

My approach is to simply list what skills I have, but no description of
the the skill level (frankly there wouldn't be room), then if they ask
about a particular skill, I can tell them about my experience in that
area, how long it lasted, what depth of knowledge I feel I have attained,
etc..  Generally, the important thing is your interviewing skills once you
get an interview (or even for pre-interview telephone conversations),
because they will probably be more important to an employer's decision
than your resume once you have made it to an interview.  Never lie or even
exagerate on a resume, if you feel the need to lie, you presumably feel
your resume is inadequate, so go learn some new skills on your own, create
a project just for the sake of learning something.  If you need more
experience, do some volunteer work (non-profits often need help with
computer skills, web sites, network setup, computer configuration, etc.),
join local groups in your area of interest and get involved, give
presentations in your area(s) of interest, etc..  All of these things can
help to make a resume more marketable, and in particular, more competitive
with the bogus resumes out there.

   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 12 17:18:03 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 17:18:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Problem w/ swap
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121616210.1757-100000@12-225-29-45.client.attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207121704520.15932-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Keith wrote:

>  I had a file go into a loop and max out my HD to 100%.
> The problem now appears to be that the swap partition
> is no longer functioning. I also have a new device
> that is mounted /dev/shm, here is the fstab file:
>
> LABEL=/                 /                       ext3    defaults        1 1
> LABEL=/boot             /boot                   ext3    defaults        1 2
> none                    /dev/pts                devpts  gid=5,mode=620  0 0
> none                    /proc                   proc    defaults        0 0
> none                    /dev/shm                tmpfs   defaults        0 0
> /dev/hdb3               swap                    swap    defaults        0 0
> /dev/cdrom              /mnt/cdrom              iso9660 noauto,owner,kudzu,ro 0 0
> /dev/fd0                /mnt/floppy             auto    noauto,owner,kudzu 0 0
> /dev/hda1		/mnt/hda		vfat	noauto,user,ro	0 0
>
> When I do a df command only the /dev/hdb1 and /dev/hdb2 are displayed.
> Any ideas on what I should do?

I'm guessing your problem is with the /dev/shm mount, it is a "tmpfs" file
system.  This is used in a manner similar to /tmp or /var/tmp, except that
the tmpfs file system keeps all of the data in virtual memory (this is
very useful for swap files on virtual machines and other applications
that need fast access temp files).  So if you have any programs using the
tmpfs file system, it could easily consume all of your swap space.  Since
it is being mounted at /dev/shm, I would take a look at this directory to
see what is being stored there.  If you have the kernel sources handy, you
can read a little more about tmpfs under the Documentation/filesystems
directory.

> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Shannon C. Dealy
> Sent: Friday, July 12, 2002 5:18 PM
>
>
> I'm guessing your problem is with the /dev/shm mount, it is a
> "tmpfs" file
> system.  This is used in a manner similar to /tmp or
> /var/tmp, except that
> the tmpfs file system keeps all of the data in virtual memory (this is
> very useful for swap files on virtual machines and other applications
> that need fast access temp files).  So if you have any
> programs using the
> tmpfs file system, it could easily consume all of your swap
> space.  Since
> it is being mounted at /dev/shm, I would take a look at this
> directory to
> see what is being stored there.  If you have the kernel
> sources handy, you
> can read a little more about tmpfs under the Documentation/filesystems
> directory.
>

For more info on /dev/shm you can try the kernel doc's 'Configure.help'
and 'devices.txt' as well.


$ rpm -qf /dev/shm
kernel-2.4.9-13
dev-3.2-5


$ grep "/dev/shm" /usr/src/linux-2.4.9-13/Documentation/*

/usr/src/linux-2.4.9-13/Documentation/Configure.help:
  tmpfs            /dev/shm        tmpfs           defaults  0 0
/usr/src/linux-2.4.9-13/Documentation/Configure.help:
  if necessary (/dev/shm is automagically created if you use devfs).
/usr/src/linux-2.4.9-13/Documentation/devices.txt:
/dev/shm      shmfs           POSIX shared memory maintenance access

Ciao a tutti,

Simple question, probably in a FAQ or prior post, but perhaps it bears
repetition.  Are HTML pages normally compressed between the Web server
and the browser, and if so, at what level does this happen?

I'm an opponent of using tabs in source code, and the only strong
argument I've heard in support of it is that it reduces the number of
0x20 characters served in an HTML page, which may be a valid concern for
some of the indentation junkies with whom I've worked.  (You know who
you are.)  So I'm looking for an educated retort to that argument.

Thanks,

--Jason V. C.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 12 18:20:45 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 18:20:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] HTML Whitespace Compression
Message-ID: <663034512.1026523230541.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Jason Van Cleve jason at vancleve.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Simple question, probably in a FAQ or prior post, but perhaps it bears
> repetition.  Are HTML pages normally compressed between the Web server
> and the browser, and if so, at what level does this happen?

No, they are not normally compressed unless it's over an SSL (HTTPS,
encrypted) session.

> I'm an opponent of using tabs in source code, and the only strong
> argument I've heard in support of it is that it reduces the number of
> 0x20 characters served in an HTML page, which may be a valid concern
> for some of the indentation junkies with whom I've worked.  (You know
> who you are.)  So I'm looking for an educated retort to that argument.

I've worked with sites that reduce their bandwidth costs by stripping
whitespace from HTML on the theory that the browsers don't need it and
nobody really looks at that stuff anyhow.

I would argue that stripping those 200 bytes out of a 25,000 byte document
is pointless when they could reduce the bandwidth costs even more by
eliminating some of the extraneous images and/or javascript and/or CSS
sent along with that highly optimized HTML.

... but they didn't ask me.

  -- Steve

PS: I like to use spaces since they always contain a consistent amount of
whitespace.  Tabs often allow for things to be misaligned when some lines
are tab-indented and others are space-indented.

From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)

In-Reply-To: <20020712183142.5b9a9a56.jason@vancleve.com>

> On Fri, 12 Jul 2002 18:20:45 -0700 (PDT)
> "Steve Bonds" <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> wrote:
> 
> > PS: I like to use spaces since they always contain a consistent
> > amount of whitespace.  Tabs often allow for things to be
> > misaligned when some lines are tab-indented and others are
> > space-indented.
> 
> Exactly, that's my big qualm.  I wonder if there is an apache mod
> that can strip out white space at the beginning of lines, for HTML
> pages.  That would be even more effective than using tabs, and it's
> doubtful it would affect the browser output.

Not.

The stripper (I just had to call it that :-) would have to parse the
i/o stream to know when it's sending bits that are sensitive to 
whitespace, especially

* <pre> ...  </pre> text (imagine how a python script could be 
  munged -- gives me the shivers just thinking about it)

* quoted strings in JavaScript, or any client-parsed script

* strings in forms

Honestly, if web performance hinges on the stripping of whitespace, 
then computer science is a lost, lost cause.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

The PRE tag is one exception, you're right.  But still I doubt it would

power, but not that much.

> * quoted strings in JavaScript, or any client-parsed script

How would quoted strings be a problem?  They start with a quote, not

about it.

I've seen in some (very large) pages, this could have an impact after
all.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jul 12 21:57:38 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 21:57:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] HTML Whitespace Compression
In-Reply-To: <20020712205655.67817976.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207122142510.21055-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> > * quoted strings in JavaScript, or any client-parsed script
> 
> How would quoted strings be a problem?  They start with a quote, not
> whitespace.  Remember, I'm just talking about whitespace at the start of
> lines, not everywhere.

I've never actually tried doing a multi-line string in JavaScript, but 
my hunch is that it's possible, just like it is in, say, Perl:

my $str = qq/
ooh

                this

     whitespace is part
  of the string
/;

And the minute you say, oh, OK, we'll make an exception for 
JavaScript, then you'll end up changing a standard Internet protocol
every time a new client-side scripting language evolves. I just don't 
think the HTTP protocol should bear the burden of defining what is and 
isn't significant whitespace.

> > * strings in forms
> 
> You mean as in a TEXTAREA?  That's probably another exception, but
> like PRE, it shouldn't be that hard.

In Textareas, yeah, and in <option value="blah">, where the value 
string could, according to the HTML spec, span lines. It's unlikely, 
granted, but a stripper could violate the integrity of a legitimate 
string.

> I'm actually a little suprised there's no compression features in
> HTTP.  Seems like the browser could request a page and indicate that
> it supports a simple compression of some sort, and the server could
> then compress it on its way out.

Some clients, even old ones like Mosaic, supported some forms of
decompression on the fly, but it's certainly not part of the HTTP
protocol.  Under some circumstances, like when the client and server 
are communicating at ethernet speeds, compression can actually slow
things down.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 12 22:23:44 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 2002 22:23:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] HTML Whitespace Compression
In-Reply-To: <20020712205655.67817976.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207122215110.16530-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

[snip]
> I'm actually a little suprised there's no compression features in HTTP.
> Seems like the browser could request a page and indicate that it
> supports a simple compression of some sort, and the server could then
> compress it on its way out.  Given the amazing volume of indentation
> I've seen in some (very large) pages, this could have an impact after
> all.
[snip]

Actually there is support for this, but it's optional and rarely used,
I used to have my server setup for it years ago, but I found that not very
many people were able to use it because their browsers didn't support it.
Check the "Accept-Encoding" HTTP header field and the "Content-Encoding"
Entity header for more info.  Also, some browsers support (or used to
support) in their default configuration, uncompressing and displaying HTML
web pages if they had the appropriate compression suffix on the file, such
as: index.html.gz which would be automatically uncompressed and displayed.
I haven't tried any of this for several years, so I don't know what is
supported by current browsers.

> had is because the economy is tanking. The economy is tanking because of
> the liars and the criminals.

No, the economy has tanked because we are in a recession. Go look at your 
history, the economy has been on a boom and bust cycle. It is called the 
business cycle. The good times will come back again.

Will they be the same as the boom times of the 90s? No. They will be 
different and likely different sectors will drive it. There will be more 
tech jobs along with this boom but it is very likely that wages will 
not be as high as they were in recent years. Perhaps it will be nurses 
that will see higher wages or some other area of shortage. But yes things 
will get better in the tech sector as everything else does depend on it. 
Perhaps it will be biotech, pharmaceuticals, and medical type industries 
that really drive things in the coming years.That will mean more jobs for 
people who can develop good software solutions, databases, administer 
systems/networks, support desktops, etc., etc. Things will get better but 
perhaps not at as high a wages and not as high a demand as before.

It is possible that the tech industry could come out of all this pain 
stronger, more stable, more sustainable, and healthies than before. 
Perhaps it will be more like a table candle that burns steadily than like 
a roman candle that burns bright and goes out. Perhaps all this pain has a 
purpose as it were.

> True. But there is a middle ground between communism and unfettered
> capitalism without rules and regulation, isn't there?

Clearly, the SEC needs to do a much, much better job of enforcing the 
laws. I think there is a consensus now that the lying and cheating is not 
acceptable.

> There is a middle ground. I think. Somewhere there, though, we decided the
> private sector did EVERYTHING better. So everything was privatized and
> deregulated. Maybe it's okay if we retreat from that bad idea a little
> bit. The govt. is often inefficient and often crooked. But it should be
> apparant that an unregulated market is just as bad, if not worse.

We don't have an "unregulated market". We have plenty of regulations. In 
some areas the laws have not been enforced very effectively. That clearly 
needs to change.

The private sector does do many things better. At the same time there is 
an appropriate role for government. We have a pretty large government now 
that does many things. The suggestion that the size of government has 
shrunk substantially in recent years is not supported by the facts.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

Carla,
I would prefer to take this discussion off the list but let me answer on your 
questions.

On Friday 12 July 2002 12:39 pm, you wrote:
> Kinda going over the line there, Alex. It's not right to accuse someone
> this way. I know many honest people who are honest all the time. Don't know
> what circles you travel in, or what you mean by "sneaky moves." How can you
> be sneaky? A customer will find out real quick if you can deliver on your
> promises. If you can't, no more customer, and no more staying in business.
>
> Carla
>
Here is my story:
I was working for two start up High Tech companies as a process engineer and 
later as a test engineer during first and the second Japanese crisis. 
One company was wafer manufacturer in Hillsboro OR , the second one is a 
circuit manufacturing foundry in Camas WA.
In both cases I had to meet with vendors on order to make conclusion and 
report for the higher management what production equipment brand we have to 
purchase for my area of manufacturing process. 
The same things did other process engineers for their areas of responsibility.
In other words our start up companies tried to get a bang for a buck.  
You can imagine how vigorously potential equipment vendors were truing to 
sell their equipment and services. 
They were lieing about technical characteristics and throughoutput of their 
products and were mixing their competitors with the dirt.
They proposed unbelievable prime service plans for their brands e.t.c.
They tried to bribe me with so called presentation dinners and so called 
business presents one of them was a brand new HP KAYAK with 21" monitor 
for my personal home usage.  I was too stupud to not accept these presents.
They were lobbying higher management up to the CEO level and bribe them as 
well but on a much higher level. 
I did research about each type of the equipment and submitted all conclusions 
based on a real information to the management for the final approval. 
Finally in both cases we purchased equipment nether the best quality nether 
for the best price.   
Because some unscurpulos vendors were more successful in lobbying and bribing 
upper management than others.
Since we bought their equipment we pretty much got into their traps.
They cheap promotional service plans magically evaporated and new plans 
they proposed added up to 30% to the capital cost of the equipment itself.
Installed and connected manufacturing equipment is not a VCR which you can 
return to a store if you dissatisfied with its quality.  
You have to live with it for the next 10-15 years being riped off by the 
vendors for the each emergency call to fix their darn thing which stopped 
working right in the middle of a process in a midnight.  
I've been through all this hell.
Next story about broken promises on stock options at my second start up 
company in Camas WA. 
I still keep its CEO e-mail with promise to go public after we reach 
profitability.  All Engineers and productions were working like dogs for 
12-14 hours a day during start up period in a good hope to get a chunk of 
wealth from the corporate pie and retire before 50.   
When we've reached targeted profitability, upper management have forgotten 
about all their promises.  Guess who got the money?
Some employees started a law suit others just left the company. 
So I did. There was even an article in Oregonian about this case.

Carla, take off your rosy glasses and lets finish this thread for good.
Amin. 


Alex

From bsr at spek.org  Sat Jul 13 01:11:27 2002
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: 13 Jul 2002 01:11:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] HTML Whitespace Compression
In-Reply-To: 
	<65284.12.231.181.15.1026539253.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
References: <20020712205655.67817976.jason@vancleve.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0207122215110.16530-100000@critter.deatech.com> 
	<65284.12.231.181.15.1026539253.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <1026547887.25208.2001.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Fri, 2002-07-12 at 22:47, Dan Young wrote:
> mod_gzip for apache...
> 
> http://www.remotecommunications.com/apache/mod_gzip/
> 
> I also don't know about browser support for this. The FAQ says HTTP 1.1
> compliant browsers will accept gzipped content. Everybody else fails down
> to uncompressed content.

For the major browser, I believe IE 4.0+ supports it (although IE 4.5
(and perhaps 5) on the Mac don't - grrr).  For IE make sure you've got
HTTP 1.1 checked on under advanced options.

Netscape 4.06+ also supports it, versions below 4.5 have buggy support
for externally referenced (rather than inline) javascript and CSS
though.

Assuming you can spare the CPU time on the web server, HTML compresses
*very* well and can help out your bandwidth challenged users.  mod_gzip
is pretty handy, it'll compress all output to the browser - CGI, PHP,
Zope, whatever, as long as the browser tells the server that it can
accept gzipped content.  mod_gzip will also cache static files so they
don't have to be continually recompressed over and over.  YMMV though,
an image intensive site won't be helped that much by compressing the
html.

--Brent

> would affect the browser output.

  Doesn't this cut to the heart of the issue with html? That is, that rather
than being solely a content markup language derived as a subset of sgml,
it's had formatting tags added to it, too. This (or so I've read) causes all
sorts of problems in terms of viewing certain pages on certain browsers.

  My understanding is that it's best to tag content but let each browser
decide on the presentation format. May be difficult to do nowadays, but is
it worth trying?

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Are you always telling the truth to your clients about your service, 
> capabilities and competitors?

Alex,

  I don't fudge the facts to clients and prospective clients. I don't need
to. I've testimonial letters and a verifiable track record that backs up
what I tell them. I don't know how to fudge my previous record. Either I've
obtained permits for my clients or I haven't. Either the reclamation I've
designed and implemented has worked or it hasn't: the proof is on the ground
for all to see. When I've designed plans and programs the results are
readily available to anyone who wants to read them. I don't talk about
competitors at all.

> Sometimes you may have to make some sneaky moves just to stay in business.
> Isn't it a true?

  No. For a consultant that's fatal.

  I don't undertake work that I'm not capable of doing -- and doing well.
Don't forget that almost all the work that I do for clients ends up in a
permit application or report to a public agency (the regulator) at the
county, state or federal levels of government. If I tried to make things up
it would affect not only me but my client as well. Credibility and
reputation are everything.

Rich

Thought I'd share this story since everything seems to be OT today:

It is 3Q 2030.

You're arguing with your wife again. It seems she's missed her spending
quota again this quarter. A proud patriot, you have no problem spending
85% and sometimes 90% of your income on consumer goods, yet she can't
manage to spend even close to the 75% required by law. It's that foreign
mentality, you suppose--that's what happens when you are educated overseas
and without the benefit of a corporate sponsor. You have to remind her
that if the Internal Consumer's Service (ICS) catches her, she'll be doing
time in Philip Morris(TM) Prison like her uncle.

Oh well, hopefully a night at the town's
AOL-Time-Warner-Clear-Channel-Blockbuster(TM) Authorized Media
Distribution Center will smooth things over with her. That reminds
you--you need to have your eye- and ear-implants inspected for this
quarter again, otherwise you won't even be allowed in tonight.

You haven't attended church services for a while. Although your wife is a
devout follower of God's Customers(TM) and shops in the Church Store at
LEAST five times a quarter, you're not yet convinced that converting from
Consumers For Jesus(TM) was that sound an investment.

Your son Rick has just graduated from the local McDonalds(TM) High School.
You want him to go to Pepsi(TM) University like his sister, but he wants
to go to Coke(TM) College. Not that it matters--the permits you get at
either school are the same. Although he really wanted to attend
Stanford(TM), his corporate sponsors rejected that proposal, based on what
it might do to his credit rating.

Your youngest daughter just graduated Pepsi(TM) U. It was expensive, but
she is all set now, having received a Creative Thought Permit and a
Entrepreneurship License. On top of that she's accepted a job at Fortune
10 corporation. Of course almost everyone works for a Fortune 10 nowadays,
there being only thirty-some corporations left. It's too bad she had to
sign all those NDA's though--you'd really like to be allowed to know where
she would be living and how to get in touch with her. Ahh well, it's the
price you pay for our corporate security.

Your older daughter, after twenty quarters of employment, was finally
permitted to tell you that she is working in middle-management at AT&T. Of
course, every job in the United Corporations of America is
middle-management. The cheaper--skilled--labor is all outsourced to Those
Other Countries, whatever they are called. In ten more quarters, assuming
her credit rating remains good and she has attained Shareholder status,
she'll be allowed to talk face-to-face (no encrypted channel) with us
again!

Apparently, her five year old daughter has been grounded again, this time
for racking up a $6000 fine--singing "Happy Birthday(TM)" at a party
without a Media Distribution License. She really needs to be taught a
lesson--that as a patriotic Consumer of the UCA, she needs to respect the
rights of Shareholders and property owners. What dangerous thoughts she
has! She thinks she should be allowed to say whatever she pleases, no
matter what it does to someone else's portfolio! No one can get it through
to her that terrorist ideas like that will land her in one of those
"special" schools--and she'd be subjected to a lower quarterly limit on
all her credit cards.

Fax from your wife--she'll be late tonight. Corporate HQ has re-instated
fourteen-hour work days until the end of this quarter. It's too bad she's
not allowed to quit her job--you could get her a pretty sweet management
position any time in your department at Microsoft.

From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Sat Jul 13 07:38:13 2002
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Sat, 13 Jul 2002 07:38:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Partition Magic Clone
Message-ID: <20020713143813.97309.qmail@web13801.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings Everyone,

 During this month's PLUG meeting I proposed an idea
for a Partition Magic clone. People gave a few
pointers to already existing projects that do similar
things.

 I have googled for what I could, and I am still in
the same situation that I was in, though I now have
more code to study.

 My situation is this: One of the sources of problems
that new users have when seting up Linux for the first
time is that they usually have to repartition their
Hard Drive. I, myself, had this problem.

 The actual problem is that most newbies don't know
much about partitions. It would be easy enough to
stick in a recent version of Red Hat and do an
automatic partition, but often, new users wish to keep
Windows.

 The next alternative is FIPS, that is nice for what
it does, but there are still problems with it. One can
also try GNU parted, but after trying it, it's not
that easy for a newbie (I found it 'easy enough' for
my own use).

 The other option is Partition Magic. Partition Magic
is quite a piece of software. It can do all the MS
type partitions and Linux partitions. It has an
excelent user interface, and even the text version it
pretty good. But it's proprietary. And I'm sick of
wondering "How do they do that?!", and having a(n)
EULA thrown into my face.

 GNU Parted is close to what I was thinking: You pop
in a disk and boot it. The thing starts up and you can
do your work. But the user interface isn't that good
for newbies and it doesn't have support for all the
file systems that PartMag does.

 So basicly, I want to make a PartMag clone, with the
exception that it will be *slightly* different, in a
better way. I don't know how yet, but that's the plan.

 Anyway I need hackers, coders, testers, and any other
form of help. If anyone can help, it would be
appreciated. If anyone knows of some other program,
tool, or other source of information, please tell me
about it.

That's about it. Thanks in advance.

Sincerely,
Vincent Damewood

When it was a local operation run by a local guy with knowledge,
it was a good place.  Yeah, it was a bit cheap, but you knew it.
At least there was someone who understood routing protocols and
how to type commands at a Linux console that you could talk to,
usually 18 hours a day, and on call the last 6.

Then, he sold the company to a canadian ISP-gobbler, and took his cash
and ran.  I don't blame him for that, but yes, the conditions under
which my box was there completely changed, without an appropriate
change in price.  Hence, we got the hell outtta there.

I'm now at sprocketdata.com, with basically the same price as I was
paying at Inetarena, but back to the same levels of service (or better)
as the "old" Inetarena.

Typical exchange.  I decide on friday afternoon at 5:45pm *their*
time, that I want to install a new box, spelling out the
configuration.  I get email within 20 minutes saying it'll be ready
monday morning, and is that soon enough?

These guys rock.  The only downside is that they're in texas, so I'm
not likely to ever touch the box running stonehenge.com.  Who cares? :)

> Hi All Guys
>
> I have Gcombust newly installed on RH7.3 which has an IDE CD-Writer and an
> IDE CD-ROM
>
> When I started to burn a CD-RW, following warning pop-up
>
> Cdrecord 1.10 (i666-pc-linux-gnu Copyright (C) 1995-2001 Jorg Schilling
> TOC Tye: 1 = CD-ROM
> scsidev: '0,6,0'
> scsibus: 0 target: 6 lun: 0
> Linux sg driver version: 3.1.22
> /usr/bin/cdrecord: No such file or directory.  Cannot open SCSI driver.
> /usr/bin/cdrecord: for possible targets try 'cdrecord -scanbus'.  Make sure

> How to make it works as user.

> Stephen Liu
>

Check the permissions on usr/bin/cdrecord, most likely wants you to run it as 
root. See the Gcombust FAQ for why: 
http://www.abo.fi/~jmunsin/gcombust/FAQ.shtml

It gives a non-root workaround which entails creating a new group & user.

On Fri, 12 Jul 2002 21:57:38 -0700 (PDT)
Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> wrote:

> every time a new client-side scripting language evolves. I just don't 
> think the HTTP protocol should bear the burden of defining what is and 
> isn't significant whitespace.

You make some good points, Paul.  But let's remember we're talking about
two different solutions.  One is a server plugin that actual strips the
HTML on the way out (obviously an ugly idea, as you argue, but an idea
still); and the other is lossless compression between the server and
client, and that's where HTTP would come in.

--Jason V. C.



From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jul 13 09:34:53 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Sat, 13 Jul 2002 09:34:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hire the Best
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207130630490.13687-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207130904500.6588-100000@localhost.localdomain>

You know the big corporations do not just run on air, they are fueled 
daily by the spending decisions of millions. It is funny, by far the 
biggest complainers about corporate America I know are by far the most 
full of shit about the issue.

They could not possibly support corporate America any more than they do:

They live in Beaverton or some other suburb, must drive absolutely 
everywhere (even to do some simple errand), subscribe to 
cable television and Internet, shop at large chain store shopping centers, 
spend much or possibly most of their disposable income on a multitude of 
consumer products especially various tech gadgets made by large 
corporations. Oh, and I almost forgot, have shelves and refridgerators 
full of processed food (grown by corporate farms and processed by 
corporate food processors). For a night out: Outback Steakhouse or one of 
the other suburbun chain restaurants. There lives could not be more tuned 
to supporting and growing the size of major corporations. From the 
corporations point of view they are the perfect consumers and supporters 
of their power.

And then have the gaul to complain about how corporations run everything, 
blah, blah, blah.

It is relatively easy to make spending and lifestyle decisions that 
support your small businesses and local organic farmers and lessen your 
support of the large corporations and corporate farms.

There are a lot of people that do a way better job than me at this 
philosophy but I am working on it. I buy fresh unprocessed food and 
vegetables either from New Seasons Market (locally owned) or from 
Organicstoyou.org (locally owned). Both outfits try to buy locally 
whenever possible and support the small farmer. I try to avoid processed 
food whever possible. Believe it or not this sort of approach takes very 
little extra effort. New Seasons is convenient and organicstoyou delivers 
a box of vegetables each week (no more expensive than store bought). There 
are other good methods such as Saturday Market and others. And fresh 
food is way, way, way better tasting. Places like New Seasons also try to 
follow the same philosophy with things like meat and fish, etc.

I minimize commercial television partially because 99% of shows suck but 
also because I don't want to see commercials. Television commercials are 
toxic. I do watch a couple sitcoms that I like and I watch the new Star 
Trek (Enterprise) but I limit it to that. Other television is through OPB 
which is public broadcasting (channel 10). I don't have cable. For radio I 
stick to the public radio with occasional forays into AM talk.

For Internet I go with Pacifier, who briefly was owned by an ISP grabber, 
but now is back in local hands (Doug Palin again).

When I want to go out to eat I always go to a locally owned restaurant, 
which are almost always better than the chains.

I recently discovered a locally owned greeting card store that is very 
cool. Many of the cards are made by local (Portland and Seattle) artists 
and make Hallmark cars look trite and stupid.

Granted things like books, movies, clothing, etc., are almost always made 
by large corporations; that does not mean you have to buy them from 
corporate outlets.

As I said, I am a mere novice on this path. For example, I drive a car 
(corporate produced) that burns fuel (corporate produced).

My point is that each of us votes with our dollars every day. WE are the 
problem not some distant corporations. They don't just magically appear 
and become powerful. They become powerful because you give them your 
dollars. Why do people in small towns vote -- with their dollars -- for 
Wallmart instead of supporting Main Street? They are in effect voting for 
Wallmart. They have chosen cheaper over having a viable downtown business 
commmunity and keeping the profits local.

I believe in freedom and I believe that you need to vote with every action 
you take. We have used this freedom to create what you see today and where 
you think things are going in the future. And I believe in America and 
what it stands for and its potential. But it is you not them. There is no 
them.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

> to do even the little bit they could do to make the world better for those
> closest to them and around them.

Oh, and I forgot to add that part of the reason I'm pissed about this
economy is that I'm doing my part for my family. I may live in
Beaverton (which in and of itself is evil for some reason), but I
when I bought my house here on the light rail, part of my plan was
to help my brother get on their feet. Now both of them, 21 and 24,
live with my wife and I and we rent to them for cheap and help them
out with money to try to get them on their feet. Does that count as
helping, since we're helping to make two more people self-sufficient, or
does it count as hurting since we live in the evil that is Beaverton?

I also send money to my parents when I can, but often it's in the form
of a gift certificate to no-longer-locally-owned Fred Meyer. That makes me
part of the problem, I suppose.

Preston

produced by large corporations. That to me is not an inherent evil.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jul 13 12:27:34 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Next: ppp via the cell phone

On Sat, 13 Jul 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard at appl-ecosys.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> On Fri, 12 Jul 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
> > There is a switch to turn on more debugging information for pppd.  Not
> > sure what it is off the top of my head but you should try turning it up
> > higher and watch (tail -f) the /var/log/messages file to make sure what
> > you're reading in the messages file is happening as pppd is trying to
> > start.
> 
> Rod,
> 
>   The switch is '-d' for debug. This is all following the instructions in
> Chapter 17 of the PPP-HOWTO. I, too, was surprized about the paucity of
> information generated by that option to pppd.

I kind of recall two gotchas when I set up ppp for debugging:

1) syslog must be set to log messages sent at the
"debug" level.  I.e. in /etc/syslog.conf "*.debug /var/log/debug".

2) The ppp kernel module has a debug option as well.  I think that this
was done using the "kdebug 4" option.  Most of the real useful info comes
from it.

This is two to three year old info, so things might be a bit different
now.

  -- Steve

Poor man. Winderz has that effect on a lot of people.

Use NTFS for security, which means more admin chores, such as setting 
permissions and having user accounts, use FAT16 or 32 for easy. Files will be 
magically translated for the different machines as they travel over the 
network.

Carla

Ken,


If it's just going to be a backup system then the choice is not
important.

I'd just stick with ext2 - well supported, mature and you shouldn't
care about fsck's.

If you do care about fsck's and want a journaling system then I
recommend reiserfs.  I've been using it for quite a while with 0
problems.

Brian

If you're running snort and/or other forms of intrusion detection, it
can be very informative to portscan hosts from which you've received
scans or compromise attempts.

You will then also have the opportunity to provide the owner of the
compromised system with useful information, such as "you have an ssh
daemon backdoor listening on tcp port 54321", should you care to inform
them.

--Stafford
