On Sat, 13 Jul 2002, Jason Dagit wrote:

> This email is less about getting people to commit and more about asking
> people how much they would be willing to donate.

Cool, an alternative sponsor for RMS! Excellent. I actually emailed him 
about speaking at a PLUG meeting and he said yes as long as you change 
your name to Portland GNU User's Group. Until we change our name he 
insisted that there needed to be *another* sponsor and you have stepped 
up. Here is what I learned from talking to RMS:

1. He requires only an airline ticket and, presumably care and feeding 
when he gets here (e.g., meals).

2. He does not require a hotel room. He said he would be just as happy to 
sleep on someone's couch or whatever. In fact, I think he would be happier 
in a private home than in a hotel.

3. He loves email and would prefer access to an Internet connection for 
his laptop so he can do email. Duh!

4. He likes Chinese food.

So, essentially, you just need the cost of the ticket plus and, I think, 
whatever it would cost to feed him while he is here.

---

I also talked to Eric S. Raymond. He has more or less the same 
requirements as RMS -- the cost of a plane ticket and food. His additional 
requirement is that he says that if the flight is over 5 hours or 
something like that, it needs to be business class. I am not sure if that 
is negotiable or not.

---

As for Linus I had a go between talk to him in person and he did express 
interest in coming here but that did not get any further than that. I 
could talk to this go between and try to get a more firm commitment. I am 
not sure the cost factors for having Linus up here. My general impression 
is that he less interested in speaking than either RMS or ESR; in fact, I 
got the impression that he does except such engagements from time to time 
but not necessarely enthusiastically. If we could bill it as less of a 
formal talk and more of light social hour type thing with beer, etc., then 
perhaps he would feel more comfortable. What do you think? A barbecue? A 
party? What?



-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

From dealy at deatech.com  Sun Jul 14 02:13:54 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sun, 14 Jul 2002 02:13:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] portscan manners?
In-Reply-To: <200207131929.g6DJTcr08603@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207140204160.19750-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 13 Jul 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> What do you consider to be 'mannerly' portscanning? Scanning all kinds of
> sites is good education and practice, but I'm leery of being an annoyance. Or
> worse, suspected of nefarious activities.

Get permission first for every IP address you wish to scan, otherwise you
are just asking for trouble.  Many systems run automated detection systems
which report scans to the originating ISP, and for most ISP's this can
result in immediate cancellation of your account.  I get regular log
reports from my firewall, and I report anything which does not appear to
be a typical virus based scan to the originating ISP, and request that
they take the appropriate action.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Jul 14 10:41:17 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun, 14 Jul 2002 10:41:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] CVS changes executable bit
Message-ID: <802143717.1026668462226.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 14 Jul 2002, Jon Jacob jon at manymoons.net XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> I am currently running a system with CVS and everytime I commit a file
> that is executable to the remote system it lands there as not
> executable.  Is this a problem on my end?  What do I do to fix it?

The way I fix this is to change the permissions inside the repository
itself.  I.e. "cd /cvsroot/path/to/your/file; chmod uog+x file"

  -- Steve






From fixin at peak.org  Sun Jul 14 12:14:41 2002
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Sun, 14 Jul 2002 12:14:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Wanted: bootable and secure linux-on-cdrom
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207141209550.18299-100000@tpol.peak.org>

I'm looking to download or build a bootable linux-on-cdrom that I can
use from insecure machines to connect securely to my home network.

Scenario: I'm visiting a public library where there are random
public-access machines that may not be well maintained.  Or I work in
a large company where unknown people have access to my cubicle.  I
want to use their machines, however insecure they are, to connect to
my network without compromising its security.

I think the solution is a bootable CD-ROM that contains enough of a
Linux distro to boot any machine and get the network up.  It'd also
contain the latest OpenSSH client, and an account for me with private
keys whose public counterparts I'd installed in the authorized_keys
files where I wanted to connect.  Ideally, the private keys would be
in an encrypted filesystem so that even if someone stole the CD-ROM
he'd not be able to read them.

It'd also be nice, though not essential, to be able to run X (with
servers for lots of video cards) so that I could xhost Mozilla, and to
have part of the CD-ROM mountable from Windoze and include a boot
floppy image and rawrite2 so that I could deal with machines that
don't boot from CD-ROM.

If I did this right, I *think* you'd need to install a hardware
keysniffer to figure out what I was doing -- even if you'd had access
to the CD-ROM.

Is there something close to this out there already?  If not, where
would you suggest I look for the parts from which to assemble it.  Can
anybody suggest an alternative way of solving the underlying problem
of connecting from an untrusted machine?

Thanks,

--Eric House

* From the desktop of: Eric House, fixin at peak.org                            *
*    Crosswords 4.0 for PalmOS is out!: <http://www.peak.org/~fixin/xwords>  *
******************************************************************************

It's also small enough to fit on one of those Pocket CD-R's that hold

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Jul 14 14:18:29 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun, 14 Jul 2002 14:18:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] CVS changes executable bit
Message-ID: <106446310.1026681493338.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 14 Jul 2002, Jon Jacob jon at manymoons.net XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> The file within the repository IS executable, unless I misunderstand
> what you mean.

Then you may have either:

1) A local "umask" setting that prevents the files from being created
executable
2) An existing copy of the file with unusual permissions set.  CVS
generally does not set permissions on files that already exist.

  -- Steve

         repeat swallow(gqview) fill: gqview -t "$file" >/dev/null 2>/dev/null

         exits: xloadimage -quiet -windowid $window "$file"
         exits: display -window $window -backdrop $file
         exits: xli -quiet -windowid $window "$file"

Nope.  The umask is set to 002 which according to umask -S is:

u=rwx,g=rwx,o=rx

So, unless I misunderstand umask, and I probably do, that is what it
should be.

From jason at vancleve.com  Sun Jul 14 20:22:41 2002

On Sun, 14 Jul 2002 15:12:48 -0700 (PDT)
"Tyler F. Creelan" <creelan at engr.orst.edu> wrote:

> How do I call plugger within my browser? I have plugger installed, and
> my/etc/pluggerc file is set up, but I don't know how to get my browser
> to

Long as it's so quiet. . . .

Plugger is a little irksome.  One thing I had to do to get it working
with Moz 1.0 is save the config' as /etc/pluggerrc-4.0, instead of
/etc/pluggerrc.  Easy to miss, since it's just pluggerrc in the archive.

Once you have the files copied correctly, you should see some change,
provided there isn't another plugin installed for the file you're trying
to view.  It'll either work, or you'll see a message somewhere in Moz's
interface.

And if you install plugger and then try to change the config' file
you'll run into another problem.  Moz' caches each plugin's supported
MIME/extensions and won't requery them--as if there were no such thing
as a configurable browser plugin.  So you have to remove plugger.so from
your plugins directory, restart Mozilla, replace plugger.so, then
restart Mozilla again to get it to update.  Icky!  There's also a file
you can delete, which is easier but may cause you other problems.

Also, if you're trying to view a file that is being served with the
wrong MIME (i.e., text/html for an MPEG), it won't work.  Technically
it's an error in the Web site, but you should be able to activate
plugger based on extensions alone, since this is a common idiocy.  If
anyone knows how to get around this, please let me know.

--Jason Van Cleve

On AOL, there is such a thing as a Group... Groups at AOL (groups.aol.com)
... if you mean that (which I don't think you do) you should be able to
chat via the chat interface.  I don't know about using the links... so
you might want to IM somebody and ask them to invite you to the chat. 
They work like regular AIM chats but are different... unlike regular AIM
chats (or regular AOL Private Rooms) they link together to a special
kind of AOL Private Chat, as well as having the AIM interface.

If you mean to ask if you can chat in a regular AOL Chat room (in a
community) you *do* need the client.  AOL 2.5 and 3.0 work well with
WinE, 4.0 works for some people, and 5.0+ tend to not work worth crap. 
And you would need an AOL account ($15/month for TCP/IP access).  You
can run Win9x inside vmware or Win4Lin.  AOL refuses to release their
very-nearly-done Linux client (which they ship through their Gateway Net
Appliances).

Let me know if you need more information!

Rob  :-)

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Fri Jul 12 09:38:24 2002
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 12 Jul 2002 09:38:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Odd Installation Problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSF.4.01.10207120836330.6007-100000@newwind.com>
References: <Pine.BSF.4.01.10207120836330.6007-100000@newwind.com>
Message-ID: <1026491904.29814.40.camel@pookie>

Dennis;

I suspect (as you imply) that your MBR is corrupt.

By the way, do you happen to have a hard drive that has it's BIOS
information written on the disk itself? Just something to consider.

The easiest way to solve this problem is to low-level format the drive
through the BIOS. Many BIOSes (in fact most) do not have low-level
formatters so do not be surprised if this is the case for you.

Barring that, the next solution is to boot from CD-ROM and execute the
following:

dd if=/dev/null of=/dev/hda bs=1024

/dev/hda, of course, refers to the primary IDE chain (Drive C:).

The above command completely writes null characters to your entire
drive. It will take some time. There will be no output.

Install Linux on your fresh drive.

Best,


Cooper

Poor man. Winderz has that effect on a lot of people.

All;

I have co-located hosted my MetaSource sight at Kattare based in
Corvallis. I must tell you that I have been very happy with the results.

standpoint, I have had zero downtime with his services.

bandwidth. Please do not quote me on this but it is not very expensive. 

What I enjoy most about the service is the ability to view statistics on
a daily basis. Kattare uses Webalizer to break down the access to your
sight by total bandwidth, which links were accessed, and the referring
page.

Bar graphs show you how your sight is doing.

I have better things to do than worry about my web sight!

From joehoffman at qwest.net  Fri Jul 12 18:34:30 2002
From: joehoffman at qwest.net (Joe Hoffman)
Date: 12 Jul 2002 19:34:30 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PJUG]  HTML Whitespace Compression
In-Reply-To: <20020712180957.52a5fc6e.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20020712180957.52a5fc6e.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1026524071.10151.9.camel@linux>

There is no compression on the HTTP data stream.

I however will take the other side of the argument (isn't free speech a
great thing...) regarding usage of white space.

The ratio of tabs to TOTAL bytes transmitted is trivial and therefore
not worth the loss of readabily of the HTML compared to the
bytes-transmitted savings.  I don't have hard numbers available but I'm
estimating it's well less than 1% of the total bytes transmitted.   For
dynamically generated HTML (which is now most of the real content out on
the web) I doubt it contains much white space.  I certainly don't put
any in my HTML generation code.  Does anyone else?

Keep in mind that it's not the HTML that causes links to slow down, but
rather the graphics.    Graphics are compressed depending on the format,
but that's another topic.

This would not be hard to measure, we could simply process some web site
logs to get a reasonably accurate ratio of HTLM ascii text to graphics
bytes, them make an estimate as to the average number of tab characters
in a typical HTML page.  But them we'd have to factor out the
dynamically generated content that doesn't generate 'readable' HTML,
then I'd have to really struggle to see why I should worry about the
trivally small amount of residual quantity of bytes that could be saved.

For what it's worth, ... my $.02.


joe

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Jul 15 09:49:53 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 09:49:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Deferred Messages
Message-ID: <3D32FD31.90101@sun.com>

Everyone,

Just a quick reminder.  If you post a message to the list, and it 
doesn't get posted (nearly) immediately, you might check to make sure 
that the address from which you sent the message is subscribed to the 
list.  Remember: the list is now configured to hold non-subscribed posts 
until an administrator gets around to checking them out and either 
approving or rejecting them.

If your message didn't get sent, it's a good possibility that the email 
address in your from: header wasn't on the subscribed list.

If you want to post from multiple addresses, you can do one of two 
things:  Subscribe all of the addresses you want, and select the 'no 
mail' option on your preferences page.  Or email ME with a list of 
addresses you use and I'll add them to an approved posters list.

That's about it for now.  If you have any questions, feel free to ask.

-R

On Sat, 13 Jul 2002, Mike Russell wrote:

> where can i find more info on Postfix mail server, piratically about;
> postfix "Deferred" messages, I am not sure if i understand this. 

  Postfix defers mailling a message if it cannot find the routing right away
or cannot reach the recipient's mail server. As soon as the path is clear it
automatically sends the deferred messages.

  Shortly after I installed postfix here my ISP's dns servers went down for
a while. I _thought_ I was sending messages, but they were stacked in the
queue. As soon as the dns server was once again available all the messages
went out.

Rich





From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jul 15 10:18:35 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 10:18:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] mail server
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020713041733.0236ab80@mail.netsailer.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020715101005.01ae0980@localhost>

At 04:25 AM 7/13/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>where can i find more info on Postfix mail server, piratically about;

Probably on the postfix web site: www.postfix.org

>postfix "Deferred" messages, I am not sure if i understand this. Is it 
>forwarding messages or just sending a responds that it mail is not 
>welcome. I do not want to be a spam house.

Deferred messages are queued messages that haven't been delivered, and have 
encountered an error. I look through the deferred messages occasionally, 
and run a utility that tells me (among other things) where deferred 
messages are bound for. Almost exclusively, they're bounces to spam 
generators about a refused message. I recently removed several users from 
my system. Evidently, they were getting large amounts of spam. Now that 
they aren't on my system anymore, the message bounces. Postfix will attempt 
to deliver the bounce for 5 days (default) and delete it after that.


>here is what concerns me in my cron log.
>
>date            received        delivered       deferred        bounced 
>      rejected
>--------------------------------------------------------------------
>Jul 7 2002      2               4               61
>Jul 8 2002      40              40              36              11
>Jul 9 2002      59              46              55              22
>Jul 10 2002     97              90              120             14
>Jul 11 
>2002     64              50              201             29              1
>Jul 12 2002     120             107             249             27
>Jul 13 2002     11              7               49              9

Looks fairly normal, at least in my experience. I've had up to 450 deferred 
messages in the queue. They go away eventually. Unfortunately, they are 
usually replaced by others, stuck in the queue by stupid spammers.

What I'd like to see is a utility that identified spam (like spamassassin) 
and then sends a "no such user" bounce. Maybe spamassassin does this and I 
just haven't found the relevant instructions.


Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 15 11:59:20 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 11:59:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] To the VI Question
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0207151157390.12434-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I deleted the email so quick that I can't reply, but here how I did it:

:%s/\n/, /
or
:%s/\n/,/

depends on if you want the extra space.

The idea is that %s is the whole file, \n is the end of line.

I hope this helps.
Jason




From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 15 12:09:50 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 12:09:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] To the VI Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0207151157390.12434-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0207151205270.12434-100000@il.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

BTW, in emacs you could use a macro like this:

Posistion the cursor on the first line:
C-x (
C-e ,
C-d
C-x )
C-u num C-x e

Where num is the number of lines-1.

There are better ways I'm sure, but for a nice pedestrian approach it
works for me :)

For those curious, the C-x e runs the last macro and C-x ( and C-x ) mark
the beginning and end of a macro.

Jason

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Jul 15 11:24:56 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 15 Jul 2002 11:24:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 7.3.92 so far...
Message-ID: <1026757496.9548.55.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

Well, I downloaded the latest version of the Redhat beta.

There are some good things and not so good things.

It installs very well on my Vaio with NO additional kernel options. 
This is a good thing. It is one of the only distributions that will do
that correctly.  (I won't comment what it took to get Gentoo on it. 
Lets just say it involved ritual sacrifice and the blood of the living.)

The graphical distribution hosed up.  There is an error in the script
somewhere.  The text option worked fine.  (I use text mode anyways. Much
easier to read on my laptop screen.)  The graphic mode install looks
much better than previous versions.  They are going away from the
horrible icons for packages.

The install went smoothly.  There was no glitches.  Took about an hour.
Mandrake on the same machine would tend to choke on later discs for some
odd reason.  Maybe a French thing...

The distribution defaults to the Gnome 2.0 desktop.  it is not quite as
full featured as the old desktop, but works smoother.  I cannot find how
to change Window managers within Gnome2, however.  It uses Metacity for
its themes, but the theme changer is set for Sawfish.  This is a royal
pain.  (The default theme is OK, but reminds me too much of XP.)  There
are few, if any, themes for Metacity yet.  http://themes.freshmeat.net
does not have any themes for it yet.

Redhat is moving towards multi-language support for the shell as well. 
This causes some off problems. Not all of the language information gets
set up correctly and directory listings can become strange.  (But only
for the "color" directory listings and man pages that have formatted
text.) Going in and setting the country codes and locales seems to fix
it.

KDE uses 3.0.2 from cvs.  Works pretty well. My only complaint is that
the menues do not contain any of the Gnome entries or the switchdesk
app.  (KDE seems to think that once you use KDE, you will not want to
leave. It is a little too controlling for my tastes.)  The KDE themes
are pretty sparse.  There are lots of KDE apps however.  (You will want
to run KDE once to get the environment configured if you use Gnome.
Otherwise KDE apps tend to core.)  "switchdesk" will allow you to switch
back.

The kernel is INCREDIBLY full featured.  The low latency patches are
installed.  There are patches for crypto hardware, foreign binaries
(like BSD and COFF format), and a whole lot of other stuff.  My prism2
wireless card did not work out of the box.  (Not a big concern for me as
I needed to install hacked drivers for it anyways.) The kernel souce is
already preconfigured in a way that it will not overlay the default
kernel. (The kernel is 2.4.18-5.58. Any kernel you compile identifies as
2.4.18-5.58custom.)  My only complaint is that they are not including
the FreeSWAN and Crypto patches.  I will be testing if they will patch
cleanly soon.  The kernel does work with the current wireless-ng
drivers.  (Compiled from source.)

The compiler is GCC 3.1.  So far, it has worked very well. No problems
yet...

The system uses Grub for a boot loaded.  If you use the text install it
will give you an option for "lilo". DO NOT TAKE IT!  Your system will
try and boot using Grub no matter what.  It will fail at this point.  I
prefer lilo.  Grub's method of configuration is a little too weird for
me.  Maybe it is what I am used to...

This version uses Apache 2.0.x, instead of 1.3.  I have done next to
nothing with the 2.x code on Apache.  (Due to waiting for it to get
stable and a general mistrust of multi-threading services.)  I guess it
is time to learn it.

All in all, this is a VERY promising release. It has some rough edges. 
(To be expected with a beta 1.)  If they can clean up those and fix a
few of the more unusual problems, it could be a very worthwhile release.
I am pretty happy with it so far.





From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Jul 15 13:34:16 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 13:34:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] To the VI Question

Did you get the slash before the n? "\n" is the newline character.

:%s/\n/,/ 
	#correct

worked for me on the list you gave. Whereas:

:%s/n/,/ 
	#incorrect

> Jason

I'm suprised the "%" doesn't work in vi on your HP box - they must be
using a very very old version.

You could try the control-v trick:

:1,$s/ctrl-v<enter>/,/

The control-v is a quote mechanism in (some versions of) vi, as in
insert the next character in this search string rather than process it
immediately. In the above example, type control-v then hit your enter
key, so don't type out the brackets or anything like that.

--Stafford

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Jul 15 13:12:38 2002

Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 13:12:38 -0700

* Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> [020715 12:54]:
> Here's how I generated the list:

I'm guessing that your original text file doesn't terminate with lines
with newline, but rather (DOS-style) carriage return+linefeeds.

Here's a text file created with notepad on a Winders machine:

srau at slobyj:~$ cat dostext.txt 
nothing
space 
tab     
srau at slobyj:~$ od -c dostext.txt
0000000   n   o   t   h   i   n   g  \r  \n   s   p   a   c   e      \r
0000020  \n   t   a   b  \t  \r  \n
0000027
srau at slobyj:~$ 

The octal dump (od -c) command is useful for showing the non-printing
characters, and show that the lines are terminated with \r \n rather
than the most more sane \n.

--Stafford

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Jul 15 13:33:30 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 15 Jul 2002 13:33:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] To the VI Question
In-Reply-To: <20020715201238.GE32625@rauhaus.org>
References: <3D3331C8.3020307@parkrose.k12.or.us>
	<Pine.GSO.4.33.0207151258240.17532-100000@lukem.com> 
	<20020715201238.GE32625@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <1026765211.11499.137.camel@pookie>


> I'm guessing that your original text file doesn't terminate with lines
> with newline, but rather (DOS-style) carriage return+linefeeds.

[snip]

If this is the case you will see a `^M' after every line when viewing
the file on the Unix box. Here's how to get rid of them in one swoop in
vi (read sentence after this command for details):

  :1,$ s/^M//

There's a trick to entering this. the ':1,$ s/' part is entered normaly.
When you get to the ^M part, instead of entering it as it looks, execute
a Ctrl-v-m. That is, hold down the control key and hit the `v' and `m'
keys consecutively.

The `Ctrl-v' part says, ``Get ready... I'm about to send you a Control
character.'' The `m' key, then, is said character. Do not release the
Ctrl key during this sequence.

The rest of the command (//) is typed normally.



--

From rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com  Mon Jul 15 14:18:08 2002
From: rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 14:18:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] how to create a comma-delimited list?
Message-ID: <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF611052CBFE7@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>

> From: Matt Alexander [mailto:m at netpro.to]
> 
> I have a list of items like this:
> 
> bob
> sam
> joe
> mark
> sally
> marge
> 
> And I'd like to convert it to this:
> 
> bob,sam,joe,mark,sally,marge
> 
> Is there a way to do this within vi?

Assuming that the list is not the only thing in your file and you eyeball
the number of lines involved you can:

(with cursor on the line with bob)
5Js/ /, /g

or if you'd rather not guess:

:set nu
[ see what the line number is for first and last list item]
:1,5j #substitute real line numbers
:s/ /, /g

^^ Though it breaks on items with embedded spaces so perhaps you'd rather:
:1,5s/$/,/
:1,5j

  
There's a couple of vi-isms to do what you want.

I expect Heinlein will weigh in with a more powerful method.

boot from the floppys I had created and however long it took to restore
from tape and the system was back up.

Bru claims to have a similar system but I've never tested it.

From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon Jul 15 17:22:22 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 17:22:22 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Whack-a-mole Install? (Y/N)
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020712091046.01a92520@localhost>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20020712091046.01a92520@localhost>
Message-ID: <20020716001143.DEF613449C@ados.com>

Reply regarding Re: [PLUG] .AVI RPM player Advice from Russ Johnson:
: At 08:02 PM 7/11/2002 -0700, you wrote:
: >4. Press "OK" until all the dialog boxes go away. (Note: You do not have
: > to actually *read* any of the dialog boxes. Think of playing
: > 'Whack-a-mole,' but with your mouse pointer - the faster you hit those
: > "OKs," the sooner you get to watch your AVI's. The fewer that appear, the
: > better the program is.)

:
: Having been a technical support engineer for a large software firm, I
: cringe when I read something like this.
:
: Expect software to work like a Kleenex (pull it out of the box and it's
: ready to use) 
:
: If someone clicks 'OK' as fast as they can, and then it doesn't work as
: they expect, well, I have no sympathy for them.

Note that I didn't include the Whack-a-mole install method in the 'serious' 
section of the letter. What I -was- pointing out, though is that this is the 
way most users think, and it's the sort of user behavior that can get 
conditioned in - I actually first heard it described in a report of a power 
plant accident - operators had gotten used to cancelling alarm klaxons 
without checking 'what did I just turn off' - and in one particular plant 
this had actually become somewhat of an autonomic reflex.

In the investigation following the accident ( a steam line rupture to a power 
turbine - I hate when that happens, but you can make off with plenty of squab 
if you can get to the roof quick enough - bring salt and pepper.) several 
operators had been asked 'what alarm did you just cancel?' after being 
observed, and they were unable to answer. At least one such operator denied, 
or was unaware of cancelling the alarm.

The data record showed that one particular alarm on the turbine that failed 
had been cancelled TWENTY-SIX times in a row, within less than an hour. "In 
effect," the report read, "the machine said 'OK Fine, I give up trying to 
warn you. You win. I die now.' "

A similar sort of double-return hit can get conditioned into user behavior if 
a common task (delete, erase) is ALWAYS followed by 'Are you SURE? (Y/N)'

In any case, thanks for the 'real' suggestions, - I'll see how it goes.

GLL

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Mon Jul 15 11:54:58 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 11:54:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Need Audio Record: $20
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA223@exchange.ci.albany.or.us>

First, (if you haven't already) check all of the mixer settings.  (With
whatever... gmix, kmix, or whatever you have.)  Make sure the right device
is selected for recording input, and that the levels are up.  (If you have
studio setup, the VU meter lights should show levels... but only while
attempting to record.  If you get no lights, you're probably not getting a
signal.)

Also make sure that the channels aren't muted.  (If using ALSA drivers, I
know they all are muted by default.)

The more I think about it, the more I think the mixer settings are what need
checking, especially considering studio isn't getting anything.


But, in case you've already done all of that (and it isn't the problem),
here's a couple links to gramofile.  (I use it for initial recording anyway,
even if studio is working.)

Homepage
http://panic.et.tudelft.nl/~costar/gramofile/
Freshmeat listing
http://freshmeat.net/projects/gramofile/?topic_id=115
RPM's someone built.  (On SuSE, but doesnt' think there would be any
compatability issues.)
http://nebuchadnezzar.zion.cz/gramofile.php


And there is always plain old sox.  At least to eliminate the possibility of
program problems, till you are sure the card/input channel/mixer settings
are good.

Jeremy

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Jul 15 18:45:07 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 18:45:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] To the VI Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207151624110.25158-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207151831490.1770-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 15 Jul 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> OK, here's the contents of a text file after the od -c is run on it:
>
> 0000000   b   o   b  \n   s   a   m  \n   j   o   e  \n   m   a   r   k
> 0000020  \n   s   a   l   l   y  \n   m   a   r   g   e  \n
> 0000035
>
> So there are clearly newline characters.  But...  the :%s/\n/,/ doesn't
> work.  SoooooOOOOooOOoOOoooo...  Any guesses why?  This is a default

I can give a good guess, though I'm really rusty in vi, so I can't say if
this is the case for vi.  Many editors (particularly older ones), are very
line oriented and don't actually even keep the newline in their memory
buffers (so it can't actually match on a newline character because it
isn't there).  Some of these editors do not allow for the concept of a
pattern that spans multiple lines (which any thing with a newline in it
would be), and for many of those that do, they use a special character in
regular expressions such as "$" to represent the concept of "end of line"
or newline.  In all of these editors that I can recall using, doing what
you want was possible, but for at least some of them it might require a
multiple stage process (or creation of a macro), so that you would first
do a search/insert to add your comma to the end of each line, then
perform some kind of "join" to add the next line to the current line.

FWIW.

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Mon Jul 15 22:19:33 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 2002 22:19:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 7.3.92 so far...
In-Reply-To: <1026788458.10786.9.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207152203010.977-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 15 Jul 2002, Alan wrote:

>> Try fiddling around with GRUB for a while. I won't use LILO anymore,
>> GRUB is much harder to screw up - and if you do screw it up you can 
>> drop down to a command prompt giving you a chance to fix the problem
>> and get the machine back up and running.
>
>I need to find a good overview of how GRUB is supposed to work.  The
>commands are a bit alien to me.

Here's 99% of what you need to know about grub under "usual" conditions:

 * The config file is /boot/grub/grub.conf (symlinked to /etc/grub.conf),
   you should be able to get the syntax down in about 15 seconds. The
   "default=?" line is the default kernel, as listed counting from zero.
   (i.e. the first kernel listed is "0", the second is "1", and so on)

 * you don't need to run a command after editing the grub.conf file, GRUB
   reads it when the system boots

 * to modify the boot parameters (say like the old "LILO: linux single"),
   use the arrow keys to select the kernel you want, hit "e" to edit the
   config, select the portion you want to edit (usually the second line which
   contains the kernel paramaters), hit "e" to edit it, hit return when you're
   done, then hit "b" to continue booting. It's fairly obvious once you've
   done it once or twice.

 * I don't want to reboot right now, am too lazy to RTFM, and can't remember
   off the top of my head how to drop down to the "boot monitor" prompt.
   I believe it's listed right on the initial bootup screen. There is a 
   help facility that explains the basics of each command. The big "gotcha"
   for me was that if /boot is a seperate partition, grub acts as if it
   chrooted to there (i.e. "/boot/vmlinuz" is "/vmlinuz" to grub).


-Eric

Billy,

You should be logging into a user account to send mail. It's not necessary
to cd to /var/mail or login to the mail server to send mail. And you should
certainly not be sending mail as root under normal circumstances. As Jon
correctly pointed out, there are a number of mail user agents you may use to
read, send, forward and bounce mail (although he left out my favorite -
mutt).

If Jon and I have failed to understand your question, please feel free to
set us straight.

cheers,
Sandy

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jul 15 23:32:18 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 15 Jul 2002 23:32:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 7.3.92 so far...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207152203010.977-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207152203010.977-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <86vg7gtc7h.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Eric" == Eric Harrison <eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us> writes:

Eric> Try fiddling around with GRUB for a while. I won't use LILO
Eric> anymore, GRUB is much harder to screw up - and if you do screw
Eric> it up you can drop down to a command prompt giving you a chance
Eric> to fix the problem and get the machine back up and running.

Alan> I need to find a good overview of how GRUB is supposed to work.
Alan> The commands are a bit alien to me.

Eric> Here's 99% of what you need to know about grub under "usual"
Eric> conditions:

Eric>  * The config file is /boot/grub/grub.conf (symlinked to
Eric> /etc/grub.conf), you should be able to get the syntax down in
Eric> about 15 seconds. The "default=?" line is the default kernel, as
Eric> listed counting from zero.  (i.e. the first kernel listed is
Eric> "0", the second is "1", and so on)

On Debian, I think this file is typically located in
/boot/grub/menu.lst.  One of mine looks like this:

   default saved
   timeout 5
   serial --unit=1 --speed=9600
   terminal --timeout=5 serial console

   title   Linux 2.4.18
   root    (hd0,0)
   kernel  /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.18 root=/dev/hda1 console=ttyS1,9600
   savedefault

   title   Linux 2.4.16
   root    (hd0,0)
   kernel  /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.16 root=/dev/hda1 console=ttyS1,9600
   savedefault

The savedefault stuff is to remember what you booted the last time and
make it the default.

You can install GRUB to a boot floppy while you are getting used to
it.  Then "grub-install" to the hard disk when you are more
comfortable.

See the GRUB manual for details:

  <http://www.gnu.org/manual/grub/index.html>

Eric>  * you don't need to run a command after editing the grub.conf
Eric> file, GRUB reads it when the system boots

Right.  As I understand it, LILO sort of "cooks" a boot environment
for you, a static sort of thing.  GRUB, on the other hand, is more
dynamic.  It groks file systems, reads text configuration files or
interactively-provided configurations during the boot phase.  While
booting, you can use GRUB to search for kernels, do tab-completion,
etc.  Just way more flexible than LILO.

Eric>  * I don't want to reboot right now, am too lazy to RTFM, and
Eric> can't remember off the top of my head how to drop down to the
Eric> "boot monitor" prompt.  I believe it's listed right on the
Eric> initial bootup screen. There is a help facility that explains
Eric> the basics of each command. The big "gotcha" for me was that if
Eric> /boot is a seperate partition, grub acts as if it chrooted to
Eric> there (i.e. "/boot/vmlinuz" is "/vmlinuz" to grub).

Ah yeah.  While GRUB groks file systems, it doesn't grok /etc/fstab
AFAIK, so your filenames are relative to the filesystem root.  GRUB
doesn't know that your boot partition is going to be mounted under
/boot, so you give it a root device descriptor (hd0,0) or whatever,
and the kernel path is relative to the root of that filesystem.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Jul 15 17:43:41 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 15 Jul 2002 17:43:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Advanced Topic Talk Wed July 17th
Message-ID: <1026780221.3574.518.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

Linux Advanced Topic Talk Wed July 17th

[Hey look I updated the date this time!]

Speaker Phil Tomson 

>From Phil's Note:

I've created an open source, object oriented, task distribution
framework I call TaskMaster.  TaskMaster allows users to easily create
their own runnable Task objects that can be distributed to multiple
machines on a network (which are running a slave program).  Tasks are
sent out by a designated 'master' machine to available slaves. When a
slave receives a Task object it runs it.  When a slave completes its
assigned task the master then 'harvests' the resulting data from it. 
Potential applications:
* Testcase distribution (that's what I was using it for): testsuites for
some software packages can contain thousands of testcases, distributing
them across multiple slave machines can result in getting test results
faster.
* Distributed software builds: sort of a distributed 'make' where a
large piece of software (the Linux kernel for example) that has lots of
hierarchy can be built in pieces across several machines more quickly
than on one machine.
* Distributed computation: I have an example where I use several
machines to calculate the value of Pi using the Monte-Carlo method - the
more machines that are added, the faster the computation should go
(given fairly equal performance of slaves).


--------------------------

                   <www.BeautifulPizza.com>

I prefer BRU to Amanda,  but Amanda works.
It has a minor potential drawback in that it requires a swap space of it's
own, or spooler if you will, that is either as big as the largest file you
have to back up or all the data you're backing up,  I forget which.
When you exceed this free space you don't get a complete backup,  naturally,
and  an email telling you to change the size of the spool filespace up a few
more gigs...actually ou get email confirmation every night whether it worked
as planned or not.
Otherwise no complaints.

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Tue Jul 16 09:45:13 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 09:45:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions
In-Reply-To: <1026834782.13168.3.camel@pookie>
References: <1026834782.13168.3.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <20020716094513.18711a51.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>

I've used two linux-based firewall "distributions" in the past. Neither was perfect, but each had its good points.

Mandrake SNF (Single Network Firewall)
Based on the older 7.2 release, it had a decent web-management interface.  Ability to backup firewall
rules, make changes to the running system and perform online package and system updates via the web.
Downsides were that documentation on the system is poor.  Among other things, the interfaces are hard-coded 
but nothing mentions this.  eth1 MUST be your internet conn., and eth0 is the local private if. It will 
mysteriously not work if it's not configured this way.

Smoothwall 0.9.9 (uh oh)
This system works pretty nicely.  The web interface is much more capable than the Mandrake one.  It has
a squid caching proxy, Free S/WAN, snort, good logging (although no built-in alerting/emailing). You can
also add rules to the fw through the web if, never used it though. Oh, it also has the ability to access
the OpenSSH server from the management page, and even gives color shell access, just like you're there! ;)
Unfortunately, the dns proxy has been dying on it lately and it's been hanging at the console (probably
a hardware issue).  This was the "trial" GNU version.  Smoothwall has a commercial product which is 
possibly more full featured and stable.

Hope that is useful, 
Cheers,

/eli

On Wed, 17 Jul 2002 00:12:06 +0800
"Stephen Liu" <satimis at writeme.com> wrote:

> How to install following tarball
> 
> xxx.tar.tar

.tar.tar, 'eh?

Strange.

tar -xvf xxx.tar.tar

then see what you have and act accordingly.  A tar file?  tar -xvf
xxx.tar.  A directory?  cd xxx && ls ...stuff like that.

If you're in KDE, you can just click on the archive in Konqueror and go
from there, too.

If there's a program in there you want to install... well... that really
depends on what the program is.  Inside the archive there should be
instructions.  Often (aptly) named INSTALL or README or README.install 
:-)

Good luck.

Rob

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jul 16 11:22:00 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 11:22:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: about sending mail.......
In-Reply-To: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAEENCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>; from bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph on Tue, Jul 16, 2002 at 01:57:51PM +0800
References: <LKELJJFGLNIKHFIAPIJGAEENCBAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20020716112200.A12869@kippered.herring.org>

Billy,

Let's keep this on the PLUG list so that others (more knowledgeable than I)
can add their two cents. I've set the Reply-To: header on this email to the
list (plug at lists.pdxlinux.org).

Sending and receiving mail is generally done by using a program designed for
that purpose rather than directly invoking the system utilities (like
sendmail) used as a foundation for a friendly user interface.

Your choices of MUAs (mail user agents) is going to be a function of who
administers the server. If it's you, then you can install whichever program
you like. Otherwise, you're at the mercy of the sysadmin. It's probable that
you have pine and elm. Good resources for learning about their use (a topic
far too extensive to tackle in this email) can be found at these web sites:

   Linkname: Pine Information Center
        URL: http://www.washington.edu/pine/ 

   Linkname: ii.com: All About PINE: IMAP, NNTP, & ESMPT for Unix, MS Windows,
             and Mac OS X by Nancy McGough
        URL: http://www.ii.com/internet/messaging/pine/

   Linkname: ELM - Electronic Mail for UNIX                               
        URL: http://www.instinct.org/elm/

You can also type in `man pine' and `man elm' at the UNIX shell prompt to
read the online manual pages.

You'll need to learn to use a UNIX editor in order to compose mail. Most
beginners start with pico, joe or vi. You can find information on these by
using the `man' command (e.g., `man pico', etc.), and also at the following
web sites:

   Linkname: Pico Tutorial                                                
        URL: http://www.usd.edu/trio/tut/pico/index.html

   Linkname: Using the Unix Text Editor Pico                              
        URL: http://www.itd.umich.edu/itdoc/r/r1168/

   Linkname: The Joe Editor
        URL: http://www.rochester.edu/ats/Documentation/joeeditor.html

   Linkname: Introduction to the Joe Text Editor 
        URL: http://heather.cs.ucdavis.edu/~matloff/Joe/NotesJoe.NM.html

   Linkname: An Introduction to Display Editing with Vi
        URL: http://docs.FreeBSD.org/44doc/usd/12.vi/paper.html

   Linkname: VI LOVERS HOME PAGE                                          
        URL: http://www.thomer.com/vi/vi.html

   Linkname: Vim FAQ#1                                                    
        URL: http://www.geocities.com/yegappan/vim_faq.txt

   Linkname: Vim FAQ#2                                                    
        URL: http://www.soyabean.com.au/gavin/vim/vim-FAQ-0.2.txt

Try them out and pick the one(s) you like. As you explore them, feel free to
post more questions to the list.

An excellent way to learn pine is to type 'pine' at the command prompt and 
check it out. The menus are fairly intuitive.

$ pine

> You'll need to learn to use a UNIX editor in order to compose mail. Most
> beginners start with pico, joe or vi. You can find information on these by
> using the `man' command (e.g., `man pico', etc.), and also at the following
> web sites:


Pine uses pico by default and it is completely intuitive. Up arrows to 
move your curser up, down arrow to move your curser down, etc. Backspace 
to backspace over a typo. And at the bottom of the screen are commands 
that are available such as ^X (ctrl-X) to send your email.

I urge you to just try it by sending a series of emails to yourself and 
responding, etc. You will learn most of what you need to know about pine 
in 10 minutes!

Neil Anuskiewicz

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jul 16 11:45:33 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 11:45:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: about sending mail.......
In-Reply-To: <20020716112200.A12869@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207161127300.30344-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:

> Sending and receiving mail is generally done by using a program designed for
> that purpose rather than directly invoking the system utilities (like
> sendmail) used as a foundation for a friendly user interface.

  This would make a very good topic for a HOWTO or, at least, a newbie
tutorial on the PLUG web site. Mail is a confusing topic for the newcomer
because there are 3-4 components (one of each must be present) and multiple
choices among each component. I'll start this HOWTO with a brief summary.

  Linux (and other unix-like systems) mail requires separate steps,
depending on whether the mail is coming in or going out. Let's start with
sending mail.

  The interface between you and the world of Internet mail (e-mail) is
called the Mail User Agent (MUA). The command line offerings include (but
are not limited to) pine, mutt, elm and mail. The GUI offerings include (but
are not limited to) sylpheed, netscape, mozilla, kmail and ... (I can't
think of more right now). The functions of the MUA are to allow you to read,
organize, store and compose mail messages. Most of 'em (many, anyhow) store
mail in /var/spool/mail/<your_username>; others store mail in ~/mail/.
Anyway, the MUA is what most users see as their e-mail "system". But, it's
only one part.

  When you compose a message in your MUA and want to send it out, the MUA
hands the message to the locally-installed Mail Transfer Agent (MTA),
unless, that's built into the MUA. Most linux installations include
'sendmail' as the MTA. Others available include postfix, elim, qmail and
smail. The function of the MTA is to determine (by looking at the message
header created by the MUA) whether the recipient is local or outside your
network (or single machine). In the latter case, it checks where to send it
(details skipped here) and ships it off. So, sending mail is the simpler of
the two processes.

  Incoming mail requires one or two additional components. If you do not run
your own mail server (whose address is publicly visible on the Internet),
especially if you dial into your ISP to collect mail waiting for you on
their server(s), you need a component that will fetch the mail for you. The
most common tool is called (quite logically), "fetchmail". Fetchmail will
use either of several mail protocols, the two most common (popular?) are the
Post Office Protocol, version 3 (POP3) and Internet Message Access Protocol
(IMAP). You can run fetchmail manually, from a cron job or as a background
daemon.

  Mail retrieved by fetchmail is transferred to your MTA for forwarding,
either externally or internally. If the message is intended for a local
recipient, the MTA passes the message to the Mail Delivery Agent (MDA);
procmail is the only one that occurs to me now. The MDA places the message
in the recipient's inbox or other message file based on recipes that control
how it processes incoming messages. This makes it useful as a spam filter,
too.

  In a nutshell (no trademark violation intended), that's linux mail. While
it's overwhelmingly confusing at first, when you understand the components
and how they work together then it all makes sense and is quite clear. In
concept if not in practice. :-)

HTH,

Rich

From alan at clueserver.org  Tue Jul 16 11:33:03 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 16 Jul 2002 11:33:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Changing Window Managers in Gnome 2.x - Solution
Message-ID: <1026844384.12932.4.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

I found this after a little bit of digging.  i figured it was something
weird and obvious.

The script that sets the window manager is /usr/bin/gnome-wm.

If the environment variable "WINDOW_MANAGER" is not set, it looks
through the list and runs the first one it finds.  Check the script for
valid options.  (I do not have Gnome 2 on this machine yet.)  The ones I
remember are "metacity", "sawfish", and "sawmill".  There are a number
of others on the list.

It would be nice if it were a little easier for the average user to
find. Glad I am not the average user...

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Ken Nowack wrote:

> > I can reset the system time, but give it about an hour and it resets
> > itself for no apparent reason, about 12 hours off. I've tried using
> > rdate -s every 15 minutes, doesn't help. I've tried setting up ntpd and
> > using it, but once the system time gets too far off, ntpd dies with no
> > explanation.

Ken,

  Linux has two clocks. 'rdate' sets the system clock and it's valid only as
long as you're logged in. 'hwclock' sets the hardware clock, and this is the
one you want to set correctly. Once you do, you can tell the sysclock to
sync against the hardware clock. I don't recall off-hand just where it goes,
but it's one of the startup scripts.

Rich

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jul 16 13:44:08 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 13:44:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] tabs in sed
In-Reply-To: <20020716200352.GA23624@boora.com>; from montagne@boora.com on Tue, Jul 16, 2002 at 01:03:52PM -0700
References: <20020716200352.GA23624@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20020716134408.E12869@kippered.herring.org>

Michael,

Most versions of sed don't parse `\t' to mean <tab>. To enter an actual tab
character, you need to escape it with ^v (Ctrl-v). e.g.

sed 's/[<Tab>]//g' foo.txt > bar.txt

...where <Tab> signifies ^v followed by a keyboard tab.

Sandy

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Michael Montagne wrote: 
> I'm trying to get rid if multiple tabs using sed.  How do I specify a
> TAB character at the command line? \t doesn't work and pressing the TAB
> key doesn't work either.

> thanks.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Jul 16 14:45:43 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 14:45:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
Message-ID: <3D349407.8010700@sun.com>

I took a Solaris sysadmin class last week - it was quite fun, we got to
play with Ultra 10's, setup networking, NIS servers, installation,
partitioning, etc etc etc.

Probably one of the best things I learned was how to partition a disk.
Not that I didn't know *how* before, but now I know *why*.

Layout (explanation to follow):

p1: /			50-80 mb
p2: swap		2x ram size
p3: /var		200 mb+, depending on server type	
p4: /usr		30-40% of the rest of the disk
p5: /home		the rest of the disk

Here's why:  The spindle spins faster around the outside, and partitions 
are created from the outside -> inside.  You put the things that get 
accessed the most on the fastest portion of the drive - IE /bin, /sbin, 
/tmp, /lib, etc.  Those things usually don't take up a whole hell of a 
lot of space anyway, so the partition can be small.  Next, put the swap 
partition, again because it's faster out there near the outside of the 
drive.  Plus - if your most-accessed things are *right next to it* on 
the physical disk, the heads won't thrash as much.  Next come /var (for 
/var/log - class taught /var/adm, but that's Solaris, not Linux), /usr, 
and /home.

Depending on what your system role will be, you'll have to decide how 
big to make these.  If it's a print server, /var/spool/lp is going to 
fill up right quick at only 200m.  Mail server, same deal.  Install a 
lot of desktop apps?  Make /var bigger.  Mount /home via NFS?  Do away 
with /home.  Like/want/need a /boot partition?  Have at you.

My point is that for better performance, putting a small root and swap 
partiton right next to each other, then divvying up the rest of them for 
the disk is even better than playing with hdparm.

If I had known this beforehand, I would have definitely done my system 
partitioning differently.  I might run some benchmarks before and after 
I redo it on my desktop, just for grins.

Cheers,

-Richard

-- 
s u n  m i c r o s y s t e m s

    ~ Richard Langis Jr. ~
    richard.langis at sun.com

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Tue Jul 16 15:03:58 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:03:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] how to host a dns server on a dhcp ip... ?
References: <004e01c22d11$b136fca0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <001401c22d14$b00af860$4a1ce00c@shrike>

You'll need to register with your dyndns provider to have them serve as
your DNS provider for the domain names you wish to serve from your
system.  I'm not sure about your provider, but dyndns.org does this.
You'll not be using register.com to provide DNS anymore.
They also have links to good tech information on the details.

As far as setting up servers 2 and 3, you do the same thing.  You'll need
to register each name with the dyndns service.  I'm not sure, but you may
need to run a client for each domain name it's providing DNS for, so that
the DNS entries are upated each time you get a new IP via DHCP.

Hopefully this helps you some.  If I haven't understood your question,
lemme know and I'll reconsider :)

Cheers,

/eli

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Tue Jul 16 15:22:20 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:22:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
In-Reply-To: <3D349407.8010700@sun.com>
References: <3D349407.8010700@sun.com>
Message-ID: <20020716152220.65726888.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002 14:45:43 -0700
"Richard Langis Jr." <richard.langis at sun.com> wrote:

> p1: /           50-80 mb
> p2: swap        2x ram size
> p3: /var        200 mb+, depending on server type   
> p4: /usr        30-40% of the rest of the disk
> p5: /home       the rest of the disk

I always put the swap at the end of the drive.  In today's high-capacity
drive days, the swap is almost always very small in proportion to the
rest of the drive.  Having the swap always be 2x the RAM size is also
something I don't do myself.  Depending on the use of the system and
amount of RAM, a gig of swap is usually quite excessive.  The faster
your swap is, the better, IMHO.

JMO...

Rob

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Jul 16 15:37:48 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:37:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
References: <3D349407.8010700@sun.com> <20020716152220.65726888.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>
Message-ID: <3D34A03C.6080204@sun.com>

End of the drive meaning closest to the spindle?

I agree with the amount of swap - I can't see making a 1.5gig swap 
partition for my primary desktop.  However, our instructor said that 
Oracle's *only* supported configuration calls for at *LEAST* mem*8=swap. 
  Our class thought this was quite funny, as the product that most of 
the people in there work on is a system capable of having over 500 gigs 
of RAM.  To which the instructor quipped, "And that's why you're getting 
into the terrabyte drive array market, is it not?"

Of course, my aforementioned desktop system hasn't even touched its swap 
partition.  On my server systems, which are 200MHz Pentiums, or my 'new' 
web surfing appliance (150MHz Laptop), partitioning things in this 
manner would make a big difference in the amount of thrashing.

Your mileage will vary.

-R

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Tue Jul 16 15:46:26 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:46:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] how to host a dns server on a dhcp ip... ?
References: <004e01c22d11$b136fca0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com> <001401c22d14$b00af860$4a1ce00c@shrike> <005f01c22d17$88bf6ea0$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <001101c22d1a$9e446fc0$4a1ce00c@shrike>

Ok sorry, I did misunderstand :) Not the first time.

Actually, I don't think you can do what you want.  You're looking to use
your dyndns served/DHCP client system ,matchboy.dynu.com, as a DNS
server for the other two domain names you have.

Unfortunately for you, an authoratative DNS server _must_ have a static IP.
That's how the system is arranged, out of necessity.  Your system which
receives its IP address via DHCP from your isp, and its DNS listing from
dynu.com just can't be listed in register.com via its IP address as it
changes,
and you can't do it by DNS name (matchboy.dynu.com).

Good luck with a resolution.

Cheers,

/eli

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:39:26 -0700 (PDT)
"Dean S. Messing" <deanm at sharplabs.com> wrote:

> I believe that the data is going by the head a lot faster at _the
> beginning_ of the drive than at the end.  So, if you want speed, I
> would think you'd define your swap partition starting at cylinder 0.
> But maybe I've missed something here about your disk geometry.

Well, I guess I could have had it all backwards... but I thought the
begining of the drive was the inside and the end of the drive was the
outside?

The outside of the drive spins a lot faster than the inside of the
drive.  Their angular velocity is the same, but the radii vary greatly. 

Sorry if I had that backwards!

Rob



From cbrown at woods.net  Tue Jul 16 15:49:12 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 16:49:12 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: Weird system time issue
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207161242130.30775-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207161638500.28946-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Ken Nowack wrote:
>
> > > I can reset the system time, but give it about an hour and it resets
> > > itself for no apparent reason, about 12 hours off. I've tried using
> > > rdate -s every 15 minutes, doesn't help. I've tried setting up ntpd and
> > > using it, but once the system time gets too far off, ntpd dies with no
> > > explanation.
>
> Ken,
>
>   Linux has two clocks. 'rdate' sets the system clock and it's valid only as
> long as you're logged in. 'hwclock' sets the hardware clock, and this is the
> one you want to set correctly. Once you do, you can tell the sysclock to
> sync against the hardware clock. I don't recall off-hand just where it goes,
> but it's one of the startup scripts.


No, Linux has one clock, the system clock.  In normal cases the
platform has a hardware clock (PCs, most workstations), though odd
systems and some embeded hardware lack an RTC.


date rdate, ntpdate, whatever all access/set the system clock.
hwclock (for most platforms) sets system time from hardware or sets
hardware time from system time.  The older 'clock' app did this as
well, but has been retired. (hwclock uses a new and safer access
method than clock for get/set from hardware RTC)


System time is is set from the RTC using hwclock in one of the init
scripts for most systems.  It has nothing to do with any login
session.  It persists until reboot.


Given time, the system time will drift vs RTC time, and both will
drift from real time.  This is why running an ntp client is a good
thing, it keeps the system clock synced.  During system shutdown (for
most distros) system time is written back to the RTC within the init
scripts.  This ensures that as of next boot the RTC is "close enough"
to real time that the initial system clock is near enough to synced
(within 70 seconds for many ntp systems) that the ntp client can drift
the system clock into sync, rather than jumping it. (jumping the clock
must be done manually from the command line and with the client daemon
shutdown)

-- 
I route, therefore you are.




From cbrown at woods.net  Tue Jul 16 15:51:43 2002
From: cbrown at woods.net (Christopher E. Brown)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 16:51:43 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
In-Reply-To: <20020716160335.1bbf47a5.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207161649380.28946-100000@spruce.woods.net>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> On Tue, 16 Jul 2002 15:39:26 -0700 (PDT)
> "Dean S. Messing" <deanm at sharplabs.com> wrote:
>
> > I believe that the data is going by the head a lot faster at _the
> > beginning_ of the drive than at the end.  So, if you want speed, I
> > would think you'd define your swap partition starting at cylinder 0.
> > But maybe I've missed something here about your disk geometry.
>
> Well, I guess I could have had it all backwards... but I thought the
> begining of the drive was the inside and the end of the drive was the
> outside?
>
> The outside of the drive spins a lot faster than the inside of the
> drive.  Their angular velocity is the same, but the radii vary greatly.
>
> Sorry if I had that backwards!
>
> Rob




Yes, convention with current HD tech is tracks start at the outside of
the platter.  Peak transfer rates start with track 0, and decrease
from their.


This is why putting your swap partition first is not such a bad idea,
and putting your bulk storage last.

From flee at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 16 16:24:24 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 16:24:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
In-Reply-To: <20020716160335.1bbf47a5.AthlonRobNF@CS.com> on Tue, 16 Jul 2002 16:03:35 PDT.
Message-ID: <200207162324.g6GNOPX06400@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

I think, position of partitions on a disk is generally
pointless micro-optimization.  My instinct is if there is a
difference, it's not a big enough difference to matter for
average use.  Benchmark it and make sure.  This type of
thing needs to be benchmarked; it's quite hard to predict
the right answer, especially now that disks are very smart
devices.

My partitioning strategy these days is aimed at robustness
and low maintenance and backup-friendliness.  One partition
for /, one for swap, one for /home.

The biggest delay is probably track-to-track seek time,
which is constant for any distance, so it shouldn't matter
where on the disk you put the partitions.  But again, run
benchmarks if you care.
--
[ sometimes otters are weasel-flavored ]

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jul 16 16:39:09 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 16:39:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
Message-ID: <279247252.1026862732685.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Felix Lee flee at aracnet.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> I think, position of partitions on a disk is generally pointless
> micro-optimization.  My instinct is if there is a difference, it's not
> a big enough difference to matter for average use.  Benchmark it and
> make sure.  This type of thing needs to be benchmarked; it's quite
> hard to predict the right answer, especially now that disks are very
> smart devices.

I'll definately agree with this.  However, I understand that some folks
have lots of free time and want to play around.  ;-)

Some drives' (and SCSI cards') translation from SCSI blocks to disk blocks
do not necessarily follow the start-at-the-outside-and-work-your-way-in
convention.  This is especially true if using CHS addressing rather than
LBA.

Benchmark to be sure, but if performance is that critical, then there are
lots of better things to do.  (Caching, striping, etc.)

Be careful of developing some bizarre, hard to maintain disk layout in the
name of performance.

  -- Steve

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Tue Jul 16 14:22:12 2002
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (Cooper Stevenson)

Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207161352310.7720-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Roderick;

On Tue, 2002-07-16 at 13:58, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

[snip]

>    I am pretty happy with my Asante FriendlyNet firewall.

[snip]

Funny you should mention the Asante. I have had great luck with the
Asante router/firewall. However, this came up just a week or two ago:

 http://www.pcworld.com/news/article/0,aid,102596,00.asp


It's an ActiveX exploit. It passes through as HTML 4 on port 80.
Unfortunately, the router won't see it. I checked for a firmware update
but even the latest version does not combat against this.

Yes, this was a ``head's up'' for me too.

What we have to do is find a firewall that is capable of Content
filtering. In other words, a firewall that does not allow ActiveX or
(optionally) Java traffic from the Internet.

Yes, I know this causes problems (especially Java) processing normal B2B
functions. The way around this is sight-specific configuration. This
means telling the firewall, ``do not allow Java traffic through unless
it is from this domain. And for goodness sake do a reverse IP lookup to
make sure they are who they say they are.''

Better yet, use time-sensitive encryption keys, VPN, e.t.c.


-Cooper

From rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com  Tue Jul 16 17:01:51 2002
From: rasmussenm at columbiafunds.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 2002 17:01:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Partitioning Schemes
Message-ID: <0E402AD0FEACD411B7C100508BCDF611052CC062@cmc-exchange.columbiafunds.com>

> From: Felix Lee [mailto:flee at aracnet.com]
> I think, position of partitions on a disk is generally
> pointless micro-optimization.  [snip]  But again, run
> benchmarks if you care.

It's a significant optimization.  I used to work for a streaming video
company and did some disk tests there to determine optimum disk layout and
block size.  

Consider the simple case of a disk with a useable platter that ranges from 1
to 3 inches in diameter.  The rate of data flowing by the heads at the
outside is 3 times greater for the outside tracks than the inside.

At the risk of firing one of the first shots in a text editor holy war, I'll
say this for pico: It's easy to figure out as a newbie. When I didn't know
much else, this was easy to figure out for the basics. Once I got stuck in
vi by mistake and made a bunch of frantic phone calls to see what I had done
to my shell account. Another time I got caught in emacs and it was equally
intimidating. I really thought I'd broken something serious and that there
was no escape. Say what you will about pico and how it lacks in certain
things, but when you're still new to The Land Of The Command Line, it helps
keep you from straying into The Land Of The Lost.

Yes, but for the most part it holds true.  By habit I locate my swap
at the beginning of the disk, it helps.  For most other things it
really does not matter though.  It can easily be a 15% difference in
throughput inner to outer, but only assuming you are not bottle necking
elsewhere.  Other than when you are heavily into swap it makes little
difference.

> block size.  

Yes, but your problem is streaming video.  Typical disk
usage is not anything like that.  If your system is
streaming large amounts of data from your swap partition,
then you have other performance problems that probably won't
be helped much by moving your swap partition to a faster
disk cylinder.
--
[ sometimes emacs is moody ]

From neil at pacifier.com  Tue Jul 16 23:01:44 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)

 MS?)

On 16 Jul 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> It sounded to me like geek-celebrity-cling-fest, which might seem
> interesting to the clingers, but probably not so much for the clingee.
> Going to a party with 200 strangers just to have them all huddle
> around, ready to catch my every dribble, doesn't sound like vacation
> to me.  It sounds excruciatingly mundane.  Maybe it's just me, but I
> find celebrity-worship, cult-of-personality obsession revolting, and
> that's what this idea smelled like.

No, I don't think that is what it would be like at all. It would be a 
barbecue with a guest of honor. Parties are held with guests of honor all 
the time. It does not mean everyone gathers around the guest of honor 
every minute.

To honor someone who has done something interesting is different than the 
celebrity-worship you malign. That sort of worship is characterized by 
people being famous for being famous, not for their achievement.

In the late 19th Century it would have been great to have had a barbecue 
and invited Mark Twain. I believe he enjoyed talking and circulating. 
Maybe Linus likes that sort of thing or maybe he doesn't. I don't know. I 
know he does not like formal speaking engagements so I suggested something 
less formal.

There are alot of others in history and in the contemporary world that I 
think I would love to meet (or have met). The list is long and it 
includes absolutely no celebrities (in the sense that you are 
describing). My list would be a pure meritocracy and I believe that it 
would be the same for most others here.

You don't like the idea which is fine but it is time to let it go. You 
have already expressed your opinion several times. Others do like the idea 
and ultimately anyone invited here will have to make the decision for 
themselves.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

 ACM? (To hear R  MS?)]
In-Reply-To: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA22C@exchange.ci.albany.or.us>

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Miller, Jeremy wrote:
> Why leave them out?  Who would invite people to a BBQ and tell them they
> couldn't bring their family?

Bringing the folks would be nice; but realize it would triple or quadruple
Linus's airfare. This might prove more difficult if we intend to reimburse
him. Other costs -- food, lodging, etc. increase with the number of people.

Practically speaking, assuming Linus comes and we have a barbecue thing,
Linus is going to get mobbed. People won't come to the barbacue to talk
with Joe Schmo, they'll come to talk to Linus, or at least hang out near
him.

What might work is the old "$20 per plate" model -- limit the
number of people to something sane, like 30 or maybe 50, then charge $20
per person, with reservations accepted; first paid, first reserved. Then
the reimbursement is easy:

cost of airfare =  max number of people  *  cost per person

One person who is perhaps less celebrity famous but just as cool in the
free software community is Miguel Iczaga. To me, Miguel would be more
interesting just because he wrote the applications I actually see,
whereas I don't interact with the kernel on a daily basis. If Linus
doesn't jump all over the idea, maybe Miguel can oblige.

Just my 2 bits...


Tyler

On Tue, 16 Jul 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> What might work is the old "$20 per plate" model -- limit the
> number of people to something sane, like 30 or maybe 50, then charge $20
> per person, with reservations accepted; first paid, first reserved. Then
> the reimbursement is easy:
> 
> cost of airfare =  max number of people  *  cost per person

I am afraid that this model may be what needs to happen for anyone from 
out of town that visits, including Stallman.

In the case of Stallman I think the ACM should accept the $200 offered 
from the CS department, set a date for him to come, set a venue, and start 
selling tickets right away. Maybe make it a requirement that people have 
to buy a ticket at a least month ahead of time. That way, you have the 
money in hand before buying his plane ticket if possible.

With the $200, you need to sell 40 more tickets at $10/each. I can't 
imagine that you would have trouble getting *at least* 40 people to buy a 
$10 ticket to see RMS. You come to a PLUG meeting to sell some tickets, 
offer an address to send the money to to get a ticket, send the info to 
the Corvallis, Kfalls, and Eugene LUGs to give them the opportunity to buy 
tickets. Make the $10 the minimum donation to buy a ticket and hopefully a 
few people will chip in a little extra. Maybe you could get some people to 
act on your behalf in Corvallis and Kfalls who could help promote at the 
LUGs there.

I think the important thing is to get the momentum rolling. If you get the 
$200 and you set a date and venue and start selling tickets, I think the 
momentum will build.

ACMers carpe diem!! Go for it. I think the stars favor this thing 
happening!

Neil Anuskiewicz

bad, but you get my drift.  :)

care for pico, really.)  Says "Control-H for help" right at the top, and lo
& behold when you hit it there it all is.  Not bad at all.

editors around, and after getting used to vi.

on a system, that or a similar one is going to be what you have to use.)

From m at netpro.to  Wed Jul 17 11:42:36 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 2002 11:42:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Directory path in the bash prompt?
In-Reply-To: <200207171422.06753.bhoran@hexdev.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207171141180.26130-100000@lukem.com>

Here's a nice prompt that I use in my ~/.bashrc

COLOR1="\[\033[1;35m\]"
COLOR2="\[\033[1;36m\]"
COLOR3="\[\033[1;32m\]"
COLOR4="\[\033[0m\]"
PS1="[$COLOR2\u$COLOR4@$COLOR1\h $COLOR3\w$COLOR4]\\$ "

This displays the full path of the current directory, \w, so you could
take that out if you don't want it.
~M

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Wed Jul 17 12:08:53 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 2002 12:08:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Directory path in the bash prompt?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207171151340.26130-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0207171157580.5154-100000@md.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Wed, 17 Jul 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

>
> On Wed, 17 Jul 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
> > Here's a nice prompt that I use in my ~/.bashrc
> >
> > COLOR1="\[\033[1;35m\]"
> > COLOR2="\[\033[1;36m\]"
> > COLOR3="\[\033[1;32m\]"
> > COLOR4="\[\033[0m\]"
> > PS1="[$COLOR2\u$COLOR4@$COLOR1\h $COLOR3\w$COLOR4]\\$ "

This would be a nice simple prompt, but I can't resist adding two more
features.

PS1="[\@][$COLOR2\u$COLOR4@$COLOR1\h $COLOR3\w$COLOR4]\n\$ "

The \@ will put the time in the prompt (only updates when you hit enter,
but still nice), and \n at the end will put the cursor on a newline so
that it is always in the same colomn on the screen.

There is of course a howto for the bash prompt.  I would recommend it,
because there are quite a few color choices.

And if you want to test a prompt there are to ways to do that.  One is to:
$ export PS1="your new prompt "
or you can edit your ~/.bashrc or whatever file the prompt is in and then
type:
$ source ~/.bashrc

(But don't type the $, that just means do it at a prompt...)

http://www.linuxselfhelp.com/HOWTO/Bash-Prompt-HOWTO/

HTH
Jason

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Jul 17 15:35:12 2002

References: <200207172203.g6HM3rmK011785@mdhost.cse.tek.com>

My first thought is to check all of the cabling and make sure it's all 
okay.  Just because you haven't mussed with it doesn't mean that the 
10krpm drive didn't want to be free.  ;)

If all looks good, then ask the wife if the kids were anywhere near it 
while you were out.  ;D

THEN start mucking with the rescue disk.  Rescue disk is probably the 
best bet if it's not a bad cable somewhere.

-R

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Jul 17 15:45:00 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 2002 15:45:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Need Help - DISK CRASH ???
Message-ID: <317048404.1026945884719.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Wed, 17 Jul 2002, Kevin Cosgrove kevinc at mdhost.cse.tek.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> At a subsequent reboot I got:
> 
>     scsi: aborting command due to timeout: pid 0, scsi 0, channel
>     0, id 1, lun 0 read(10) 00 00 5d 65 7c 00 00 08 00
>     scsi0: aborting CCB #54 to target 1
>     scsi0: CCB #54 to target 1 aborted

That is a SCSI-level error which should be independent of your disk
contents (MBR or otherwise).  For some reason a SCSI command that Linux
sent out never came back.  This could be due to:

1) Loose cable
2) Unpowered or intermittently powered device
3) Poor termination
4) Dead disk
5) Driver bug
6) Some really obscure problem

I would avoid the rescue disk until the SCSI errors are solved.  Trying to
"rescue" a disk and having the process fail in the middle might just cause
more problems.

Unless it's an obvious problem (i.e. loose cable), I would quickly invest
in a replacement disk and get all the data on this disk mirrored someplace
else.

  -- Steve
