From lemming at attbi.com  Mon Jul 22 12:12:05 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 19:12:05 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Windows versus Linux security
Message-ID: <20020722191205.EHRA26053.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@rwcrwbc69>

I saw four or five different Linux worms in the past, 
but they were usually written for particular 
vulnerabilities and often would even depend on how the 
system had been installed.  One worm would only 
propagate with Redhat installed as one partition.

The big difference between the Windows and Unix attacks 
are that the Unix vulnerablities are usually a 
programming mistake, while Windows starts from a design 
mistake. Ok, that's a bit of a biased view, but that 
does make the Unix problems easier to fix.

I think Unix was helped tremendously by having BSD on 
many college campuses in the 80's.  There were all sorts 
of problems pointed out by rogue programs. (Hmm, what 
happens if I just fork recursivily...)

-Mark

nothing. I've checked the power supply, and it is putting out + and - 12

sold all their inventory to somebody called Derf in New York, and that
they (Planar) didn't know anyone locally who could work on the unit.

inventory. I've sent them an e-mail, but I'm not hopeful.

Unfortunately, they were both archives of e-mails I had sent to the PLUG
list and the related replies! Sigh.

I remember reading some recommended service houses on this list in the
last couple of months. I'll check the archives and see if one of those
places can work on this thing.

I figured out what was wrong.

Had NOTHING to do with Gnome2.

Had everything to do with XkbLayout in XF86Config set to "us_intl"
instead of "us".

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 22 16:58:47 2002

apt-get install kernel-internals-guide?

You might try finding a book that teaches unix.  I have one called "Unix
for Programmers and Users" that describes things pretty well.  It teaches
how to use csh, bash, perl and a few others at the basic level.  How to
use system calls when programming and gives the concepts behind the
filesystem, scheduler and networking.  Not enough technical detail if you
want to be an administrator, but it is good for giving people an
introduction to unix operating systems, and gives tips for deciphering man
pages.

If you are interested, I can send you the ISBN of the book.  I don't have
it with me, but it is smallish blue book.  The cover has a web browser on
it.

HTH,
Jason

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jul 22 16:59:59 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 16:59:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] mounting HP drives on Linux
Message-ID: <570028566.1027382382359.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Josh:

I don't think your chances are good.  HP uses the Veritas filesystem
(vxfs) by default.  Although there is a "freevxfs" driver in the kernel
(2.4.9) I don't know how stable it is.

HP includes by default a proprietary logical volume manager (LVM) which to
my knowledge has not been reverse-engineered.  The best you can hope for
is to find out the general header structure so that you can "dd" the data
off the disk and try to get the Veritas filesystem to mount this image
over a loopback device.

You might be able to hack something that searches the raw disk for a valid
vxfs superblock and tries different offsets until the filesystem looks
"sane".  But that's a lot of work.

It's going to be easier to just copy the data from the HP system to the
Linux system.

  -- Steve

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Mon Jul 22 17:03:16 2002
From: eli.stair.lists at attbi.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:03:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
References: <20020722235135.STRD24728.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <000501c231dc$5a0be3d0$4a1ce00c@shrike>

As far as distro-agnostic texts go, Running Linux is pretty good.

A great book for Debian is "Debian Unleashed", it covers quite a
lot, many topics are very in depth.  The only Red Hat book I've 
looked at is "Linux Administration: A Beginner's Guide".  If you're 
running Red Hat, and a beginner, it really can't be beat.  It's pretty
light if you have much experience with UNIX at all, but from the
sounds of it it might be a good fit.

Hope this helps :)

/eli

From sandy at herring.org  Mon Jul 22 17:18:05 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:18:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Windows versus Linux security
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207221006540.10408-100000@localhost.localdomain>; from neil@pacifier.com on Mon, Jul 22, 2002 at 10:09:51AM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207220947470.25535-100000@critter.deatech.com> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207221006540.10408-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20020722171805.F20629@kippered.herring.org>

On Mon, 22 Jul 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote: 
[...]
> It is all too arbitrary, including the money metric.
> 
> There has to be a standardized, easy to measure metric. That is the only 
> way it will be credible. It must be simple and not subject to much 
> "interpretation".
> 
> Again, as an economic study measuring the economic costs of security 
> vulnerabilities would be fantastic.

What this all really boils down to as a practical exercise (as opposed to an
academic analysis) is how do we convince the guys in suits (CEOs/CIOs) of
the cost/benefit in using linux vs. windows in their enterprise? They're not
interested in numbers of virii, or how sysadmins see the issue. They want to
know how much it's going to cost them to stay with the status quo, what is
the cost of switching, and how much money will they save if they do switch.

And no, I have no idea how to arrive at those answers.

Sandy

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 22 17:08:18 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:08:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
In-Reply-To: <20020722235135.STRD24728.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207221704480.12950-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 22 Jul 2002 crisponions at attbi.com wrote:

> I was wondering if any of you knew of a good book(s) to help aid me in my
> understanding of Linux.  I have several books that show you how, but none
> explain WHY.  I am looking for something that describes the operating
> system and how it works a little more, so next time I am configuring I
> might have a bit more of an understanding instead of just following
> directions.

Dave,

  Yes, there are a lot of distribution-specific books out there and others
on system and network administration (Marcel Gagne's book is particularly
good, by the way), but too few that give a broad overview.

  I understand that my favorite is no longer in print (after a couple of
years!), but the library or a used book store should be able to get a copy
for you. It's Phil Cornes' "Linux A-Z" and is based on his English
university course in operating systems. He covers a lot of the same topics
as everyone else, but he puts in a lot of the why; just what you're seeking.

  Highly recommended.

Rich

>Stephen,
>
>   Below is a copy of ~/.emacs. They're always a work in progress and readily
>shared among users. I like the same appearance of emacs whether it's running
>on a console or in a virtual terminal during an X session. Take what works
>for you.
>
>Rich
>-----------------------------------------------------------
>(cond (window-system
>   (setq default-frame-alist
>     '((width            . 350)
>       (height           . 400)
>       (font . "-adobe-courier-medium-r-*--*-165-*-*-m-*-iso8859-1")
>       (foreground-color . "white")
>       (background-color . "black")
>       (mouse-color      . "Orchid")
>       (cursor-color     . "Orchid")
>       (icon-type        . t)      ; gnu picture as Emacs icon
>       (icon-name        . nil)    ; use frame title
>   ))
>   (setq frame-title-format "%b")      ; set frame title to buffer name
>   (setq  icon-title-format "%b")      ; set  icon title to buffer name
>))
>
>(custom-set-variables)
>(custom-set-faces
>  '(default ((t (:size "14"))) t))
>(setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)
>(add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)
>(setq-default transient-mark-mode t)
>;(require 'tex-site)
>(require 'ps-print)
>(global-font-lock-mode 
>t)
>(setq font-lock-maximum-decoration t)
>
>(cond (window-system
>   (setq font-lock-face-attributes
>;              face                     fg        bg  bf  it  ul
>     '((font-lock-comment-face       "GreenYellow" nil  t   t  nil)
>       (font-lock-string-face        "wheat"   nil nil  t  nil)
>       (font-lock-keyword-face       "purple"      nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-type-face          "MediumVioletRed" nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-function-name-face "DarkOliveGreen4"       nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-variable-name-face "DodgerBlue"       nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-reference-face     "SeaGreen"        nil nil  t   t ))
>     font-lock-maximum-decoration t
>     font-lock-support-mode 'lazy-lock-mode
>     font-lock-verbose nil
>     lazy-lock-stealth-verbose nil
>   )
>   (if (fboundp 'global-font-lock-mode)
>       (global-font-lock-mode t)
>       (add-hook 'find-file-hooks 'turn-on-font-lock))
>))
>
>;; kludge until colors work correctly:
>(make-face 'rbs-comment-face)
>(set-face-foreground 'rbs-comment-face "wheat")
>(set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")
>
>(make-face 'rbs-string-face)
>(set-face-foreground 'rbs-string-face "LightPink1")
>(set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")
>
>(make-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
>(set-face-foreground 'rbs-keyword-face "khaki1")
>(set-face-background 'rbs-keyword-face "black")
>
>(make-face 'rbs-type-face)

>(set-face-background 'rbs-type-face "black")

>(make-face 'rbs-function-name-face)

>(set-face-background 'rbs-function-name-face "black")

>(make-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)

>(make-face 'rbs-constant-face)
>(set-face-foreground 'rbs-constant-face "black")
>(set-face-background 'rbs-constant-face "black")
>
>; let the new face be the font face
>(setq font-lock-comment-face 'rbs-comment-face)
>(setq font-lock-string-face 'rbs-string-face)
>(setq font-lock-keyword-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
>(setq font-lock-type-face 'rbs-type-face)
>(setq font-lock-function-name-face 'rbs-function-name-face)
>(setq font-lock-variable-name-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)
>(setq font-lock-reference-face 'rbs-reference-face)
>(setq font-lock-constant-face 'rbs-constant-face)
>
>;; for C code:
>(global-set-key "%" 'match-paren)
>
>(defun match-paren 
>(arg)
>"Go to the matching parenthesis if on parenthesis otherwise insert 
>%."
>       (interactive 
> "p")
>       (cond ((looking-at "\\s\(") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\)") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\{") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\}") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\[") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\]") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             (t (self-insert-command (or arg 1)))))

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 22 17:29:22 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:29:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SuitWatch - June 27 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207221728460.12962-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
                                   SuitWatch

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                            "Karmic Adjustments"

   Thursday, June 27--Here at Linux Journal we often half-joke about the
   years remaining before we finish working off our "Microsoft-bashing
   karma". (Bashing Microsoft is so last millennium, y'know?) That means
   the trick is to talk about Our Friends from Redmond in an objective
   way, which is easier these days because Microsoft looms progressively
   smaller as a dominant force. (See, I didn't bash. We're talking facts
   here.)

   For perspective, let's remember what life with IBM was like when that
   company's influence was at high ebb--a period that lasted through most
   of computing's history. Those of us old enough to remember can recall
   referring to Big Blue simply as "the environment". In those days you
   either lived as fleas in the fur of the great blue beast or you were,
   so to speak, out in the cold.

   What's interesting from today's perspective is not that IBM
   "controlled" so much of the industry or that Microsoft later did the
   same. What's interesting is that both dominated through a long period
   when it was possible for one company to define the whole world for
   everybody else. For a century or more AT&T did the same in telephone
   communications. IBM and AT&T provided base infrastructure for
   everybody else in their industries. Even if they didn't own the iron
   or the wires, they owned and controlled countless protocols, standards
   and foundational products. Gradually that kind of hegemony wore away.
   Few of us remember when Racal-Vadic came out with the first non-"Bell"
   full duplex 1200bps modem. It may seem like a small thing today, but
   at the time it looked like a crack across a vast ice shelf. There were
   a lot of those cracks, mostly forgotten today.

   The ice age is over. What dominates now is the Internet, with an
   infrastructure that consists mostly of protocols: TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP,
   SMTP, IMAP, LDAP, FTP, Telnet, POP3 and so on. "The history of the Net
   is the history of its protocols", Vint Cerf says. These are the things
   that nobody owns, everybody can use and anybody can improve, although
   once a protocol is established, improvement tends to come in the form
   of additional protocols supporting additional services. These
   protocols are established often by quiet adoption by many companies,
   rather than by loud promotion by one company.

   In the last few days I've heard casual mention that two widely
   different companies were using the Jabber protocol for routing XML
   streams between here and there. One is Apple, which apparently will
   use the Jabber protocol (not the server, just the protocol) in its new
   iChat system. The other is Fidelia:
   http://www.fidelia.com, which does performance management for Linux
   and Solaris systems in enterprises. Neither company mentions this fact
   anywhere in its public documents (not that I can find, anyway). If
   this constitutes a trend (and I suspect it does), AOL's and
   Microsoft's instant messaging (IM) systems will inevitably find
   themselves adapting to a world where the prevailing IM protocol is one
   they don't own.

   There is no reason either company shouldn't be able to continue
   dominating the IM service business, whatever that business becomes.
   They just won't control IM infrastructure, because Jabber (or one of
   its descendents) will become the Net's primary protocol for instant
   messaging and presence detection (the protocol's other main virtue).

   As the Net grows in the number and variety of services supported by
   its basic protocols (say, wireless networking, thanks to 802.11b, and
   zero configuration networking (zeroconf):
   http://www.zeroconf.org, which will make its first major appearance in
   Apple's forthcoming Rendezvous:
   http://www.apple.com/macosx/newversion/), countless new businesses and
   market categories will be made possible. This is a good thing, even
   for dominant companies like AOL and Microsoft. The trick for these
   incumbent dominators is to play a supportive game, not a lock-in
   game--to obey the imperative best expressed by John F. Kennedy: "With
   great power comes great responsibility."

   In apparent compliance with that imperative, Microsoft has been
   expressing a need to take responsibility for security. Not long ago
   Bill Gates declared that "trustworthy computing" was Job One. This
   week that commitment bore fruit in the form of "Palladium", a "vision"
   that would, in the words of the Wall Street Journal, "Make online
   security and the protection of some Internet content a built-in
   feature of personal computers."

   The rollout was carefully orchestrated. In Newsweek and MSNBC:
   http://www.msnbc.com/news/770511.asp, Steven Levy called Palladium
   "one of the riskiest ventures the company has ever attempted. Though
   Microsoft does not claim a panacea, the system is designed to
   dramatically improve our ability to control and protect personal and
   corporate information. Even more important, Palladium is intended to
   become a new platform for a host of yet-unimagined services to enable
   privacy, commerce and entertainment in the coming decades." He adds,
   "Because its ultimate success depends on ubiquity, Palladium is either
   going to be a home run or a mortifying whiff."

   Some of the best thinking about Palladium has been coming from Eric
   Norlin at DigitalID World. In "The 282 Billion Dollar Riddle":
   http://www.digitalidworld.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=ar
   ticle&sid=72, Norlin says Microsoft's grand strategy mooshes Palladium
   together with the .NET development framework and "Trustbridge", a new
   "federated identity system for the enterprise". He says:

     As Palladium, TrustBridge and .NET come to fruition Microsoft will
     once again find themselves the OS company with an OS that isn't a
     commodity. The reason for this is an identity-based core, but -- in
     what I'm willing to proclaim a masterstroke -- Microsoft has chosen
     not to try to make *that* part of it proprietary. In other words,
     Microsoft will push hard for federated, interoperable identity.
     They will do so, while keeping some parts of Palladium, TrustBridge
     and .NET proprietary -- that is their hook. They will let identity
     be open, interoperable and flexible, and in return they will make
     sure that their OS is proprietary. It's in their best interest to
     do so from a legal and business perspective, and they know it.

   Among other places, here's where Norlin goes: "Microsoft's involvement
   with the WS-I (web services) standards group--specifically their cozy
   involvement with IBM--now makes perfect sense. IBM turns Linux into a
   pure enterprise play; Microsoft takes the "consumer" market."

   Then he makes one more point worth passing along: "Microsoft does not
   consider Liberty, Sun or anyone in identity to be competition. They
   want to intemperate with all of them."

   In fact, selective interoperability appears to be a key strategy. How?
   Well, get this: Microsoft is going to publish the Palladium source
   code. "We want to be transparent in all this", Jim Allchin says. For
   more of the rest of the story, Extreme Tech has a rather deep
   analysis.:
   http://www.extremetech.com/article2/0,3973,274309,00.asp

   Meanwhile, right next to the Palladium story in Monday's Wall Street
   Journal was a larger, above-the-fold item that was anything but good
   news: "New Microsoft Pricing Looms". The subhead said much more: "Some
   Customers Consider Switching to Rivals' Software". The larger story is
   about Microsoft's new software pricing policy, which takes effect at
   the end of July and has been anything but a PR success. Says the
   Journal:

     Because of expected price increases, some longtime customers are
     considering competing products such as the Linux operating system
     and Sun Microsystems Inc.'s StarOffice, which competes with
     Microsoft's ubiquitous Office suite of programs. The chief
     information officer of one large European financial concern who
     declined to be named for fear of raising Microsoft's ire said he
     was "70% sure" his firm would start moving its more than 30,000
     computer desktops to Linux-based software made by a company called
     Ximian Inc. instead of re-signing with Microsoft.

   Meanwhile Ximian is calling Microsoft's July 31 deadline "Y2Pay" and
   is offering customers a special deal:

     If yours is like many companies, you're facing an ominous deadline
     on July 31st. You'll have to decide whether to commit now for
     future Microsoft software upgrades you may not need or want, or
     face the prospect of higher costs for new licenses later. The
     countdown to Y2Pay is coming. What will your company do?

     You do have a choice--begin moving users to lower-cost Linux
     desktops using software and solutions from Ximian. From now through
     August 15th, you can purchase Ximian Desktop Professional Edition
     for Linux, a complete desktop environment and suite of productivity
     applications that includes Sun StarOffice 6.0 and Ximian Evolution,
     at a savings of up to 25% over the usual price.

   Any business Ximian gets out of this will be a huge boon, even if most
   Microsoft customers go ahead and sign new contracts (which is the
   default assumption). Operating systems continue to commodify at a
   rapid pace. Linux is simply taking the lead in that much broader
   movement. The new commodity operating system isn't Linux but whatever
   UNIX you feel like using, Linux included. If you're working under the
   hood in command-line mode, the differences between Linux, BSD, Solaris
   and OS X matter less than the fact that deep down they're all breeds
   of an OS that's purely infrastructural.

   I suspect that Palladium isn't as infrastructural as Microsoft would
   like it to look. But it still involves a number of concessions that
   make clear that the company is simply a significant inhabitant of a
   larger ecosystem, rather than the whole environment.

   Doc Searls:
   mailto:doc at ssc.com is senior editor of Linux Journal. His monthly
   column is Linux for Suits. He is also a coauthor of The Cluetrain
   Manifesto.




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jul 22 17:34:09 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:34:09 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SuitWatch - July 11 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207221733310.12962-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
                                   SuitWatch

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal

                              "Getting Clear"

   Thursday, July 11--The appeals of Linux the enterprise are rapidly
   crossing the perceptual line between the possible and the obvious. On
   Monday, eWeek published "Open-Source Enterprise":
   http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,362400,00.asp, in which Debra
   Donston wrote, "It's not a question of whether open source should
   exist in the enterprise, but a question of how much and where."
   According to eWeek Labs West Coast Technical Director Timothy Dyck,
   "there's probably no company that hasn't used open source." There's a
   trend here, and it's apparent in eWeek's name, which used to be PC
   Week.

   But what is that trend toward, and is it only about open source? Let
   me put it a different way: Is open source (or free software, or any of
   the other well-worn Linux development topics) the only subject we can
   talk about here? Now that open source and Linux are so successful, are
   there any new topics we should start paying attention to?

   I had that question in mind earlier this week when I interviewed Tim
   O'Reilly:
   http://tim.oreilly.com for two hours. It was a follow-up to an
   interview from January 2000:
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=4467, conducted at
   LinuxWorld Expo during the height of the dot-com boom. What interested
   me about Tim at the time was his experienced perspective. Tim had been
   around both publishing and UNIX for so long that he knew how trends
   tend to work, how to take advantage of them and how not to get sucked
   in by transient obsessions.

   During this week's interview (which is still being transcribed), Tim
   said, "Successful businesses and movements know that trends tend to
   peak and start on a downturn. Often there is a related trend, an
   expansion, or a different slant on it, that is picking up steam at the
   same time. And you have to jump to the new curve."

   When you're talking about subjects like Linux and open source--a
   technology and a methodology that are each soaking into the world,
   spreading like a stain--the trend is not part of a sine wave. If there
   is a decline, it's more likely to be one of velocity, not of
   direction. But even a velocity change is still a curve. And maybe the
   subject at hand isn't the only one that people want to talk about.
   Topics rarely travel alone; there must be allied trends nearby.

   So, what are the allied trends that tend to support Linux and open
   source but are not immediately concerned with them--that are starting
   to ramp up?

   I've been thinking lately about two candidates. One is infrastructure,
   and the other is transparency. I've been writing about both here in
   SuitWatch and on the Linux Journal site. "Is Linux Infrastructure--or
   Is It Deeper than That?":
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6074 ran on the site in
   May. "Is Transparency the Killer Virtue?":
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6196 ran a few days ago.

   In both cases I looked at conversations taking place outside the
   traditional Linux community, or outside the usual conversations within
   the Linux community. For example, IBM may now belong to the Linux
   community, but its INFRASTRUCTURE campaign:
   http://www-3.ibm.com/e-business/doc/content/event/infrastructure.html
   doesn't even mention Linux on its web page. I believe that's because
   IBM is less interested in selling Linux as an operating system than in
   putting it to use as infrastructure supporting IBM products and
   services. In that role, Linux is somewhat invisible.

   Which brings me to a question I've been wrestling with: Is
   infrastructure naturally transparent? If so, that would seem to
   account for much of its appeal.

   A few years ago I was talking to a friend who was a programmer for a
   rapidly growing dot-com. Their platform was Windows NT, which he said
   was fraught with memory leaks and other reliability problems. He added
   this: "When I'm building a skyscraper, I want to know there's rebar in
   the concrete. With Linux, I know. With Microsoft, I don't. In fact,
   NT's memory leaks prove to me there isn't rebar in there. Since I have
   to work with NT for political reasons, I just cope with it. But I know
   if we could see the source, we could probably fix the problem pretty
   fast."

   I've thought often about what he said, almost always in terms of
   "open" and "closed". But what about "transparent" and "opaque"? Yes,
   concrete building materials are hardly transparent in a literal sense,
   but builders need to be extremely clear about what they're working
   with. If it's foundational stuff--true infrastructure, not a
   "platform" that sits on other infrastructure--the builder wants to
   know, or to be in a position to find out, exactly what's in there.
   Lives, or at least livelihoods, depend on it.

   There is another reason transparency appeals as a virtue. It's not a
   loaded term that brings up all kinds of old political conflicts from
   inside the community, as "open:" and "free" tend to do. It also
   doesn't need much explaining. The reason governments from Peru to
   China are adopting Linux has everything to do with the transparency of
   its innards. It also may have to do with its price and its development
   methods, but transparency is the deeper issue. Without any secrets,
   governments don't have to waste any time or energy wondering what's in
   there.

   Positioning Linux as transparent infrastructure--along with the Net it
   augments--also tends to position Windows as non-infrastructural (or
   relatively less infrastructural) software, regardless of its immense
   popularity. If there are limits to which one can conceptually depend
   on it, then there are limits to its qualifications as infrastructure.
   This doesn't make it bad, but less useful as foundational building
   material.

   Note that I'm not saying opaque platforms and software that run on
   those platforms are bad either; I'm simply saying they are not
   necessarily infrastructural. If their developers are smart, they'll
   make use of existing infrastructural protocols or write some of their
   own. That's what Userland and Microsoft did by developing SOAP, a
   purely infrastructural protocol that benefits every product that uses
   it.

   Yesterday I put up a new discussion at the Linux for Suits forum,
   titled "Should we be talking more about transparency?":
   http://www.linuxjournal.com/modules.php?op=modload&name=Forum&file=vie
   wtopic&topic=180&forum=18

   I'm honestly not sure. What do you think? Jump in the forum, and let's
   talk about it.




From m at netpro.to  Mon Jul 22 17:51:13 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 17:51:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Editor in Console window
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020723083314.00bdee90@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207221748420.15402-100000@lukem.com>

On Tue, 23 Jul 2002, Stephen Liu wrote:

> I discover some files with "rc" at their end, such as "abcrc", "defghrc",
> "ijklmnrc".  What are those files used for ?

rc stands for resource configuration.  It generally means that it's a
config file for whatever is before the rc.  For example, .bashrc is a
config file for your bash environment.
~M

On Mon, 2002-07-22 at 17:33, Mike Witt wrote:

> and flowcharts. All I need is to be able to draw rectangles,

dia isn't bad.  It stores the diagram in an XML form, and there are a
couple of compilers out there that can take a dia UML diagram and
generate code stubs and data structures from it.  One takes UML and
outputs SQL.

From verso at mac.com  Mon Jul 22 20:13:38 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 20:13:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <000701c231ee$885dc7a0$6501a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <B96217F2.3D1D%verso@mac.com>

I have considerable experience with OSX (I signed up at the Public Beta
phase) and I have spent some time in *nix as well, so if you would let me
know what sort of issues you are interested in I'll do my best to fill you
in. (See below)

OSX comes in two pieces, essentially. There's the guts, called Darwin, which
is the *nix stuff. Underpinnings (I think) is the word Apple uses. Darwin is
based on BSD, but is propietary (which is how they get away with charging
for it). Aqua is the second piece of the OS. Aqua is the UI portion of
things. This is the part you see, but is not necessarily what you are stuck
with. I have heard tell of others using different window managers aside from
Aqua, and I know that you can boot OSX into single user mode, enable root,
run fsck, and all sorts of other groovy *nixy stuff with Terminal.

One of the things I think is most impressive about OSX (It's pronounced oh
ess ten, btw) is what they call "Classic". This is the ability of OSX to run
an emulation layer of OS9, the 'old' OS. It's not as big a deal now that the
Big Ones have OSX versions (Photoshop, Office, etc) but if you still need
something from OS9 there's nothing standing in the way of your forward
migration. To build a native emulator of an entire OS into the system itself
is pretty gol-danged cool.

My experience with OSX vs. Win2k is as follows:

I have both in my office right now. I use OSX and my husband uses the
Wintendo (as I lovingly refer to it). He restarts his all the time. Things
happen, stuff just up and breaks, etc. He knows to do preventative
maintenance on his machine because I won't help him with it if he doesn't.
(: I restart mine when I have a software update that requires it. And even
then I store up a bunch of them. This is nowhere near as often. I mean, not
even once a month. I don't run Outlook or IIS so I don't get the virus du
jour. I don't have any problems with file compatibility or with trying to do
things on my Mac that he can do on his machine, and I don't have to go
through any sort of gyration most of the time. In fact, I run as the
fileserver on our network because it's easier to set up and less work to
admin my machine than it is to set him up the same way. I have only ever
worried about my computer freaking out when my hard drive began to swallow
itself whole. Usually I want to hug my computer. My husband usually wants to
hit his.

Wow I got long-winded! This help? (:

-Kelly
R-17 is not a fixed velocity, but it is clearly far too fast.  -H2G2

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 22 21:52:21 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 21:52:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
In-Reply-To: <20020722235135.STRD24728.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207222004290.13882-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> I was wondering if any of you knew of a good book(s) to
> help aid me in my understanding of Linux.

Most of the books mentioned so far revolve around system administration;
if you want a theoretical approach try Bell Lab's classic "Operating
Systems" (the dinosaur book) by Avi Silberschatz; it has a hefty chapter
on the internals of Linux, as well as covering general operating system
concepts.

For those interested in Mach, FreeBSD, or Nachos, there are
supplementary chapters on those systems freely available at:

http://www.bell-labs.com/topic/books/os-book/

Btw, much of the Hurd microkernel is derived from Mach.


Tyler

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 22 21:53:30 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 21:53:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <000701c231ee$885dc7a0$6501a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207222115580.13882-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> I have a paper to write constrasting MacOSX and Windows 2000.  I also
> wanted to contrast Mac OS with Linux

The term "operating system" covers a lot of ground -- at what level are
you performing this comparison? Operating systems could be compared at:

1) kernel level (how the OS actually works)

2) API level (what developers interact with)

3) Application level (what users interact with)

You might find FreeBSD and GNU/Linux-based systems very similar at levels
2 and 3, for example, but very different at level 1. Strictly speaking,
Windows NT is also similar at level 2 since it can implement POSIX.

Also note how inner workings of the operating system are largely
transparent: an expert Linux or Windows programmer might not have much
idea what kind of paging table the OS uses, or how VMM is implemented.

Tyler

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 22 22:36:01 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 22:36:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207222004290.13882-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207222222070.14678-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>


On Mon, 22 Jul 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> For those interested in Mach, FreeBSD, or Nachos, there are
> supplementary chapters on those systems freely available at:
>
> http://www.bell-labs.com/topic/books/os-book/

Hey that's cool.

>
> Btw, much of the Hurd microkernel is derived from Mach.

I think the more correct thing to say would be that the microkernel used
by Hurd is the Mach microkernel (it only has slight modifications, to call
it the GNU Mach).  Hurd is a collection of "servers" that run in user
space and provide much functionality that is traditionaly built right into
the kernel.  This approach has a performance penalty, but allows for
debugging of many kernel modules in user space.  Another advantage is that
servers can be loaded/unloaded dynamically.  In many cases this allows
kernel development to be done by non-root users, with the advantage of
allowing the developer to use a normal debugger.  And one more advantage
of seperating the address space of the servers and kernel, is that it is
much harder to corruput the internal state of the kernel.  The servers
actually have a normal main like normal C programs.

One interesting feature of the Hurd is that you don't mount things in the
traditional sense.  Instead you create a translation, or a server that
provides a translation.  One simple but interesting example is a file that
changes its contents whenever it is read.  One use might be a .sig file
that changes to a new sig everytime it is read.

One final note is that Hurd is planning to change to the L4 microkernel as
soon as the L4 developers give the signal.  I don't know much about L4
other than it is getting a lot of attention from its performance and
stability.

Anyway...that is all I know about the subject...

Jason

Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 23:59:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
In-Reply-To: <20020723050526.72065.qmail@web13802.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20020722235135.STRD24728.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020722234911.00b603d0@mail.localnet.dimstar.net>

At 10:05 PM 7/22/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>The
>question usually is "I want to do this, HOW to I do
>it?" not "I can do this, WHY would I want to do so?".

Not necessarily. "Why?" is a very good question, and an important one.

 From the original query, I take it to mean that the subject in question 
wishes to understand why they are doing the configuring they're doing. They 
aren't content with simply following someones' instructions because they're 
told to.

Why do we use a firewall?

Why do we configure postfix the way we do?

Why do we... etc.

If we stop asking why, then we're just repeating what others before us have 
done, and we'll all be in trouble when a flaw is found. One of the reasons 
we have freedom of the press in this country is so that someone will 
continue to ask, "Why?"

In my mind, the why question is every bit as important as the how question. 
In fact, the why question should be answered satisfactorily, prior to one 
asking the how question.

Why should I ask how to do something, if doing so, makes no sense?

Just because one can do a thing, does not mean that one *should* do that 
thing. If there is a compelling reason to do it, then that may be the 
answer to the question of, "why?"

I, and I assume the person in question here too, want to know why I must do 
these things, not simply that I must do them. Then let me decide for myself 
if I really *must* do them.


Russ Johnson
Stargate Online

http://www.dimstar.net
telnet://telnet.dimstar.net
ICQ: 3739685


How do you tell when you're out of invisible ink?

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul 23 03:05:00 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 03:05:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Good linux book
In-Reply-To: <20020722235135.STRD24728.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207230253460.14987-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 22 Jul 2002 crisponions at attbi.com wrote:
> I was wondering if any of you knew of a good book(s) to help aid me in
> my understanding of Linux.  I have several books that show you how,
> but none explain WHY.  I am looking for something that describes the
> operating system and how it works a little more, so next time I am
> configuring I might have a bit more of an understanding instead of
> just following directions.

While I'm as confused about this question as just about anyone who has
already responded in this thread, I'll throw in a few cents.

Personally, I think that if you're new to Unix and unix-like operating
systems, the first thing you should read is Essential System
Administration by Aeleen Frisch.  The website
(<URL: http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/esa3/ >) says that the third edition
is 2002 (est.).  I don't know if it's available yet.  But this is probably
the best guide to understanding why we do things "the Unix way" that I've
ever seen.

I imagine that since GNU/Linux has exploded in popularity since the
previous edition was published, we can expect a fair amount of focus on
those systems (and distributions other than Ygdrassil).

Failure to read this book is the number one reason we see people on this
list who have entries in their fstab like this:

/dev/hdc1	/D	ext2	defaults	0	1

I can't tell you how much that sort of thing annoys me.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jul 23 03:32:43 2002

Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 03:32:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <B96217F2.3D1D%verso@mac.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207230325270.14987-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 22 Jul 2002, Kelly Guimont wrote:
> Darwin is based on BSD, but is propietary (which is how they get away
> with charging for it).

Being proprietary isn't "how they get away with charging for it".

Being proprietary is how they get away with restricting its distribution
and hiding its implementation details from those to whom they choose to
distribute.

It's an important distinction.

Note that Free Software is not proprietary, but you can charge whatever
you like for it.  You just can't hide its implementation details by
distributing only binaries or restrict its further distribution by other
people.

The BSD license specifically allows such distribution restrictions and
carries no requirement of openness or freedom.  It is essentially a
license to take from the public domain without adding anything.

J.

From ebaur at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 23 09:16:57 2002
From: ebaur at aracnet.com (Eric Shore Baur)
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 09:16:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207230325270.14987-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207230904200.8791-100000@216-99-211-213.dsl.aracnet.com>

On Tue, 23 Jul 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Mon, 22 Jul 2002, Kelly Guimont wrote:
> > Darwin is based on BSD, but is propietary (which is how they get away
> > with charging for it).
>
> Being proprietary isn't "how they get away with charging for it".
>
> Being proprietary is how they get away with restricting its distribution
> and hiding its implementation details from those to whom they choose to
> distribute.
>
> It's an important distinction.
>
	There is a very important distinction... but that's not it.  At
least not for Darwin.  As far as I can tell, there isn't much argument to
be made that Apple is restricting the distribution of Darwin.  It is only
propietary in the sense that Apple modified a number of things in BSD to
work on their hardware and with some of their other technologies.  To
learn more about it (or download it so you can install it yourself -
without cost) go to:
	http://developer.apple.com/darwin/projects/darwin/
They have source code available, a binary installer for the current
version, a CVS repository, etc.  (Note: I believe you do need to register
as a "developer" in order to get to most of the downloads.)

	What they are charging for, and "ptotecting" in some sense, is
Aqua - all the graphical stuff on top of that.  If you install Darwin, you
get UNIX, sure... but nothing on top of it.  You can then build XFree86 on
top of it, if you want a graphical interface, but you won't get one from
Apple.  That's what they want you to buy OS X for.  (And really, what's
the point of Darwin by itself for most users?  LinuxPPC or one of the
other PPC Linux distros has far more to offer).

Eric

don't use the word bugs.  Calling defects bugs has the effect of
shifting responsibility for defects to a mythical creepy crawly that
infests bit rot into code.  Programmers create defects, not bugs.

From ebaur at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 23 09:37:19 2002
From: ebaur at aracnet.com (Eric Shore Baur)
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 09:37:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <000701c231ee$885dc7a0$6501a8c0@Endeavor>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207230920560.8831-100000@216-99-211-213.dsl.aracnet.com>

On Mon, 22 Jul 2002, Greg Long wrote:

> Would welcome any input from those experienced in Linux and MacOSX - My
> experience with all Win32 is considerable (except Me which I considered
[snip]

	I've been using Linux for about 5-6 years (mostly on Apple
hardware, actually) but my desktop systems at home have been classic Mac
OS and OS X since March a year ago.
	First impressions: GUI is very different from anything else I'd
used.  "Cleaner" than X (which has always felt a little klunky to me) and
a little more intuative than Windows.  There seemed to be a lot "missing"
that I wanted, but I was able to adjust very quickly and I can get around
very efficently now.  Even my wife (a Windows sysadmin) doesn't get mad at
it, like she did MacOS 9.
	Stability: similar to Linux.  My OS X machine has crashed probably
5 times in the last year.  Once because I was doing something naughtly
(running a program that I knew was a resource hog on old/slow hardware -
maybe it didn't crash, but I was sick of waiting), the other times it hung
on shutdown (no good idea why).  My Win2K box at work is fairly stable as
well (probably the same number of crashes in the past year), but it seems
to be "worse" when it does crash (like blowing out its video drivers for
no apparent reason).

	As a Mac / Linux user, the system over all was a major blessing.
I had been programming with perl (and now PHP) on top of apache and
postgres all installed on a Linux backend while using the Mac as a front
end - since that's where I had all the tools I liked and the OS I prefered
to interface with directly.  Now I have a single machine that I can do the
same things on without the division of labor.  I currently have all those
server-type things installed as well as XFree86 (XDarwin) so I can run
things like ethereal or rdesktop when I need to.
	With fink (on sourceforge), many unix packages have been ported
over to the OS X / Darwin platform.  I'm not a good enough programmer to
know exactly how difficult it is, but my understanding is that there
really isn't much to do for most things.  Quite often I can download
source code from the internet and compile directly.  (Note: basic install
will not allow this, but you can get Apple's Developer Tools for free
(again, with registration) and get all the necessary command line tools
and a rather nice IDE, if you want to get into Mac OS X programming.)

	From others I've talked to:  If you know BSD, open the Terminal
and you'll be right at home in the shell, if not the directory structure.
If you've used NeXT, a *lot* will look familiar (directory structure and
some elements of the GUI - like the column views).  If you're used to Mac
OS Classic, you might have a lot of adjusting to do.  Same with Windows
users.  For Linux people, it will look and feel a lot different, but
you'll be able to do a lot of the same things.

	Hopefully, this didn't wander too much (or sound too much like a
commercial for Apple's Switch campaign <grin>).  I'm just not really busy
at work right now...

Eric

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 23 11:24:11 2002

> 
> I was originally looking for information on which compiler gives the best 
> performance with Qt. This is better.  :)
> 
> In case anyone wants to chime in with an informed opinion, developers I've 
> talked to like Kai's C++ and Intel C++. Not so happy with gcc, not for C++.

I've never used Kai's or Intel's C++ compilers.  I find g++ works fine for C++
especially the 3.x versions of g++.  There was an article in Dr. Dobb's a couple
of months back where they ran language compliance tests with various C++
compilers - the only two I recall were gcc and Micro$oft's compiler, but there
were others in the mix.  The results of their tests showed that g++ was near the
top in the language compliance department (in fact, if I recall correctly, of
the compilers tested g++ was the most compliant), while Micro$oft's compiler was
the worst.

Anyway, the opionions you got about g++ may have been from folks who were using
pre-3.x versions.

Phil

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 23 11:35:34 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 23 Jul 2002 11:35:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mac OSX contrasted with Linux and Win2000?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207230325270.14987-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207230325270.14987-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <867kjm70nd.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> Note that Free Software is not proprietary, but you can charge
Jeme> whatever you like for it.  You just can't hide its
Jeme> implementation details by distributing only binaries or restrict
Jeme> its further distribution by other people.

BSD code also comes as Free Software, even by the FSF's definition:

    Non-copylefted free software
    
    Non-copylefted free software comes from the author with permission
    to redistribute and modify, and also to add additional
    restrictions to it.

    If a program is free but not copylefted, then some copies or
    modified versions may not be free at all. A software company can
    compile the program, with or without modifications, and distribute
    the executable file as a proprietary software product.

See: <http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/categories.html>

Now, as soon as you (or someone else) start distributing only binaries
and/or restrict its further distribution, then that is no longer Free
Software.  One of the nice features of BSD code these days from a GNU
perspective, is that its relicensability can be used to GNU-ify
previously non-copylefted Free Software, to make it "more Free" in the
GNU sense.

Another Classic system adminsitration book has been ported to Linux, meaning
a Linux specific edition is now available.
http://www.phptr.com/browse.html?http://www.phptr.com/specintr/unix/unix.htm
l

Linux Administration Handbook by Evi Nemeth, Garth Snyder and Trent R. Hein 

The blurb reads: 

Linux Administration Handbook is the first guide for Linux system
administrators that examines how Linux behaves in real-world production
evironments. Replete with war stories and hard-won insights, it describes
difficult tasks in all their complexity, with detailed, true-life examples
for three leading distributions: Red Hat, SuSE, and Debian. Coverage
includes OS configuration, networking, sendmail, security management, kernel
building, performance analysis, routing, and more. Includes a foreword by
Linus Torvalds.

On Mon, Jul 22, 2002 at 09:57:25AM -0700, Jon Jacob wrote:
> Does anyone here use php-mode in xemacs?  I used to have this working
> but took it out for some unknown reason, and now I can't get it back
> again.  
> 
> If anyone knows lisp or emacs well enough to help me with this, I would
> appreciate it.
> 

I use emacs 20.7.

In .emacsrc I have:

(setq auto-mode-alist
      (cons '("\\.php$" . php-mode) auto-mode-alist))

(autoload 'php-mode "php-mode" "PHP editing mode." t)


I also have the files:

/usr/share/emacs/site-lisp/php-mode.el
/usr/share/emacs/site-lisp/php-mode.elc

Hope that helps.

- Aj

> Anyone have any notions on the original question, which may not have been 
> clear: for developing applications in C++,  what compiler do you prefer? The 
> developers I've talked to so far like Kai and Intel for these reasons:
> 
> -complete support for IA 32 & 64 instructions sets

Doesn't gcc have this now?

> -more support for various C++ libraries and widgets
I tend to doubt it - think of all the libraries and widgets that come with your
average Linux distro, they used gcc to compile these.

> -faster compilation and runtimes
split this into two because they're often mutually exclusive.
For your day to day development you want fast compilation so you don't turn on
any optimization, but when you do a release you want to bump your optimization
up to the max which means it'll take longer to compile.  I can believe that the
Intel compiler probably has better optimization for Intel architectures, not
sure about compilation speed, though.

How about price? 
What about language coverage? (I think gcc wins here, but I'd have to dig up the
article)

Phil




From shahms at shahms.com  Tue Jul 23 13:48:15 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 23 Jul 2002 13:48:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Qt-Console released (C++ compilers)
In-Reply-To: <200207232040.g6NKepTY019544@franka.aracnet.com>
References: <200207232040.g6NKepTY019544@franka.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1027457295.2235.2.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

The last time I bothered caring and looked into Intel's C++ compiler
versus G++ I came out with these conclusions:

Intel's supports more of the P2/3/4 specialized instructions than GCC,
but GCC supports the AMD instructions which the Intel compiler doesn't
at all.

Intel's both compiles faster and tends to produce faster run-times than
3.x (and 3.x compiles slower but tends to produce faster run-times than
2.x).

But in terms of features, there isn't another compiler that comes
anywhere close to G++ in standards support.

--Shahms

Subject: [PLUG] Qt-Console released (C++ compilers)

On Tue, 23 Jul 2002 ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:

> > -more support for various C++ libraries and widgets

> I tend to doubt it - think of all the libraries and widgets that
> come with your average Linux distro, they used gcc to compile these.

<disclaimer value="I'm not a compiler nor a C++ wonk"/>

g++ 3 supports C++ templates and namespaces in ways that 2.x doesn't.  
Also, there are some STL interfaces (e.g., sstream) that aren't
supported in 2.x. You'll encounter the problems with 2.x when you try 
to compile code that really relies on the newer C++ standard stuff; 
the Sablotron XSLT processor is like that.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From steveshome at attbi.com  Tue Jul 23 15:07:13 2002

On Tue, Jul 23, 2002 at 08:41:33PM +0000, ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:
> > On Tuesday 23 July 2002 07:58 pm, ptkwt at aracnet.com wrote:
> > > > On Tue, 23 Jul 2002 18:24:11 GMT
> > > >
> > Anyone have any notions on the original question, which may not have been 
> > clear: for developing applications in C++,  what compiler do you prefer? The 
> > developers I've talked to so far like Kai and Intel for these reasons:
> > 
> > -complete support for IA 32 & 64 instructions sets
> 
> Doesn't gcc have this now?

GCC still lacks support for some of the fancy features of the IA-64
architecture such as speculation and software pipelining using
rotating registers.  This hurts IA-64 applications which are heavy
with floating point.  Sorry I don't have any hard data; this is just
from staring at a lot of generated code.

As for C++, library interfaces were changing up to about 3.0.2, which
sometimes caused problems using old shared libraries with new binaries
and vice versa.  If you compile everything with 3.0.2 or later, you
should be ok.

Steve (former IA-64 GCC hacker)

And think in terms of freedoms.  Remember that when you use gcc you are
using/supporting free software.  If you're big on principles then the "my
compiler is faster than your compiler" argument is not really important.
Unless you want to hack the source and make it faster :)

The other thing to remember about compiliing is that if you use makefiles
properly then the time to compile is drastically reduced when developing.
As for releases, I can wait an extra hour if need be.  I believe that gcc
also has many misunderstood options for creating optimizied programs.  I
would be interested in seeing what benchmarks were used, and what
optimazations where applied.  It may be the case that with the right set
of optimizations for the benchmark/architecture that gcc is just as
fast...

Well that's my highly opinionated $0.02 :)
Jason

For C++ there's big difference between gcc 2.x and 3.x. Version 3.x
is much closer to standard C++. For that reason it is the compiler of
choice for my present project. This project's source code base will be around
for a very long time so it will pay to be as forward-compatible as possible.
Sticking to ANSI C++ provides the best chance for forward-compatibility.
On the down side, there some risk in using 3.x because it's still fairly
young, and it's slower to compile code. Supposedly there were some
performance improvements in 3.1 (mostly in the preprocessor) but I've
not tried it yet. It looks like Mandrake will be the first distro to use 3.x
to compile all their code. That should air it out.

> Personally, I think that if you're new to Unix and unix-like operating
> systems, the first thing you should read is Essential System
> Administration by Aeleen Frisch.  The website
> (<URL: http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/esa3/ >) says that the third
> edition is 2002 (est.).  I don't know if it's available yet.  But this
> is probably the best guide to understanding why we do things "the Unix

I'll second that endorsement. I have the second edition, circa 1995. The
advantage I see to some of the older seminal *nix books is that they _do_
often address the "why" question, if only by showing that something is
done a certain way because it's been done that way since the dawn of time.
Its useful even if you never plan to deal with a SCO/AIX/etc box, if just
from a historical perspective.

Not that there hasn't been a tremendous amount of progress, but the basic
concepts have been around for many moons. That is something that has taken
some acclimation for me, in picking up the *nix culture. Our original
poster seems to be talking about learning the culture and "way of doing
things" as much as anything. How about the History of UNIX? Many google
hits on this one; everthing from

http://www.bell-labs.com/history/unix/

to

http://www.crackmonkey.org/unix.html

From steveshome at attbi.com  Tue Jul 23 21:27:23 2002
From: steveshome at attbi.com (Steve Christiansen)
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 21:27:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Qt-Console released (C++ compilers)
In-Reply-To: <200207231913.26097.griffint@pobox.com>; from griffint@pobox.com on Tue, Jul 23, 2002 at 07:13:25PM -0700
References: <200207231957.g6NJvqOY025866@franka.aracnet.com> <200207232029.g6NKTIF13220@smtp.easystreet.com> <200207231913.26097.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <20020723212723.D14982@us.ibm.com>

On Tue, Jul 23, 2002 at 07:13:25PM -0700, Terry Griffin wrote:
> On Tuesday 23 July 2002 06:43 am, Carla Schroder wrote:
> > You can have as many versions of gcc installed as you like, that takes care
> > of kernel compilation.
> >
> > Anyone have any notions on the original question, which may not have been
> > clear: for developing applications in C++,  what compiler do you prefer?
> > The developers I've talked to so far like Kai and Intel for these reasons:
> >
> > -complete support for IA 32 & 64 instructions sets
> > -more support for various C++ libraries and widgets
> > -faster compilation and runtimes
> >
> > That's the story I'm getting so far.
> >
> 
> For C++ there's big difference between gcc 2.x and 3.x. Version 3.x
> is much closer to standard C++. For that reason it is the compiler of
> choice for my present project. This project's source code base will be around
> for a very long time so it will pay to be as forward-compatible as possible.
> Sticking to ANSI C++ provides the best chance for forward-compatibility.
> On the down side, there some risk in using 3.x because it's still fairly
> young, and it's slower to compile code. Supposedly there were some
> performance improvements in 3.1 (mostly in the preprocessor) but I've
> not tried it yet. It looks like Mandrake will be the first distro to use 3.x
> to compile all their code. That should air it out.

Compilation speed is better in 3.1 (compared with 3.0.x), and inlining
is done in a different way.  The RTL inliner in 3.0.x had a reputation
for being overly aggressive, sometimes even reducing performance because
of code bloat.  The inliner in 3.1 is tree-based and uses less aggressive
heuristics.  In fact, one of the problems we had in compiling an IA-64
Linux kernel with GCC 3.1 was that the kernel code assumed certain
functions would be inlined, and they weren't with 3.1.  Fortunately,
GCC provides many command line options to control such things, so a
simple makefile tweak fixed it.

Steve

On Tuesday 23 July 2002 03:21 am, Stephen Liu wrote:

> #smb start
> bash: smb: command not found

Try:
/sbin/service smb start

> # smbd -D|nmbd -D
> bash: smbd: command not found
> bash: nmbd: command not found

If you really want to start the daemons outside of the service script 
mentioned above, it would be something like:

/usr/sbin/smbd -D | /usr/sbin/nmbd -D

If you want to find a certain executable, try:

whereis <executable name>

LIke this:

  [youngdan at dan youngdan]$ whereis smbd
  smbd: /usr/sbin/smbd /usr/share/man/man8/smbd.8.gz

On Wednesday 24 July 2002 05:30 am, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
--snip--
> I see this possible but I'm not really sure how to determine the RPM
> dependencies except by brute force.  I.e. do a test erase (-e --test) for
> each package.  Anyone aware of a tool for graphically showing the
> dependencies.

I prefer:

rpm -q --whatrequires <packagename>

as it gives _just_ a list of dependencies, rather than the mess that the erase 
n' test method gives, i.e.

[youngdan at dan youngdan]$ rpm -q --whatrequires mozilla
mozilla-chat-1.0.0-4
mozilla-devel-1.0.0-4
mozilla-dom-inspector-1.0.0-4
mozilla-js-debugger-1.0.0-4
mozilla-mail-1.0.0-4
mozilla-psm-1.0.0-4
galeon-1.2.5-1

It's not GUI, but it's certainly easier to parse.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School



From bjh at avalongroup.net  Wed Jul 24 08:54:50 2002
From: bjh at avalongroup.net (Brian Hoag)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 08:54:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ip port forwarding?
In-Reply-To: <00ab01c23325$3a38e950$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <NGBBLJPCILJHOGABMALBKEENCJAA.bjh@avalongroup.net>

---Ok, instaleld redir, but how do I use this thing?
---I am searching google for a good howto for this...

---any tips you can throw my way would be great.
---for instance... i need to open up 1417-1419 to an internal machine
---192.168.0.111

---r0bbY

redir --help  for more info

here are some samples

/usr/sbin/redir --laddr=99.999.99.999 --lport=1417 --caddr=192.168.0.111 --c
port=1417 &
/usr/sbin/redir --laddr=99.999.99.999 --lport=1418 --caddr=192.168.0.111 --c
port=1418 &
/usr/sbin/redir --laddr=99.999.99.999 --lport=1419 --caddr=192.168.0.111 --c
port=1419 &

May not be the best way but I run these out of rc.local.  Any startup script
should work.
Here is how it works.

laddr is listen address
lport is listen port
caddr is connect address
cport is connect port
& runs the program in the background

Should work!

Brian Hoag
Group Avalon Technology Services, Inc.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Wed Jul 24 08:59:52 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 08:59:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Minimizing a Linux distribution (RH)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207240519080.3625-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <3D3ECEF8.6020708@sun.com>

I realize you said RH, but here's my take on the Debian side of things.

1) it's much easier to keep your packages updated with cron-apt or a 
cron job that runs apt-get update ; apt-get upgrade

2) removing packages (and finding dependency problems/issues) is as easy 
as apt-get remove [package].  If a package you want to remove has too 
many dependencies, it tells you just exactly what they are.  If it 
doesn't, bye-bye [package]

3) although it's not that important to ME, personally, Debian is a 
GNU/Linux Distribution - meaning it's free as in beer AND as in speech.

The above reasons are pretty much why I went from using RH exclusively 
to now using Debian exclusively.  Dependencies are a major pain in the 
arse, and although no package manager is *perfect*, apt and dpkg come 
pretty close.

You might see how mature the apt-rpm (or somesuch) packages are 
nowadays.  I tried it on my RH system before I converted to Debian, but 
the functionality just wasn't there.

YMMV.

-Richard

From ebaur at aracnet.com  Wed Jul 24 09:11:54 2002

xinetd also works for this.  You can set up a unlisted service that
listens on a specific port, and then you put in a "redirect" option that
will forward all data to that port onto somewhere else.  I use this to ssh
to a machine behind my firewall.

During the installation process, choose to do a custom installation.

absolutely know are essential to your host's operation, e.g.,

The RedHat/base/comps found with your installation media lists the 
packages included in each of the package groups.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Wed Jul 24 10:01:54 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 24 Jul 2002 10:01:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] The "Aptitude" paradigm. (? Out of the box revisited.)
In-Reply-To: <3D3ECEF8.6020708@sun.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207240519080.3625-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
	 <3D3ECEF8.6020708@sun.com>
Message-ID: <1027530114.6196.50.camel@bittersweet>

On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 08:59, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
>> I've been trying to figure out how to minimize a Redhat Linux 
>> distribution.  On the web there are a few references to this but
nothing 
>> concrete.  I am working with vservers 
>> 
>> I see this possible but I'm not really sure how to determine the RPM 
>> dependencies except by brute force.  I.e. do a test erase (-e --test)
for 
>> each package.  Anyone aware of a tool for graphically showing the 
>> dependencies?

> I realize you said RH, but here's my take on the Debian side of things.
> 

Yes, Debian!  When code matters more than commercials.  Qualitatively
and Quantitatively, Debian is hands down the best choice logicale libre
distribution for the IT implementor.  It is simply the best and most
extensive toolkit available.  Debian is a treasure trove.

> 1) it's much easier to keep your packages updated with cron-apt or a 
> cron job that runs apt-get update ; apt-get upgrade
> 

I recommend using "aptitude" for many tasks, rather than "apt-get". 
Most of the features that "aptitude" offers via it's tui (text user
interface; ncurses based) are also available via the command line.  It
utilizes the same library, libapt-pkg (C++), that "apt-get" does, but
provides additional functionality over and above that of "apt-get"...

> 2) removing packages (and finding dependency problems/issues) is as easy 
> as apt-get remove [package].  If a package you want to remove has too 
> many dependencies, it tells you just exactly what they are.  If it 
> doesn't, bye-bye [package]
> 

Here's one of the things that "aptitude" makes into a simple task. 
Inside it's TUI.  You can easily see the forward and reverse "Depends",
"Recommends", "Suggests", and "Enhances" dependencies.

"aptitude" will let you mark a package as having been installed due to
another package listing it as a dependency.  It can be set so that it
will automatically uninstall packages so marked when their reverse
depends packages are uninstalled.  This feature is the solution to the
problem presented in the original question.

You can also put a package on "hold" status, and it and it's
dependencies will never be automatically upgraded from that point on. 
You must unhold it to get it to upgrade after that.  This feature is
very useful when you've patched something locally, or need to maintain a
version of something for which a (non security or feature critical)
upgrade would break a set of local admin scripts (for instance), or that
you've patched, like if you've got ipfilter patches applied to your
kernel and have rebuilt iptables to match.   Aptitude's command line can
be used to script the setting and unsetting of hold status when need be,
in case you've got to write a script to run on many machines or
something.

If you need to rebuild a Debian package, perhaps to configure it with a
feature not built into it by default, or to apply a patch you need in
it, you can easily do so with "apt-get source" and a minor amount of
effort (I recommend the use of CVS to facilitate maintenance.).  It will
easily build a binary .deb with your changes, with a simple
"debian/rules binary".  The Debian packaging system is well documented
(look around on http://www.pdxlinux.org/dc/) and driven by standard
"make", rather than by a special tool that introduces yet another syntax
you must learn.  The build system is infinitely  malleable, modular, and
easy to extend in arbitrary ways.  (Can YOU predict future needs?) 

You can then place that .deb into a locally visible HTTP server, run a
command that builds the apt "Packages" meta data file, and add that site
to the "sources.list" on all the machines where you want that
installed.  You then create a "Release" file (see the official Debian
archive with a web browser to see where to put it and what it contains;
also read the apt_preferences man page), and set up apt "preferences" to
cause your local builds to shadow the upstream archive or your local
mirror of the unmodified upstream packages.

Another cool feature of "dpkg" is "dpkg --get-selections >
dpkg-selections", "scp dpkg-selections otherbox", "ssh otherbox", "dpkg
--set-selections < dpkg-selections", "apt-get dselect-upgrade".  That
will duplicate the package set from one box to another.

> 3) although it's not that important to ME, personally, Debian is a 
> GNU/Linux Distribution - meaning it's free as in beer AND as in speech.
> 

Yes -- It's a shared resource pool for IT professionals.  It's our
toolkit, as per the GNU Manifesto.

> The above reasons are pretty much why I went from using RH exclusively 
> to now using Debian exclusively.  Dependencies are a major pain in the 
> arse, and although no package manager is *perfect*, apt and dpkg come 
> pretty close.
> 

It keeps getting better and better, doesn't it?  (got any good hat
recipes?)  I've not reinstalled "bittersweet" for FOUR or FIVE years
now.  She's been upgraded, in place, often without even a reboot, many
many times over the years.  I love the way that core packages, such as
Sendmail, are set up to minimize the service downtime.  When I upgrade
from one release of Sendmail to the next, the downtime averages in the
sub-minute range.  It has always been flawless, but I know that the
downgrade path is available when I need it provided I "dpkg-repack" or
keep a copy of the last version on hand. (a wise precaution in a
production environment).

> You might see how mature the apt-rpm (or somesuch) packages are 
> nowadays.  I tried it on my RH system before I converted to Debian, but 
> the functionality just wasn't there.
> 

Even if "apt-rpm" works, theres no way in hell that Red Hat is going to
be able to package as much software as you'll find in the Debian
distribution.  There are more libraries available for developers, more
games for the kids, more tools for the student and scientist in Debian
than in any other distribution.  And it supports the largest number of
hardware architectures relative to any other distribution.

The other thing is that "dpkg" has a richer feature set wrt package
dependency declaration and maintainer script functionality than RPM
does, or so I gather.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Jul 24 10:11:34 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 24 Jul 2002 10:11:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] debootstrap -- try Debian on your RPM based machines (are belong to
 us)
Message-ID: <1027530694.6196.64.camel@bittersweet>

There's an "rpm" of "debootstrap" in
http://people.pdxlinux.org/~karlheg/ if anyone would like to try it.  It
was converted from the Debian package to an rpm with "alien --to-rpm".

You can use "mc" (Midnight Commander) to browse inside of the RPM, or
use the rpm command that just unpacks it in your current directory, to
reassure yourself that it's not a trojan horse; that it's honestly just
what it says it is and no more.

"debootstrap" will install a Debian base system in a subdirectory.  It
will not affect anything outside of that subdirectory.  Once you've run
it, you can "cd DIR && chroot . && cd /" and work with Debian while
inside there.  You'll have access to "apt-get" and everything.

If you know how to create an empty loopback filesystem, you can mount it
and run the "debootstrap" in there, umount it, then use that loopback
filesystem to boot a User Mode Linux.  It works very well.

"debootstrap" requires only "bash", "wget" and "binutils".

Subject: [PLUG] PHP and Xemacs
In-Reply-To: <1027357045.25461.767.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
References: <1027357045.25461.767.camel@lana.manymoons.net>
Message-ID: <1027532787.13663.14.camel@bittersweet>

On Mon, 2002-07-22 at 09:57, Jon Jacob wrote:
> Does anyone here use php-mode in xemacs?  I used to have this working
> but took it out for some unknown reason, and now I can't get it back
> again.  
> 
> If anyone knows lisp or emacs well enough to help me with this, I would
> appreciate it.

I like "mmm-mode", which you can find if you look around a little on the
"http://www.masonhq.com/" site.  It gives you multiple major modes in
the same buffer.  You edit your template in psgml-mode as HTML, and the
PHP or Perl parts are in their own mode.

At http://people.pdxlinux.org/~karlheg/mmm=ext.el you'll find a simple
extension that makes mmm-mode work for php and embedded css stylesheets.

RTFM to learn how to make this work.

From dealy at deatech.com  Wed Jul 24 13:03:40 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 13:03:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Minimizing a Linux distribution (RH)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0207241235460.6873-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207241253420.4851-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Wed, 24 Jul 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> On Wed, 24 Jul 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
>
> > You might want to look into User-Mode Linux, that will allow you to setup
> > virtual Linux machines running on a Linux host for testing and other
> > purposes.  The latest version of Debian includes it in the distribution,
> > RedHat and others might also.
>
> I use vservers already but I'm trying to do the main server so I need a
> system I can really screw-up and just install/remove again.
[snip]

This is not the same as User-Mode Linux, UML creates a complete virtual
machine with virtual hard-drive, network, console, etc., and you can
even install different brands of Linux within the virtual machine,
regardless of what your host is running.  UML uses a patched version of
the stock linux kernel which runs as a program in user space, but when it
boots up, you are running an entirely separate instance of Linux using a
large file as a virtual hard drive.  There is also a special file system
that supports direct access to a directory tree on you local drive, but I
haven't tried it yet (I prefer complete separation between virtual
machines and host).  If you were at the PLUG meeting for my presentation
on virtual computing environments a few months ago, UML is the virtual
machine that I used to boot and run DOOM inside of an Xnest virtual
server.

> forwarding.
[snip]

One potential problem with this is that alot of these no cost email
accounts have severe mailbox size limitations, so if you don't check
your email very often, get alot of email, or receive some large
spams/viruses (a number of these I have received lately run up to 300k),
everything sent to you will start bouncing.  Probably be a good idea to
use a store and forward approach rather than just forwarding, so anything
you miss will still be in your mailbox when you get home.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jul 24 14:35:17 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

On Wed, 24 Jul 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> I realize you said RH, but here's my take on the Debian side of things.

Phew.  Shocked there weren't flames following this.  There are almost
always a few mules who bray every time someone responds with a Debian
solution.  Even (especially?) when it's exactly the right thing to
suggest.

> 1) it's much easier to keep your packages updated with cron-apt or a
> cron job that runs apt-get update ; apt-get upgrade
> 
> 2) removing packages (and finding dependency problems/issues) is as
> easy as apt-get remove [package].  If a package you want to remove has
> too many dependencies, it tells you just exactly what they are.  If it
> doesn't, bye-bye [package]
> 
> 3) although it's not that important to ME, personally, Debian is a 
> GNU/Linux Distribution - meaning it's free as in beer AND as in speech.

Those reasons are all quite good, though the third one doesn't really
relate to the reason he gave for using Red Hat.

When I hear or read someone use the phrase "RPM makes my life easier", I
realize they haven't ever used dpkg and the apt tools.

Anyway, it's also true that a base Debian install is MUCH smaller than a
base Red Hat installation (like, 50% with no real attempt to slim it
down).  Also, there is more flexibility at install-time in choosing which
packages get installed and which do not.

J.

I have a couple of other suggestions for this:

1. Some ISPs locally have partnerships with others through things like iPass
and other ways so that you can dial a local ISP wherever you end up. Some of
these partnerships are limited, you kind of have to call around.

2. Sign up with a place like Yahoo! to get your mail. They do offer a 'check
other mail' option and (as of now) you don't have to pay extra for it.

3. Sign up with a less evil ISP like Earthlink

Other than that, there might be other ways that you can do it, but those are
my suggestions based on tech support for the local ISP joints and answering
this exact question a lot of times.
