From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Jul 24 14:32:44 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 14:32:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] AOL substitute
In-Reply-To: <20020724201017.GC327@boora.com>
References: <20020724201017.GC327@boora.com>
Message-ID: <200207241432.44454.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I would guess that the larger dialup ISPs would have POPs all over the 
place. When my wife was doing some work for Boeing she was able to get 
a discounted account through GTE.net/Verizon.net. She still has the 
account and has dragged her laptop to various places around the country 
and has always found a local POP number. 

My wife uses Win98 but I've had a Linux system dial-in and connect to 
Version.net without any problems. I used the modem setup in YaST2 under 
SuSE and created multiple providers. With the modem setup, I get this 
little "plug" icon in the system panel of the KDE desktop once the 
modem and provider stuff was setup. Once the little "plug" thing is 
started, the modem automatically dials the specified provider that I 
have selected when outgoing packets are detected. 

If I right mouse-click in the "plug" icon when the connection is 
disconnected, I can change the provider being called. I think wvdial is 
used as part of this magic setup. I've gotten lazy over the years and 
am happy to set the modem stuff up using YaST2. In my old Slackware 
days I wrote shell scripts, chat scripts and used "diald" to get "pppd" 
to an automatic PPP connection when outgoing packets were detected.

The downside is even though the number is local, many hotels charge for 
local calls so it's not necessarily a free phone call. Maybe that's 
different with an 800 number being called from a hotel room. I guess 
too that if it's a single 800 number then setting things up is alot 
easier since multiple POP numbers are not required. I usually do some 
research and setup my wife's laptop before she leaves on a trip so the 
new POP numbers have been added to the dialup setup. Windows is pretty 
flexible here and multiple locations can be specified and profiles can 
be setup to dial 9 to get an outside line through the hotel's PBX 
system. I know I can do this in SuSE as well but the setup just isn't 
as easy as Windows IMHO.  

As long as an ISP supports connection via PPP without some other cruft 
software being run it should be possible to get Linux to connect. And 
as long as the mail servers support standard protocols like POP3, SMTP, 
and/or IMAP Linux shouldn't work. Probably the biggest hassle is 
getting the modem and dialup providers setup. I didn't think this was 
too bad with SuSE's YaST2 but it wasn't as easy as setting up an 
ethernet card IMHO.

Tony

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Wed Jul 24 15:06:41 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 15:06:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] AOL substitute
In-Reply-To: <20020724201017.GC327@boora.com>
References: <20020724201017.GC327@boora.com>
Message-ID: <20020724150641.3d27608d.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>

On Wed, 24 Jul 2002 13:10:18 -0700
"Michael Montagne" <montagne at boora.com> wrote:

> I have a friend who clings to MS because she needs AOL.  The reason
> she needs it is because she wants to have internet access when she
> travels the country.  At home she uses DSL but on the road she can
> dial an 800 number and access the web.  At a reasonable price even.
> Are there any OSS soloutions to this this issue?  Netzero does not
> support Linux.

This isn't an answer to your question, but it may help nonetheless.

You have a few options dealing with AOL under Linux.

1)  There's Wine.  It lets you dial up and 2.5 (likely 3.0 as well)
might get web access, but there is no external TCP/IP connectivity (ie;
external apps can't use the AOL connections).

2)  There's PengAOL.  A google search should bring it up.  It allows an
AOL connection to be made within Linux to give you *just* Internet
access... no access to AOL-only things.  It dropped out of active
development almost a year ago, but should still work fine.

3)  There's Gamera, the AOL Net Appliance client.  It may not be legal
to use, but it is still an option.  It works with only dialup to give
you a nearly full-blown AOL client.  I couldn't get it to use my modem
when I was in Mandrake oh-so-long-ago... but I didn't try very hard.  If
it helps, the Net Appliance itself uses a Conexant modem, so if the
Conexant kernel modules work funky (like only on a wierd com port) you
may need to do some symlinking in /dev  :-)

Hope this helps.

Rob

> especially the 3.x versions of g++.  There was an article in Dr. Dobb's a couple
> of months back where they ran language compliance tests with various C++
> compilers - the only two I recall were gcc and Micro$oft's compiler, but there
> were others in the mix.  The results of their tests showed that g++ was near the
> top in the language compliance department (in fact, if I recall correctly, of
> the compilers tested g++ was the most compliant), while Micro$oft's compiler was
> the worst.

Isn't it interesting that at PCC, at least a few years ago, I was told
that I cannot take a C++ class there and do the homework with the G++
compiler...  The textbook intro stated that the book taught only
ISO/ANSI standard C++.  Now if Microsoft's compiler, today, is more
non-compliant than G++ 3.0, then for certain it was at least as
non-compliant then.

Yes, in terms of standards compliance, VSC++ (not sure up to what
versions this is applicable, certainly 5 and probably 6, hopefully NOT
VS.NET) was just awful such things as

for (int i=0; i < some_num; ++i)
    do_something();
for (int i=0; i < other_num; ++i)
    do_something_else();

Would fail to compile because the scoping rules didn't fit the standard,
among other things (this is just one of the more frequent bugaboos you
encounter).

--Shahms

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Wed Jul 24 19:34:32 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 19:34:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lilo or Grub?
In-Reply-To: <1027563555.20741.2.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207241916090.25176-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> > I am doing a fresh install on a machine and setting up duel boot. Should I
> > use lilo or grub and why? Thanks.

The answer depends on your machine and what you plan on doing with it; if
you value flexibility or experimenting with different OSes and kernel
images try grub:

"GRUB, unlike LILO, is able to read filesystems and recognize kernel
images too. While LILO requires the physical location of the kernel on
your drive, GRUB does not. Even the latest filesystem ReiserFS is
supported. This means that you don't have to re-install GRUB every time
you make a change to the config file or install a new kernel. If your BIOS
supports LBA then there is also no problem reading beyond 1024 cylinders.
There's some good support for network booting of diskless clients."

http://www.freeos.com/articles/3482/

Also info at:

http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue64/kohli.html


--Tyler

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Jul 24 21:21:05 2002

Well since you already have a solution this isn't going to help you now 
but maybe in the future...I have a 2.4.18 kernel on my primary 
workstation and I'm able to download images from my Kodak digital 
camera via USB using "gphoto2". It would seem to me that USB support is 
pretty solid in newer versions of the Linux kernel. 

I was a bit skeptical since I had never used any USB devices with Linux 
before but I was pleasantly surprised when I pressed the button on my 
camera's dock and my system beeps, and I see message in the syslog that 
shows that the hotplug stuff detected my camera. I even managed to get 
the hotplug stuff configured so I don't have to be root to access my 
camera through the USB port.

I admit I don't have any experience with a USB card since my mobo has 
USB ports on it already.

Tony

From revans at e-z.net  Wed Jul 24 22:49:09 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 2002 22:49:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] MySQL connection monitoring
In-Reply-To: <3D3F1A65.611C2CF4@truedisk.com>
References: <3D3F1A65.611C2CF4@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <20020725054242.RZNG1451.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>

I thought this was an interesting question so I added what I found out. 


mysqladmin extended-status | grep nect
| Aborted_connects         | 0      |
| Connections              | 16     |
| Max_used_connections     | 1      |
| Threads_connected        | 2      |

Connections
Number of connection attempts to the MySQL server.

Aborted_connects
The server variable Aborted_connects is incremented when:
When a connection packet doesn't contain the right information.
When the user didn't have privileges to connect to a database.
When a user uses a wrong password.
When it takes more than connect_timeout seconds to get a connect package

Max_used_connections
The maximum number of connections in use simultaneously.

Thank you
Russell

>  number of connections currently in use?

Subject: [PLUG] power hit... am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <20020724232617.A27582@aracnet.com>

On Wed, 24 Jul 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:
> The power failed while I was a work today. Fat lot of good the UPS did. I
> tried rebooting my P-Pro S 200 (SMP) and it panics...
> 
> VFS: Cannot open root device "hda3" or 03:03
> Please append a correct "root=" boot option
> Kernel panic: VFS: Unable to mount root fs on 03:03

OK, so this says it can't mount the root filesystem.

> So, then I tried booting into single user mode from (what I believe is) a
> good boot floppy, and it bombs out with...

A single boot floppy?  Was this something like your distribution's "rescue
disk" or was this a single floppy system like Tom's Root Boot or similar
microdistribution?

If it's a rescue disk, it's just a kernel.  You'll still need to mount a
root filesystem to get your basic utilities like init, login, and a shell,
not to mention fsck.

> <lotsa stuff>
> hde:hde lost interrupt
> hde: lost interrupt
> hde: lost interrupt
> ide_dmsproc: chipset support ide_dms_lostirq func only 13:
> <more stuff>
> Kernel panic: No init found. Try passing init= option to kernel.

Well, if you can't mount the filesystem, you can't get to init, can you?

(Is that earlier stuff a result of not having dma support in the floppy's
kernel?)

> I (of course, *sigh*) don't have a backup - and can't afford to lose
> /var (it's my web server). It's running (or was) RH7.2 - which didn't
> have ATA100 support in 2.4.2. I had to finagle the bagel to load it on
> my Maxtor by attaching the drive to the onboard controller, then
> making and booting into 2.4.17 and then connecting the drive to the
> Promise controller. I've also got the media for RH7.3. I'm wondering
> if I create a boot floppy for it (the CD-ROM isn't bootable on this
> box) if I'd be able to simply do an upgrade. I'd prefer to get the
> system back up as it was and do the upgrade as a planned exercise.
> 
> I welcome any and all help here.

OK, any and all.  Hear me out before you dismiss this.

I'm not terribly familiar with all the various boot floppy options out
there, so I'll tell you what I'd do in such a pinch.

Hopefully you have a working system on which to do this.

Download the first two Debian install floppies (don't worry, I'm not
telling you to reinstall anything):

<URL: http://http.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/rescue.bin >
<URL: http://http.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/root.bin >

dd if=root.bin of=/dev/fd0 bs=512; sync
[swap floppies]
dd if=rescue.bin of=/dev/fd0 bs=512; sync

OK, now boot the broken system with the Rescue floppy.  When it asks for
the Root floppy, feed it that.

Hit enter at the prompt (I know, it says you're going to install something
or lose data, but you won't if you don't actually try).

When you get the Welcome! splash screen (curses interface), hit ALT+F2 and
hit enter to activate the virtual console.

>From there, you can fsck your drives and attempt to repair the
filesystems.

When you're done, just make sure the drives are unmounted, pop out the
floppy, and reboot the system normally.

Anyway, that's what I'd do.
J.

From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Jul 25 05:13:14 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 25 Jul 2002 05:13:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] power hit... am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <20020724232617.A27582@aracnet.com>
References: <20020724232617.A27582@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1027599195.13043.4248.camel@red>

On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 23:26, Sandy Herring wrote:
> The power failed while I was a work today. Fat lot of good the UPS did.

A UPS will not help when the power outage is longer than your
battery reserves and you've not setup your system for power fail.
You need to connect your UPS to your computer with a signal cable,
run a power fail daemon (such as powerd), and check the power
fail settings in your /etc/inittab file.

Putting /var on a separate partition formatted with ext3 or Reiserfs
is also a good idea.

Ed

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jul 25 06:30:40 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 06:30:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] USB <-> serial converter?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0207241944140.22984-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207250621560.24448-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 24 Jul 2002, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:

> There are USB-serial adapters for mice, I could never get them to
> work, the PC just does not see the mouse.

I've had mixed luck with the one USB -> serial adapter with which I've 
had experience, a Belkin F5U103. Greg K-H would, of course, be the 
expert on the subject (hey, Greg -- I see you're now a Linux Journal 
columnist; way to go!).

Our problem is that if the mouse is plugged into the USB-serial port,
everything works OK -- unless something is also plugged into the
native serial port; at that point, the USB-serial mouse disappears. 
Oddly, if the mouse is plugged into the native serial port, other 
serial devices can co-exist on the USB-serial port. I'm not sure why 
mice have such a hard time in that environment.

IOW, my experience is that only a hands-on test will tell you whether 
or not a USB-serial adapter will successfully host your cradling 
device.

Plus, you'll want to make sure that your kernel is relatively recent, 
since USB support gains ground with every release.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Kyle,

  The configuration of the default cradle has a wire from the cradle to a
USB connector. There's a small power brick that plugs into the rear of the
USB connector so the charging juice comes from the wall outlet, not the
computer.

  My Kyocera QCP-6035 (Palm/cell phone) has a serial cradle with two wires
coming out the back: one goes to the computer's serial port for syncing, the
other to a small power brick for charging. So, the technology is proven and
Handspring could have offered that as a no-cost option if they cared.

> > I (of course, *sigh*) don't have a backup - and can't afford to lose

> > system back up as it was and do the upgrade as a planned exercise.

> OK, any and all.  Hear me out before you dismiss this.
> 
> I'm not terribly familiar with all the various boot floppy options out
> there, so I'll tell you what I'd do in such a pinch.
> 
> Hopefully you have a working system on which to do this.
> 
> Download the first two Debian install floppies (don't worry, I'm not
> telling you to reinstall anything):
> 
> <URL: http://http.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/rescue.bin >
> <URL: http://http.us.debian.org/debian/dists/stable/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/root.bin >
> 
> dd if=root.bin of=/dev/fd0 bs=512; sync
> [swap floppies]
> dd if=rescue.bin of=/dev/fd0 bs=512; sync
> 
> OK, now boot the broken system with the Rescue floppy.  When it asks for
> the Root floppy, feed it that.
> 
> Hit enter at the prompt (I know, it says you're going to install something
> or lose data, but you won't if you don't actually try).
> 
> When you get the Welcome! splash screen (curses interface), hit ALT+F2 and
> hit enter to activate the virtual console.
> 
> >From there, you can fsck your drives and attempt to repair the
> filesystems.
> 
> When you're done, just make sure the drives are unmounted, pop out the
> floppy, and reboot the system normally.
> 
> Anyway, that's what I'd do.
> J.
> -- 
>    -----------------
>      Jeme A Brelin
>     jeme at brelin.net
>    -----------------
>  [cc] counter-copyright
>  http://www.openlaw.org

> A UPS will not help when the power outage is longer than your
> battery reserves and you've not setup your system for power fail.

> fail settings in your /etc/inittab file.

What it looks like to me is that whatever boot floppy or kernel you are 
using to boot with does NOT have the ata-100 driver (promise?) 
installed.  I've gone through the exact same issues, and what saved my 
bacon was finding a boot floppy image with the drivers I needed.

I'm not sure if the images that Jeme pointed you to have those - I 
haven't created a 'current' set of boot floppies in a while - but I'm 
sure the RH7.3 disks have an image you could use at the very least.

I would try that before giving up the ghost and reinstalling with new 
hardware.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Jul 25 09:54:23 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 25 Jul 2002 09:54:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: SquidGard Does not Block
Message-ID: <1027616074.25312.59.camel@pookie>

Excerpt from the SquidGaurd FAQ:

squidGuard does not block? 

    There my be at least 2 reasons for this: 
    
    You didn't end your pass rules with "none". Pass rules ends with an
    implicit "all". It is good practice to allways en the pass rules
    with either "all" or "none" to make them clear. Ie. use: 
    pass good none
    or 
    pass good !bad all
    squidGuard goes into emergency mode. Reasons may be syntax errors in
    the config file, reference to non existing database files,
    filprotection problems or missing directories. Check the squidGuard
    log. 
    Note:When run under Squid, squidGuard is run with the same user and
    group ID as Squid (cache_effective_user and  cache_effective_group
    in squid.conf). The squidGuard configuration and database files must
    be readable for this user and/or group and the squidGuard log
    directory must be writable for this user and/or group. If not
    squidGuard will go into the "pass all for all" emergency mode.
--

From chgenly at naturalmessaging.com  Thu Jul 25 09:01:06 2002
From: chgenly at naturalmessaging.com (Chris Genly)

Subject: [PLUG] lilo or Grub?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207241916090.25176-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207241916090.25176-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1027612867.4151.3.camel@songoda>

An odd difference that is sometimes important to me.  You can switch OSs
remotely with LILO.  I haven't found a way to do that in GRUB.

VNC in to my work machine.  While the work machine is in Linux

 lilo -R windows  
 reboot

The -R tells lilo to boot in to windows only once.  After that it
uses the default boot.  So with the above, the work machine reboots
in to windows.  Where VNC is again running.   When done with windows,
I just reboot and it comes back to Linux.

Can grub do this?

Chris



On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 19:34, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> > > I am doing a fresh install on a machine and setting up duel boot. Should I
> > > use lilo or grub and why? Thanks.
> 
> The answer depends on your machine and what you plan on doing with it; if
> you value flexibility or experimenting with different OSes and kernel
> images try grub:
> 
> "GRUB, unlike LILO, is able to read filesystems and recognize kernel
> images too. While LILO requires the physical location of the kernel on
> your drive, GRUB does not. Even the latest filesystem ReiserFS is
> supported. This means that you don't have to re-install GRUB every time
> you make a change to the config file or install a new kernel. If your BIOS
> supports LBA then there is also no problem reading beyond 1024 cylinders.
> There's some good support for network booting of diskless clients."
> 
> http://www.freeos.com/articles/3482/
> 
> Also info at:
> 
> http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue64/kohli.html
> 
> 
> --Tyler
> 
> 
>  On 24 Jul 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> 
> > On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 18:25, Neil wrote:
> >
> > > I am doing a fresh install on a machine and setting up duel boot. Should I
> > > use lilo or grub and why? Thanks.
> >
> > vi or emacs?  pico or nano?  Chevy or Ford?  AMD or Intel?  :-)
> >
> > I like lilo.  It's tried and true.  However, I'd go with whatever the
> > distro you're installing defaults to.  It makes life easier down the
> > road.  They should both be able to dual boot your system.  I've done
> > multiboots with both.
> >
> > --

Well, are you able to boot from floppy and mount any of the filesystems
on the drive?  The debian boot disk should be able to do that, a
Slackware 8.0 boot/root combo should be able to do that (as would an 8.1
but it's six disks for boot/root)... or Tom's mini distro disk
thingimibob that's out there should be able to do that.

>From there I wonder if you could chroot yourself into your disk and
compile yerself a new kernel (or use a [bleh!] precompiled kernel) and
maybe re-initialize Grub (or install lilo, I like lilo, although I've
seen many advantages of booting with grub) to be sure the MBR is doing
good.

That's if your kernel has gone bad.  If it's a bad filesystem, then you
just try and fix it good enough to boot again (get yourself a new
kernel?)...

But then, I've never dealt with a dead filesystem before, so y'all are
probably more adept at this stuff than I.  It's hard to tell what to do
when you aren't *actually there*.  :-)

> 
> <detects Ultra 100TX2 controller>
> hda: CD-ROM <etc>
> hde: MAXTOR GL040J2 ATA DISK drive
> 
> Partition check:
>  hde: hde1 hde2 hde3 hde4 <hde5 hde6 hde7 hde8>

Since it is trying to read the root file system from hda3, why not
unplug your cd-rom and plug the maxtor into that controller (I'm
assuming that your root is on the 3rd partition)?  It looks like GRUB
lost the ide=reverse kernel option.  (I think there are advantages to
having the kernel options stored in the boot record, lilo style.)

> post-lilo grub install...mine never seemed to work, no matter what I 
> tried.  New kernels wouldn't load after reboot, and I once got the 
> dreaded LI after POST.

You didn't do it right.

If you still see LI, that means that you never installed Grub's MBR
(master boot record) program.  Lilo's is still there and cannot find the
rest of LILO where it used to find it.

I've had trouble in the past with "grub-install", and have learned to do
it "by hand", like this:

cd /boot
mkdir grub
cd grub
cp /usr/lib/grub/i386-pc/* .
grub

 Ok, now I'm in the grub shell, hopefully.

Let's say that /boot resides on /dev/hda1.  Here's what I type to
install grub:

grub> setup (hd0) (hd0,0)

... output here ...

grub> quit

Now it should reboot to a grub shell, unless I've created a 
"/boot/grub/menu.lst".  Also, if your "/boot" is on it's own partition;
that is, "/boot" is a mount point, then you also must do:

cd /boot
ln -s . boot

... to get Grub to find the menu.lst file.

Please read the grub texinfo documentation (info grub) from cover to
cover before attempting this procedure.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul 25 11:55:31 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 11:55:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lilo or Grub?
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020725111525.019ecdd0@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207251148510.19497-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 25 Jul 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> At 09:01 AM 7/25/2002 -0700, you wrote:
> >You can switch OSs
> >remotely with LILO.  I haven't found a way to do that in GRUB.
> 
> How do you do that?

He actually described it exactly in the same email you quoted here.

> I'd think it would be changing the default OS in the conf file, which
> you can do with grub as well.

No, that is pointless because you don't necessarily have access to the
configuration file to get BACK after the switch.

With LILO, you simply pass the -R switch and tell LILO which stanza in the
lilo.conf should be used for the NEXT boot.  When you reboot, lilo will
then use the options from that stanza and then revert to the default
configuration.

So, in the case the original poster described, you are using GNU/Linux
with a MS Windows partition on the same system and lilo is configured to
boot the first by default and the second by a stanza titled "windows".

You can be connected to the GNU/Linux system via ssh or vnc or whatever,
type `lilo -R windows` at a root prompt, then reboot the system.

When the system boots, it will use the "windows" section of lilo.conf and
then revert to the usual default setting.  The system boots into MS
Windows (where this fellow is also running VNC).  When the system is
rebooted (via VNC or whatever), then it boots normally with the GNU/Linux
system as default.

Very handy, I would think, for folks with multi-boot systems.

I'd be kind of shocked if grub didn't do this and folks still claimed it's
superior.

J.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jul 25 11:56:56 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 11:56:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] power hit... am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <1027599195.13043.4248.camel@red>
References: <20020724232617.A27582@aracnet.com> <1027599195.13043.4248.camel@red>
Message-ID: <200207251156.56773.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Yep I went through great efforts to avoid paying $40.00 a pop from APC 
for signaling cables for my BackUPS units. I made my own for a couple 
dollars in parts from a second-hand electronic. I also put together a 
monitoring daemon based-on code from the UPS-HOW that works with the 
dumb APC BackUPS units.

The daemon signals when the power goes out and when the power is 
restored assuming the system is still up. I'm real conservative so I 
don't drain the battery to low and use a 2 minute timed shutdown that 
shuts a system down if the power isn't restored. If the power is 
restored before the shutdown commences the shutdown is canceled. So far 
this setup has worked pretty well since most timess the power goes out 
for a few seconds or has a momentary sag so the shutdown is canceled 
and the system continues to run.

I also had a Tripp-Lite unit from Costco that also included a signaling 
cable and monitoring software for Linux but there was some problem with 
the charging of the battery. After a few weeks there was a noticable 
bubbling sound, burning smell, and finally a whistling sound like gas 
was venting from the battery or something. The fault light also came on 
the unit and so back to Costco it went. After after leaving Costco I 
headed to my favorite computer store with my return money and ordered a 
more expernsive APC SmartUPS unit.

The APC SmartUPS unit I got included the signaling cable and also a 
version of APC's Powerchute software that even had a version for Linux 
on the CD. I got a newer version of PowerChute off of APC's website.

Tony

On Thursday 25 July 2002 05:13 am, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 23:26, Sandy Herring wrote:
> > The power failed while I was a work today. Fat lot of good the UPS
> > did.
>
> A UPS will not help when the power outage is longer than your
> battery reserves and you've not setup your system for power fail.
> You need to connect your UPS to your computer with a signal cable,
> run a power fail daemon (such as powerd), and check the power
> fail settings in your /etc/inittab file.
>
> Putting /var on a separate partition formatted with ext3 or Reiserfs
> is also a good idea.
>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jul 25 12:58:15 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 12:58:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lilo or Grub?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207251148510.19497-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207251238550.24699-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 25 Jul 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> You can be connected to the GNU/Linux system via ssh or vnc or
> whatever, type `lilo -R windows` at a root prompt, then reboot the
> system.
> 
> When the system boots, it will use the "windows" section of lilo.conf and
> then revert to the usual default setting.  The system boots into MS
> Windows (where this fellow is also running VNC).  When the system is
> rebooted (via VNC or whatever), then it boots normally with the GNU/Linux
> system as default.
> 
> Very handy, I would think, for folks with multi-boot systems.

I don't think grub provides any direct analog to 'lilo -R'; the 
closest thing is a simple swapping of the 'default' directive in 
grub.conf, but it's not really the same thing since the setting would 
remain in force even after the first reboot.

> I'd be kind of shocked if grub didn't do this and folks still
> claimed it's superior.

Without making any claims of superiority for grub vis-a-vis lilo, it's 
worth mentioning what grub can do that lilo (afaik) can't:

* hide partitions from this or that operating system
* grab a boot image off the network via tftp
* provide a fallback kernel
* pause to prompt user to do something (e.g., insert a floppy) during
  the boot process
* store bootloader password in strong (md5) crypto format and prompt 
  for password at place of your choosing
* allow user to alter kernel parameters at boot time
* allow kernels to be represented in boot menu by titles of arbitrary
  length, including whitespace

This isn't meant to disparage lilo in any way; it served me well for 
many years.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Thu Jul 25 14:03:07 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 14:03:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] lilo or Grub?
In-Reply-To: <1027612867.4151.3.camel@songoda> (message from Chris Genly on 25
	Jul 2002 09:01:06 -0700)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207241916090.25176-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <1027612867.4151.3.camel@songoda>
Message-ID: <20020725210307.666A410E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

Somebody, I think Tyler F. Creelan, worte:
> "GRUB, unlike LILO, is able to read filesystems and recognize kernel
> images too. While LILO requires the physical location of the kernel on
> your drive, GRUB does not. Even the latest filesystem ReiserFS is
> supported. This means that you don't have to re-install GRUB every time
> you make a change to the config file or install a new kernel. 

This may be a bit mis-leading to the beginner.
"Installation" here means typing "lilo" at the (root) command prompt,
which re-"installs" the loader into the boot track at the head of
the disk, or partition.


It's not like you're installing the gcc compiler from source.

So I would not base my decision on GRUB vs LILO on this alone (which
you were not).

Dean

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Thu Jul 25 18:28:51 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 25 Jul 2002 18:28:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Change monitor - how to start text mode at start
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726085831.02af88e0@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726085831.02af88e0@pop.net-yan.com>

On Thu, 2002-07-25 at 17:59, Stephen Liu wrote:
> Hi All Guys,
> 
> Re-change of monitor
> 
> My problem is I could not read the screen to start Xconfigurator after 
> starting RH 7.3.  It automatically enters the Login screen in graphic mode. 
> I forgot the command how to start the text mode (init 3) at starting the PC.
> 
> Could any guy shed me some light.  Thanks in advance.

Edit /etc/inittab... you want to change the line that says

id:4:initdefault:

to say

id:3:initdefault:

(or something else if you want a different default)

Hope this helps!

Rob
"Google is your friend"




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jul 25 18:24:12 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 18:24:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Change monitor - how to start text mode at start
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726085831.02af88e0@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726085831.02af88e0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <200207251824.12091.aschlemm@attbi.com>

You can do a <CTRL>-<ALT<-<F1> to get to a text console, login and root 
and then place the system into runlevel 3 by running the command:

"init 3". 

You can also edit your systems /etc/inittab file and change the default 
runlevel. You should see a line similar to below. Change the 5 to a 3 
and your system will default to runlevel 3 rather than 5:

# default runlevel
id:5:initdefault:

Tony

Rich,

I don't necessarily think that Windows/Microsoft based servers running open 
relay.  For example I have been recently using xmail (www.xmailserver.org), a 
somewhat popular cross-platform mail server.  By default it is open relay, 
and the documentation doesn't specifically state how to turn it off.  I had 
to ask around before I found out that in order to turn off open relay you 
have to restrict relay capabilities to your location range in a config file.  
This seems like a rather roundabout way of doing it IMHO, and it's not well 
documented that this is the correct way to turn relay off.

Regards,
Jim Adams

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jul 25 23:26:57 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 23:26:57 -0700 (PDT)

On Thu, 25 Jul 2002, Jim Adams wrote:
> I had to ask around before I found out that in order to turn off open
> relay you have to restrict relay capabilities to your location range
> in a config file.  This seems like a rather roundabout way of doing it
> IMHO, and it's not well documented that this is the correct way to
> turn relay off.

How ELSE would you do it?

What we call an "open relay" is just a system that relays mail regardless
of source.  Unless you specify somewhere the systems to which you'd like
to restrict relay capabilities, you're on open relay.  If the system
DOESN'T allow relay from some sources, then it is just a local mail
agent... what good is that on the internet?

J.

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Jul 25 23:55:05 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 25 Jul 2002 23:55:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mouse horizontal scrolling - how to edit XF86 Config file
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726083326.00b6ba88@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020726083326.00b6ba88@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <20020726064828.FIKH1451.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@dhcp-279-190>

I removed some parts of the original. I'm to lazy to paraphrase.

Thank you
Russell 

http://www.xfree86.org/4.2.0/mouse5.html#23   
-----------------------------------------------------

Option"ZAxisMapping""N1 N2 N3 N4"

For a mouse with two wheels, of which, the second wheel is used to generate
horizontal scroll action, and the mouse which has a knob or a stick which can
detect the horizontal force applied by the user. The motion of the second wheel
will be mapped to the buttons N3, for the negative direction, and N4, for the
positive direction. If the buttons N3 and N4 actually exist in this mouse,
their actions won't be detected by the X server.

NOTE #1: horizontal movement may not always be detected by the current version
of the XFree86 X servers, because there appears to be no accepted standard as
to how the horizontal direction is encoded in mouse data.

NOTE #2: Some mice think left is the negative horizontal direction, others may
think otherwise. Moreover, there are some mice whose two wheels are both
mounted vertically, and the direction of the second vertical wheel does not
match the first one's.

Currently this option can not be set in the XF86Setup program. You need to edit
the XF86Config file by hand to add this option.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Jul 26 08:56:24 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 08:56:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Open relays for spammers
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0207252324430.25524-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <1027665260.8097.78.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3D417128.8050707@sun.com>

When I set up my first linux server - RedHat 5.2 - Sendmail was 
configured, BY DEFAULT, to relay mail from *anywhere*.  Only when I 
recieved a peice of spam that seemed to come from my own box did I 
realize what was wrong and took steps to correct it.

About a year ago, there was someone from Russia asking for linux 
distribution donations here on this list.  Some of the donated 
distributions could have been configured just as mine had been, and as 
someone else mentioned, the howto's are generally written in english, 
not russian.  Perhaps all of the open relays are simply older 
distributions with insecure default mail configurations?

I can easily imagine a newbie doing just this and then forgetting about 
it...  Especially if they have an ISP they use for mail and don't bother 
with the imap/pop services their new server has available for them.

Thankfully, the distribution creators figured this out and fixed it in 
the newer versions.  At least...I HOPE they have.  We can only hope that 
some of these relays eventually upgrade, and the configuration problems 
they had 'go away'.  Of course, that would be in a near-perfect world.  ;)

-R

Russell Evans wrote:
> 
> I thought this was an interesting question so I added what I found out.
> 
> mysqladmin extended-status | grep nect
> | Aborted_connects         | 0      |
> | Connections              | 16     |
> | Max_used_connections     | 1      |
> | Threads_connected        | 2      |
> 
> Connections
>   Number of connection attempts to the MySQL server.
> 
> Aborted_connects
>   The server variable Aborted_connects is incremented when:
>   When a connection packet doesn't contain the right information.
>   When the user didn't have privileges to connect to a database.
>   When a user uses a wrong password.
>   When it takes more than connect_timeout seconds to get a connect package
> 
> Max_used_connections
>   The maximum number of connections in use simultaneously.
>

> Russell

Well since I saw this question earlier and no one has responded to
either, I'll take a shot.  I'm going to venture a guess and say that it
is, at the moment, not possible.  Sadly, X typically only supports up to
5 mouse buttons, which is just fine for your typical wheeled mice (1,2,3
4 and 5 are bound to the wheel), but those of us with other mice, say
the A4 Tech or my own Logitech MouseMan+ (with the thumb button) are
SOL.  You may be able to hack it using the XInput drivers rather than
the usual mouse driver, but I wouldn't know where to begin or even if
it's worth investigating.

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Fri Jul 26 09:29:49 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 09:29:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Open relays for spammers
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA24F@exchange.ci.albany.or.us>

As long as we're talking about issues contributing to open relays, look at
older versions of MS mail servers.

FWIW, not so long ago the Internet Messaging Service (or
whateverthehelltheycalledit) on Exchange didn't even have the capability of
controlling relays.  It was an open relay by default AND THERE WAS NO OPTION
TO CHANGE IT.  (At least nowhere in the standard configuration tools.)  What
a crock.  5.5 eventually put out a service pack giving you that kind of
control.  Probably because their customers were complaining about being put
in "black hole" listings. :)

To make matters worse, you couldn't find the word "relay" in documentation
anywhere... not even the index.  All third-party big-buck manuals I saw had
the same problem.  Actually, even the most recent 5 inch thick Exchange 2000
book I've seen didn't even have the term relay in the index.  To figure out
how to manage relaying, you had to piece together information from many
different places.  (Of course, using unintuitive MS terminology and trying
to guess what actually constitutes "relaying".)

No wonder there are so many open relays... in the MS world at least, "relay"
often barely even shows up in the lexicon.

And they have the gall to claim it is an email server. If you ask me, it's a

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 26 11:36:01 2002

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207261117160.2621-100000@critter.deatech.com>

I've been trying to determine why some packets are going back and forth
across my internet links, and find I need some information that I can't
seem to find an easy way to acquire.  Before I resort to writing software,
does anyone know of a way to track which process (or even user id) last
used a given port (primarily udp and tcp).  The problem is that I'll see a
packet go out from a dynamically allocated port, but once the transaction
completes (in well under a second), the port is freed, so I have no way of
telling what process/user was generating the packets.  Packet sniffers and
iplogger are helpful, but don't appear to provide a means of connecting
the packets back to the source process/program on the local system, or did
I miss something?

Anyone got any ideas?

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 26 11:49:32 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 11:49:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printer Job Splitting
In-Reply-To: <054801c234c3$ed855300$6501a8c0@jeremyb>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207261138590.2672-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 26 Jul 2002, Jeremy Bowen wrote:

> Hello Everyone!
>
> I have searched all around nut I have not bee able to find job splitting
> software for printing.
>
> I want to have a linux box that is a print server and run samba to connect
> my windoze boxes and be able to break up a large mail merge (or other lare
> jod) over more than one printer.
>
> Do a program like this exist?

You might be looking in the wrong place, it's been awhile since I've seen
this, but some print servers allow you to define a single printer frontend
to a group of printers, so if you send multiple jobs to the "printer" it
will split them between the actual printers.  Of course if your mail
merge (or other program) won't allow you to do the merge as multiple
individual print jobs, this won't help, but all of the programs I can
recall using do allow this (I did it with OpenOffice two weeks ago).  I
always run merges as individual print jobs in case a problem develops,
that way only the current piece is messed up, rather than the rest of the
merge.

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Fri Jul 26 11:04:53 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 11:04:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Open relays for spammers
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA252@exchange.ci.albany.or.us>

I just remember how flabbergasted I was when a person running an Exchange
server asked me if I knew any reasons some emails were being bounced back,
and if I knew what RTBL meant.

"You mean that mail server is an open relay?!"

"Huh?"

"Let's go fix this, shall we?"  *Poke and prod icky server*  "OMG, there's
not even an option to turn it off!" *Dumbfounded look on face*  "I can't
believe they shipped something like this.  Well, maybe I can... but I still
don't believe this!"

It was fixed long ago, as soon as it was possible to do so.  But it still
gives me the heebie-jeebies.

Speaking of relays, now there is a different problem with it... there is now
an internal server that it *should* relay for.  And is configured to relay
for (by IP under "Hosts and clients with these IP addresses")... but it
doesn't.  (I've read those docs before, and looked it over.  It does look
like it is set up right, but it certainly doesn't work.  Looked at it via
telnet from that server, and it is rejected.  "Relay not allowed or
whatever".  Figures. :)

They're not suprised at all, but don't want to mess with it until they get
the Exchange 2000 server up and everything hunky-dory.  Of course there is
no-such-thing as a non-Exchange email server to some persons.  So in the
meantime I don't get my relay.  *sigh*.

I don't trust Exchange as far as I can throw it.  I'm no wimp, but it IS a
very big machine. :)

Jeremy

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 26 13:03:38 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 13:03:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Ports and Processes
Message-ID: <70028147.1027714130614.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Shannon:

If you're quick, you might be able to get an lsof listing to show you the
offending program.  Since your program completes so quickly, this will
just be a matter of luck on getting lsof to be running when the program
opens its connection.  I find that a nice "while true" loop does a decent
job, though it's kind of hard on the system.

If you can afford to disrupt the traffic, an invalid static route for the
destination of those mystery packets sometimes helps hold the connection
open long enough for lsof to collect the information.  (I.e. the packet
gets dropped and the TCP connection needs to time out, keeping it open
longer than if it completed successfully.)

The other option (which is *way* more hackerly) would be to modify the
tcp_output.c portion of the kernel to log all connect() calls and build a
new tcp-logging kernel.  This is probably best done from the console.  
;-)  The hard part would be figuring out how to get access to the calling
program's process table structures from within the TCP kernel code.

Good luck!

  -- Steve

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jul 26 15:04:02 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 15:04:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Occasional HD Activity
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207261456340.1667-100000@localhost.localdomain>

I just got a new (er, used) computer: dual P-III, SCSI 160, .5GB RAM 
-- much more powerful than my old Celeron 333 (not that I really need 
all that power :-).

It's got an IBM 36GB drive that has one odd feature: every once in a 
while, it makes a mild squealing noise for 3 to 4 seconds:

* the activity light doesn't flash during that period
* it seems to happen only when the system is idle
* it seems completely unrelated to OS activity since it happened
  once while I was doing stuff in the BIOS setup menus

Someone off-list suggested it might happen because the drive is 
programmed to sweep its platters every so often just so no crud ends 
up on them.

Has anyone heard of this?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From eli.stair.lists at attbi.com  Fri Jul 26 12:14:35 2002

Lots of older SCSI drives thermally recalibrate frequently, that's 
probably what it is.  Nothing to worry about (unless you could cook
and egg on it...).  I haven't seen a newer one do it in a few years,
but it's not surprising.  The bigger and faster, the louder.

/eli

From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Fri Jul 26 15:27:47 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 15:27:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Ports and Processes
In-Reply-To: <87ofcugnjc.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207261525090.974-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I don't know how well it will work but one way to get this in a loop is
with the watch command.

watch -n 0 netstat --tcp --udp -lp >> logfile

It will run watch pretty fast, but slowenough that it doesn't take over
you CPU completely...Or if you want to watch the output as it happens
there is a nice command tee.

watch -n 0 netstat --tcp --udp -lp | tee logfile.

Note: I didn't test them so I can't gaurantee they work.

Jason

Or for even less overhead and disk usage, create a FIFO, and read from that
continuously.  You could then include/exclude  whatever you want, grep for
the PID of the program, look up the owner of the process, have it return that
and the terminal they logged in on.  

/eli

From cbrown at woods.net  Fri Jul 26 15:57:24 2002

> can't offer an example but I swear there is an option to log activity.
> In fact I just checked and see a --log option.  I've never tried it but it
> has been offered as a solution to me.  (Turned out my problem was PEBKAC

If you can define the traffic enough to identify it, I assume you can
filter for it.  It is simple enough to use tcpdump writing raw traffic
to a file (just make sure to increase snaplen enough to get the
*whole* packet w/ payload, not just the header).
If nothing else you can do a raw of all traffic on that interface.


Even assuming it is a raw TCP session examining the payload should
give you a good idea of the application.  Reconstructing the full
bi-dir stream even more.


As mentioned in the thread, the BSD accounting option in the kernel
would be useful.  grab the tools, and you get a nice timestamped log
of every proc including name, uid, walltime, cpu timer, etc.  That
compared with timestamped tcpdump logs...

 -- I route, therefore you are.

Subject: [PLUG] Printer Job Splitting
In-Reply-To: <054801c234c3$ed855300$6501a8c0@jeremyb>

On Fri, 26 Jul 2002, Jeremy Bowen wrote:

> Hello Everyone!
>
> I have searched all around nut I have not bee able to find job splitting
> software for printing.
>
> I want to have a linux box that is a print server and run samba to connect
> my windoze boxes and be able to break up a large mail merge (or other lare
> jod) over more than one printer.
>
> Do a program like this exist?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Jeremy



By the time the print job is sent from the windows station to and
queued for printing on the SAMBA server the job is already in printer
specific binary format (assuming it is not a native postscript
printer).  The split *must* be done *before* job submission, after
submission it has already been paginated and converted.

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jul 26 17:35:12 2002

On Fri, 26 Jul 2002, Alot of different people wrote :-)

With heavy snippage & rearrangement

Since there was a great deal of overlap, I decided to respond to all at
once.

> If you're quick, you might be able to get an lsof listing to show you the
> offending program.  Since your program completes so quickly, this will
> ====
>  Why not run "netstat --tcp --udp -lp >> logfile" in a loop?
> ====
> watch -n 0 netstat --tcp --udp -lp >> logfile
> watch -n 0 netstat --tcp --udp -lp | tee logfile.
> ====
> Or for even less overhead and disk usage, create a FIFO, and read from  that
> continuously.  You could then include/exclude  whatever you want, grep  for
> the PID of the program, look up the owner of the process, have it return that
> and the terminal they logged in on.

This approach would have worked for the latest irritation that I was
trying to track down, because the problem was occuring multiple times per
minute, and while it had occurred to me to try this, it most likely will
not work for another problem I have been trying to track down because it
only once every few hours for a day or so, then goes away (sometimes for
weeks), then shows up again.  Basically this loop approach is a
statistical method, eventually things will time out so that you capture
one, but, I'm trying to find a general solution that will work for the
rare packets as well.  I say this would have worked, because after
several days of irritation, the problem went away (more on that below)
before I could capture it.

> If you can afford to disrupt the traffic, an invalid static route for the
> destination of those mystery packets sometimes helps hold the connection
> open long enough for lsof to collect the information.  (I.e. the packet
> gets dropped and the TCP connection needs to time out, keeping it open
> longer than if it completed successfully.)

This is one that hadn't occurred to me, I'll have to give it a try.

> The other option (which is *way* more hackerly) would be to modify the
> tcp_output.c portion of the kernel to log all connect() calls and build a
> new tcp-logging kernel.  This is probably best done from the console.
> ;-)  The hard part would be figuring out how to get access to the calling
> program's process table structures from within the TCP kernel code.

Given what I do for a living, I'm more than up to the "way more hackerly"
aspect, but I hate reinventing the wheel (aside from being both busy and
lazy :-) so I was hoping someone else had already done something along
these lines, or some similar alternative approch.

> ===
> Could you describe the process of creating and using the FIFO in more
> detail.  I would like to know how to do that, but have never seen it
> before.

To create a FIFO (also called a named pipe), use the mkfifo command,
something like:

   mkfifo <some_arbitrary_file_name>

This creates on your file system a pipe, similar to what you get when you
pipe the output of one command into another such as "ls -l | less"
the difference is that the pipe has a name and is attached to your file
system.  To make use of the pipe, you can simply redirect the ouput of a
command to it, then have another command read from it like this:

  mkfifo /var/tmp/shannons_pipe
  cat /etc/passwd >/var/tmp/shannons_pipe &
  cat </var/tmp/shannons_pipe

this is obviously a stupid and trivial example, but fifos are often used
for things like a simple way for a daemon to provide status information,
or to pass data between independent processes (that may be running as
different users).  One thing to be aware of, once the pipe is full the
process which is filling it may block (if that is how it's I/O handling is
written), until some process is attached to the other end and starts
reading data from the pipe.

> =====
> I've seen all the other replies so I'll suggest ipchains/iptables.  I
> can't offer an example but I swear there is an option to log activity.
> In fact I just checked and see a --log option.  I've never tried it but it
> has been offered as a solution to me.  (Turned out my problem was PEBKAC
> so I never had to use it. :-)

While this will give me access to the packets, so far as I'm aware, it
will not give me information on the process which generated the packets,
and I don't think it will give me anything the packet sniffers

> =====
> If you can define the traffic enough to identify it, I assume you can
> filter for it.  It is simple enough to use tcpdump writing raw traffic
> to a file (just make sure to increase snaplen enough to get the
> *whole* packet w/ payload, not just the header).
> If nothing else you can do a raw of all traffic on that interface.
>
> Even assuming it is a raw TCP session examining the payload should
> give you a good idea of the application.  Reconstructing the full
> bi-dir stream even more.

Actually, this is what I have been doing, the problem is that what I am
trying to track down is sending very generic packets and doesn't give any
real clues.  The packets I was dealing with today were DNS lookups and
ICMP errors (relating to the DNS lookups), but they weren't coming from
the DNS server (I shut it down just to be sure), and I can't figure out
who was making the request, email was my first guess, but I scanned all
email messages and log files and found no references to the IP addresses
or domains that were involved in this.  Unfortunately (or fortunately
depending on your perspective), when I restarted BIND, the problem went
away.

The intermittent packets that I mentioned previously are unfortunately
even more generic, they are TCP echo requests (not ICMP)

> As mentioned in the thread, the BSD accounting option in the kernel
> would be useful.  grab the tools, and you get a nice timestamped log
> of every proc including name, uid, walltime, cpu timer, etc.  That
> compared with timestamped tcpdump logs...
---
> You might also see if you could make some combination of BSD
> process accounting and ip accounting work for your purposes.

With regard to the BSD accounting, I'm afraid I don't know much about it's
capabilities, so I'll have to look into this, but if it can just give a
simple time stamped record of processes and their ports, that might be
sufficient when coupled with a filtering packet sniffer.

Thanks to everyone for their suggestions, by using some of these, it looks
like I just might be able to remain lazy and avoid writing code! :-)

You can't except for 3 ways:

1) give them root
2) use a restricted SAM ( sam -r)
3) use sudo

I work with hpux quite a bit so let me know if you need any more help.
HP-UX considers mounting to be mounting a filesystem and even changing
the permissions on mount wont help you.

I should interject that using HP's "pfs_mount" can result in the entire
system crashing or hanging.  More frequently, it just grabs your CD so
that you can't eject it except using the "manual override", which of
course means that you can't mount a new one and any process that touches
the directory where it was mounted will hang.

My preferred method of mounting CDs on an HP box is via NFS from a linux
or Sun box.  ;-)  Maybe someday HP will abandon their asinine system for
mounting Rock Ridge CDs, but I'm not holding my breath.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 26 18:05:52 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 18:05:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Ports and Processes
Message-ID: <1843630393.1027731971187.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On Fri, 26 Jul 2002, Shannon C. Dealy dealy at deatech.com wrote:

> > If you can afford to disrupt the traffic, an invalid static route for the
> > destination of those mystery packets sometimes helps hold the connection
> > open long enough for lsof to collect the information.  (I.e. the packet
> > gets dropped and the TCP connection needs to time out, keeping it open
> > longer than if it completed successfully.)
> 
> This is one that hadn't occurred to me, I'll have to give it a try.

Let me know how it goes.  Since the connection is TCP based (those TCP
echoes) this will probably hold it open for at least 5 seconds, and
possibly as long as 30 seconds.

Setting IPchains to drop the offending packets also works, and may even
work better since linux tends to be very quick about sending back a
"destination unreachable" ICMP on static routes.

> > As mentioned in the thread, the BSD accounting option in the kernel
> > would be useful.  grab the tools, and you get a nice timestamped log
> > of every proc including name, uid, walltime, cpu timer, etc.  That
> > compared with timestamped tcpdump logs...
> ---
> > You might also see if you could make some combination of BSD
> > process accounting and ip accounting work for your purposes.
> 
> With regard to the BSD accounting, I'm afraid I don't know much about it's
> capabilities, so I'll have to look into this, but if it can just give a
> simple time stamped record of processes and their ports, that might be
> sufficient when coupled with a filtering packet sniffer.

The BSD process accounting lets you record the date/time every process
starts and stops.  Check the docs for the "psacct" RPM on disk 3 of RedHat
7.3 (if that's what you're using.)

This data would need to be correlated with your packet trace in order to
be useful, and I'm not sure that psacct has a fine enough granularity to
really help.  (I.e. I think it only records the process start time to the
nearest second, maybe even just to the nearest minute.)

I think it's more likely that the lsof or netstat methods will succeed.

Another option that might work:

Run "tcpdump" with the "-c" option and some carefully chosen filters so
that it exits after capturing one packet, then run "netstat -ap"
immediately afterwards.  This would make a nice little trigger for
whatever is causing you grief.  For example I just ran:

# tcpdump -c 1 icmp && netstat -ap --ip

And in another window I did:

$ ping <host>

And the first window showed a bunch O crap with this little gem at the
end:

raw        0      0 <ip omitted>:icmp        *:*                     7
3051/ping

Sure enough, that was my ping.

Good hunting!

  -- Steve Bonds

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 26 19:11:01 2002

On Fri, 26 Jul 2002, dh at mda.huntbros.net wrote:

> I'll be in Ireland for three months and have to depend on cybercafes
> for internet access. I have two shell accounts on Linux boxen here
> that I can can only access using an ssh login, and the cybercafes I
> have to use run a M$ OS. How does one launch an ssh login session from
> one of these things? Will ssh2 likely be already on these boxes? Any
> special security considerations, since I don't have control over these
> M$ boxes or their networks?

My biggest fear on public computers is that some bozo has installed a
keystroke logger.  These range from simple software programs to devilish
hardware jobbies that look like the old PS/2-to-DIN keyboard converters.

The only good workaround is to use one-time passwords for
everything.  Unfortunately, you can't do that for your bank passwords
since you don't control the login method there.

Basically, if you can't bring your own client (notebook, Palm w/TopGun
SSH, etc.) in and hook it to their network, don't enter any sensitive
data.

Or maybe I'm just paranoid.  ;-)

  -- Steve

filter and/or reformat the data being collected.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Fri Jul 26 19:23:44 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Jul 2002 19:23:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Slightly OT: How to mount as a user in HP-UX
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207261529220.974-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207261529220.974-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <87fzy5kixb.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Jason Dagit <dagit at engr.orst.edu> writes:

> Does anyone know the typical command to mount a cdrom drive in HP-UX?  I
> know on the sun boxes we have here at school I just use the removable
> media manager, but I can't find anything like that in hp-ux, and mount
> /cdrom doesn't work, mount says I need to be root to run mount.
> 
> Any ideas?

I wonder if an automounter could be configured to perform automatic
mounts of the CDROM?  That's what I do on Linux.  I use "autofs":

    /etc/auto.master
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
# $Id: auto.master,v 1.2 1997/10/06 21:52:03 hpa Exp $
# Sample auto.master file
# Format of this file:
# mountpoint map options
# For details of the format look at autofs(8).

# /mnt/misc	/etc/auto.misc

/mnt/rem /etc/auto.rem --timeout=1
/mnt/nfs /etc/auto.nfs
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

    /etc/auto.rem
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8
#boot		-fstype=ext2		:/dev/hda1

cd		-fstype=iso9660,nosuid,nodev,user,ro	:/dev/cdrom

cdu		-fstype=udf,nosuid,nodev,user,rw	:/dev/cdrom

vfloppy		-fstype=vfat,nosuid,nodev,sync,user,uid=0,gid=25,umask=002 :/dev/fd0
floppy		-fstype=auto,nosuid,nodev,sync,user :/dev/fd0

## lzip		-fstype=auto,nosuid,nodev,sync :/dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target2/lun0/part1
## dzip		-fstype=vfat,user,sync,uid=0,gid=25,umask=002 :/dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target2/lun0/part4
## cdrom		-fstype=iso9660,ro	:/dev/sr0
## icd		-fstype=iso9660,ro	:/dev/hdd
## sparq		-fstype=auto,nosuid,nodev,sync :/dev/hdc1
8<------------------------------------------------------------>8

... now all I do is put the CD in the drive and "cd /mnt/rem/cd".

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Jul 26 20:52:08 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 26 Jul 2002 20:52:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] How to use cybercafes?
References: <mailman.1027734444.15250.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86ofctomjb.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "dh" == dh  <dh at mda.huntbros.net> writes:

dh> I'll be in Ireland for three months and have to depend on cybercafes for
dh> internet access.

Ahh, a topic that is near and dear to my heart.

dh>  I have two shell accounts on Linux boxen here that I can
dh> can only access using an ssh login, and the cybercafes I have to use run a
dh> M$ OS. How does one launch an ssh login session from one of these things?
dh> Will ssh2 likely be already on these boxes? Any special security
dh> considerations, since I don't have control over these M$ boxes or their
dh> networks?

The easiest is if they just give you access to a desktop.  If that
happens, fire up IE, enter "www.google.com" and then "putty ssh
download" and then hit the "I feel lucky" button.  Download Putty (the
first link in the middle of the page) and save it to the desktop.
Double click, and you're on.  Be sure to select ssh not telnet.

If they give you a web browser and not a desktop, select the "run it"
rather than "save it" when it starts to download.  This is less likely
to work, but works more frequently than you might expect. :)

If that doesn't work, google for "authenticated mindterm", and run any
one of the dozen hits you find.... it'll fire up a Java ssh terminal
inside the browser window.  A few of the control keys won't work
(they'll be intercepted as browser controls), but the rest is fine.
(Forget emacs. :-)

I've found one of those three plans almost always works, unless it's a
really crappy internet cafe.

dh> Secondly, I have to access my bank's website too. Would accessing these
dh> pages from a cybercafe's browser pose special security considerations?
dh> Would one browser be any safer than another? Would it be safer to ssh into
dh> my shell account here, then launch a local browser? I think I can do the
dh> banking with Lynx, but not sure yet.

Make sure you're getting 128-bit SSL and not 40-bit SSL.  But SSL
is better than nothing.

--

# Samba config file

[global]

From sandy at herring.org  Mon Jul 29 10:59:51 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 10:59:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] power hit... am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <20020725115129.A22914@aracnet.com>; from sandy@herring.org on Thu, Jul 25, 2002 at 11:51:29AM -0700
References: <20020724232617.A27582@aracnet.com> <1027620866.1697.213.camel@dereklinux> <20020725115129.A22914@aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <20020729105951.A5098@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 25 Jul 2002, Sandy Herring wrote: 
> On Thu, 25 Jul 2002, Derek Loree wrote: 
> > On Wed, 2002-07-24 at 23:26, Sandy Herring wrote:
> > > The power failed while I was a work today. Fat lot of good the UPS did. I
> > > tried rebooting my P-Pro S 200 (SMP) and it panics...
> [...]
> > 
> > Since it is trying to read the root file system from hda3, why not
> > unplug your cd-rom and plug the maxtor into that controller (I'm
> > assuming that your root is on the 3rd partition)?  It looks like GRUB
> > lost the ide=reverse kernel option.  (I think there are advantages to
> > having the kernel options stored in the boot record, lilo style.)
> > 
> > Derek Loree
> 
> That thought has occurred to me. I'm going to give that a try before I try
> the plastic "fix". If I can get booted up via the onboard controller, I can
> make the adjustments necessary to reboot with the Promise.

And that was the charm. Hanging the Maxtor off the onboard controller
allowed the system to boot via grub from the HD. It fsck'd cleanly. I took
advantage of the down time to upgrade to RH7.3 - which also got me a kernel
with native support for the Promise controller. I adjusted grub.conf and the
swap entry in fstab, shutdown, hung the drive off the Promise controller,
crossed my fingers and rebooted into 2.4.18-3smp, et voila! 

Upgrading to 2.4.18-5 rpms was another story altogether (which, IIRC, has
already been told on the list). Bottom line, 20Mb isn't enough for /boot on
RH7.3.

The only other problem I had was when I fired up fetchmail to get my ~1Mb
worth of email from mail.aracnet.com. Spamassassin somehow got its knickers
in a twist and went spawn crazy. The load went up to around 90, and I
noticed lots of duplicate email was being created in my mail spool. I killed
fetchmail, commented spamassassin out of my .procmailrc, cleaned up the
dupes, and fired up fetchmail again. This time, no problems. I've since
reenabled spamassassin and haven't seen a repeat of the fiasco.

It's nice to be back :-) And tomorrow my mother-in-law goes home <big grin>.

Many thanks to _all_ the PLUGers who came to my aid. This list rocks!

Sandy

No. The ROM isn't backward compatible with the old Zaurus. All they have
in common is the name.The newer hardware really is worth the money. 200
Mhz StrongArm, 64MB memory, SD and CF slots, QWERTY keyboard (Blackberry
style) Nice 16 bit TFT screen. The one drawback is battery life. I get
about 6-8 hours of active use for it, but if you use it continuously (
like to listen to MP3s) you would want to get a second battery. Luckily,
you can plug the power cord directly to the unit as well as using the
cradle to charge. It only takes about 2 hours to fully recharge.

Doug

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Mon Jul 29 11:54:22 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 11:54:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: SquidGard Does not Block
In-Reply-To: <1027616074.25312.59.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <20020729185422.18730.qmail@web14402.mail.yahoo.com>

For troubleshooting, try this: (Don't forget to change permissions
back
to something reasonable)

Create a /var/log/squidGuard/log directory if it doesn't exist.
Create an /etc/squidGuard directory if it doesn't exist.
symlink /etc/squidGuard/squidGuard.conf to the real file, if needed.
In squid, call squidGuard with the -c /etc/squidGuard/squidGuard.conf
option.
Change your permissions on /var/log/squidGuard to 777 recursively
(Change this
back when you are done troubleshooting)
Change your permissions on /usr/whatever/squidGuard-1.2 to 777
recursively (Change
this back when you are done)
Try starting squid, and view the squidGuard log files, both in
/var/log/squidGuard 
and /var/log/squidGuard/log
If this doesn't work, simplify your squidGuard.conf file as much as
possible until
it works, then add the rules back in.

Sean Harbour


--- Cooper Stevenson <cooper at linux-enterprise.net> wrote:
> Excerpt from the SquidGaurd FAQ:
> 
> squidGuard does not block? 
> 
>     There my be at least 2 reasons for this: 
>     
>     You didn't end your pass rules with "none". Pass rules ends
> with an
>     implicit "all". It is good practice to allways en the pass
> rules
>     with either "all" or "none" to make them clear. Ie. use: 
>     pass good none
>     or 
>     pass good !bad all
>     squidGuard goes into emergency mode. Reasons may be syntax
> errors in
>     the config file, reference to non existing database files,
>     filprotection problems or missing directories. Check the
> squidGuard
>     log. 
>     Note:When run under Squid, squidGuard is run with the same user
> and
>     group ID as Squid (cache_effective_user and 
> cache_effective_group
>     in squid.conf). The squidGuard configuration and database files
> must
>     be readable for this user and/or group and the squidGuard log
>     directory must be writable for this user and/or group. If not
>     squidGuard will go into the "pass all for all" emergency mode.
> --

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Jul 29 12:13:50 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 12:13:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cursor Only?
In-Reply-To: <3D458984.93D781B5@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207291155150.13677-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 29 Jul 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

[snip]
> Is there a keyboard combination that I can use to put me in some mode
> that will let me recover from this? This happened to me once before and
> I simply shut down and restarted. I realize that's the wimpy way out,
> and I'm trying to learn "the better way."
[snip]

You don't really indicate the setup here, but if the screen that you are
on is your X display, you could try the <ctl><alt><F1> combination to
switch you to a virtual console and fix the problem from there.  In some
cases, just switching to a virtual console and back to your X display will
clean-up/fix display and mouse problems.  If you are already on a virtual
console, the only thing I could suggest would be to try switching to a
different one using <alt><F2> (or F3, F4, ...).  An alternative for
getting out of X is to use a specially defined key sequence for
killing the X server (assuming it is configured).  I'm can't remember
what the current standard sequence is, but I think it is either:
<ctl><alt><backspace> or <ctl><alt><\> unfortunately, I'm having a fit of
senility and can't remember where/how this is configured.

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Jul 29 12:49:34 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 29 Jul 2002 12:49:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba connection problem - RH7.3 box to WinME
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020729002834.00b6bfe0@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020729002834.00b6bfe0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1027972184.19835.250.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Stephen,

You need to hard-set the IP addresses of both the winblowz box and the
Red Hat box.  They can't communicate if they are on separate subnets
(the reason the crossover works between winblowz boxes is that if they
can't find an address, they assign themselves an address that has
nothing to do with your network, but allows communication between them,
linux doesn't do this).

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From judah at opusnet.com  Mon Jul 29 13:38:01 2002
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: 29 Jul 2002 13:38:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Wheel mouse
In-Reply-To: <1027971273.15539.75.camel@red>
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0207291052230.11168-100000@shell.pacifier.com> 
	<1027971273.15539.75.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1027975082.6726.0.camel@laptop>

You won't be using a module for this unless it's a usb mouse.. then it
will be the usb modules that will load and not a specific module for the
mouse alone. There is part of XFree86.

If it's ps/2 don't worry about the usb stuff if it's usb make sure that
usb-uhci is loaded before you plug in your mouse.

As root run `mouseconfig` and choose from the list. You will probably
need to ctl+alt+backspace to restart X after you've done this.

A-

From judah at opusnet.com  Mon Jul 29 13:53:32 2002

Now that this list is being moderated would it not be a good idea to let
relevant posts through to the list even if the are posted from a
non-subscribed email address. I would think denying only truly off topic
emails and spam would be desirable. That's pretty much the theory of
moderation correct. Especially a list that is for the passing of
information on to other individuals in the community. 

You now automatically get a response saying that you sent the message
from a non-subscribed email. That's either going to remind you to double
check next time or make sure to subscribe with that address.. It should
not automatically mark the post for non-inclusion to the list unless
it's as described above. Also, if you are _replying_ directly to a
previous post to the list you're probably subscribed to it anyway and
not just trying to post a first of thread message to the list.

I make this note because a post to the list was denied today even though
the post was relevant, a thorough answer and mistakenly sent from
another email address which is not what I am subscribed as.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Jul 29 14:16:55 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 14:16:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG Moderation Thoughts/Advice
References: <1027976013.6726.17.camel@laptop>
Message-ID: <3D45B0C7.2000704@sun.com>

As I'm the one who's been checking the administrative page lately, it 
falls to me to decide if/when email makes it through to the list.

It is by no means an 'automatic' thing.  Each and every email that comes 
through and is NOT from a subscribed address, I will see.  Every spam, 
every legitimate email, everything.  For about 2 weeks after I made the 
change to the list to make it subscriber-only, I let email go through 
that was relevant from non-subscribers.  I added people to the whitelist 
who had an alternate address, or who posted from the newsgroup.  I 
posted a message to the list REQUESTING this information from people who 
wanted to post from multiple addresses, and gave instructions for those 
who would have liked to do it themselves.

I've done more than my fair share.  If there was an option to BOTH admit 
the message AND send and email back to the sender reminding them to post 
from a subscribed address, I'd do that.  However, I'd much rather have 
people get into the habit of posting from a subscribed address.  After 
all, it's only your FROM: header that has to include the correct 
address.  I don't believe it actually checks if you're posting from 
foo.org when your email address looks like user at foo.org.

I check the administrative pages at least once a day during the week. 
Usually there are 1 or 2 messages in there a day.  Most of the time 
they're spam, or someone who has munged their address for newsgroup 
posting - but not posting from the news gateway.  Spam gets denied, 
other relevant email I will usually reject with a more informative 
message explaining WHY the message was rejected and what you can do to 
avoid this in the future.

-R

From don at truedisk.com  Mon Jul 29 14:25:48 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 14:25:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Delete duplicate entries in MySQL
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207281542440.13107-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <3D45B2DC.C8750F20@truedisk.com>

Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> Does anyone know how to delete duplicate entries in a MySQL table?
> 
> I can use "distinct" to select unique values, but I'd like to remove the
> duplicates entirely from the table.
> Thanks,
> ~M
> 

Is the "LIMIT" qualifier what you're looking for?
e.g.

  DELETE FROM table WHERE (condition) LIMIT n;

So if you have 8 duplicate entries, then you use n=7.  
(I think -- test on a database copy first :-)  )

- Don

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Mon Jul 29 15:50:24 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 29 Jul 2002 15:50:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Cursor Only?
In-Reply-To: <3D45AA29.13E19681@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207291155150.13677-100000@critter.deatech.com> 
	<3D45AA29.13E19681@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1027983026.9051.40.camel@duron>

Sorry for top-posting, I'm not in a trimming mood.  :-)

My guess is you just need to kill X and go from there.

ps ax | grep X
should give you a pid to kill... or just do a..

killall X

or maybe...

killall gdm

To kill the gnome login manager thing.  As root, just run gdm again and
it should bring back your graphical login.

You could also go into a single user mode (telinit 1) and go back to
where you were (runlevel 4?  telinit 4) and all should be good.

Don't forget to log out of your console after you have things back up
and running.  :-)

HTH,

Rob
