From dagit at engr.orst.edu  Mon Jul 29 15:52:39 2002
From: dagit at engr.orst.edu (Jason Dagit)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 15:52:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cursor Only?
In-Reply-To: <1027983026.9051.40.camel@duron>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0207291546030.9940-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

I appologize if these are redundant tips, but there are easier ways to
navigate the virtual terminals (VT) in linux.

At the command line you need only press <alt>, <ctrl> is only needed in X.
The next thing to notice is that if you are going to look at all the VTs
then you can hold down the alt key and use one of the left or right arrow
keys.  It works pretty well to scan through the VTs.  Try it sometime
during a distro install.  Many distros will let you cycle through the VTs
or if it is a graphical install sometimes you can hit <ctrl><alt> and one
of the F keys to find a terminal.  I have used it before to do lots of
handy things during an install.  Or just to learn about the installation
process.

BTW, if you use the <alt>arrowkey trick eventually it will put you back in
X if it is running.  So I usually do like <alt>F1 then use the arrow key
trick.

Well random tips...I hope you find them useful.
Jason

> > I tried <ctrl><alt><F1> and found some lines referencing NEOMAGIC,
> > mostly saing that it was "Not programming shadow registers."
> >
> > I tried <ctrl><alt><F2> and found a login prompt.

From dtsig at hotmail.com  Mon Jul 29 16:01:58 2002
From: dtsig at hotmail.com (Dtsig)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 16:01:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Delete duplicate entries in MySQL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207281542440.13107-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207281542440.13107-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <211205122.20020729160158@hotmail.com>

Hello Matt,

To follow up on my last message .. No .. probably the easiest way to
do this would be to create a new table with the same structure as you
currently have and create an index which is built of multiple columns
which when put together will define your 'unique' information.

Here is a little example from the DOC for mysql

CREATE TABLE test (
           id INT NOT NULL,
           last_name CHAR(30) NOT NULL,
           first_name CHAR(30) NOT NULL,
           PRIMARY KEY (id),
           INDEX name (last_name,first_name));


Then if you insert into your new table from your old table .. all rows
which do not maintain uniqueness will create and error.  Your new
table will have only unique rows.  Then use this new table so any
newly inserted or updated data will follow the rules.

Hope this helps
           
Sunday, July 28, 2002, 3:44:26 PM, you wrote:

MA> Does anyone know how to delete duplicate entries in a MySQL table?

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Jul 29 15:59:14 2002

No, it's not a moderated list.

The list was moved from an 'open' list (any message sent to the list 
address from ANY address would get through) to a 'subscribe-only' list 
(only subscribers can post) because we were getting quite a bit of spam. 
  South African money laundering scheme, Viagra ads, standard Porn spam, 
etc.  There was quite a hubub about it, and at the time the list admin 
was too busy to take care of it and/or research what was needed to get 
it done.  A couple of us in the #orlug irc channel (on 
irc.openprojects.net) figured out what was needed and I made a request 
to the list admin to help with the job.

So we changed the list to a subscribe-only list.  There was no one 
person who caused the change, and no legitimate posts were the catalyst. 
  In the end, it was a particulary graphic sex advert that caused the 
biggest uproar (and no, I don't have a copy ;).

The only time any moderation is necessary is when someone posts from a 
non-subscribed address.  Since your message made it through without any 
user intervention, you are just fine.

-R

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Jul 29 16:04:45 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 16:04:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cursor Only?
In-Reply-To: <3D45AA29.13E19681@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207291544590.14267-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 29 Jul 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

[snip]
> Thanks. That got me to a console screen and I was able to log in as
> root. ps -ax didn't show any processes used by my ordinary user, so I'm
> assuming that I wasn't logged in.
>
> Now, what's the way to get back to X? I tried startx, but I got:
>
>   Fatal server error:
>   Server is already active for display 0
>           If this server is no longer running, remove /tmp/.X0-lock
>           and start again.

Sometimes, if X is working but just messed up, all you have to do is
switch back to the X screen once you have switched so a virtual console,
and everthing will be fine.  This should be the screen you got below:

[snip]
>
> <ctrl><alt><F7> is the cross-hatched background with the X cursor.
[snip]

If what you got here was not what you normally expect to see for your X
display, and if moving the mouse around or hitting a key (preferably with
a sledge hammer :-) didn't give you the display you expect (in case this
is a screen saver you are looking at).  Then X is presumably hosed, and
you should switch back to one of your virtual consoles <ctrl><alt><F1> (or
F2 - F6), and restart X.  I'm not sure what brand of Linux you are using
or which program you are using for the X login screen, but something like
one of the following might work (run as root):

    /etc/init.d/xdm restart
or
    /etc/init.d/gdm restart
or
    /etc/init.d/kdm restart

These are the most common X login managers, but the locations of these
scripts and the "restart" option may be different on your system, this is
Debian style, and I don't know/remember where/how most other distributions
do this.  If it is majorly hosed, you may need to manually kill it and
then use the "start" option with one of the above scripts.

system to use 1 IRQ for each card, but that doesn't help.  I also tried 
1 IRQ for all ports on both cards.

I've tried moving cards around, changing out memory, compiling the 
kernel with debugging support, but nothing seems to help.

Any ideas?

I'll let some of the Cisco experts comment, but the short answer is yes.

> What exactly happens when the syslog says "TCP: drop open request from
> xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx/xxxxx"?  Is this a connection that timed out (hung in
> there for the 30 secs that apache gives it), or was it dropped as soon
> as it was connected (there was a one minute period where I had close
> to 1000 of these)?

This is a result of the TCP syn cookies code kicking in and dropping TCP
connections.  Look at tcp_ipv4.c for details.  ;-)

  -- Steve





From satimis at writeme.com  Mon Jul 29 18:04:34 2002

Restart your X Server.  That is all.

will be another story.  I am still looking for a solution of the latter.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Jul 29 18:34:59 2002

Subject: [PLUG] List Working?

References: <776825332.1027987084025.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <1027992900.7777.5.camel@pookie>

I hardly ever use `rm' by itself as myself and *never* as root.

I usually perform the following:

find /the/directory/or/files/you/wish/to/delete -exec ok {} \;

In scripts, I always check first to see if the directory exists:

  if [[ -d /full/path/to/directory ]]
  then
    find /full/path/to/directory -exec rm {} \;
  fi

Of course, if you enjoy sleeping in your office, be my guest.


-Cooper

The other one I did was on Andy Fraser's Student's lab computer at
PSU...  I was doing some housekeeping, using "dired" in XEmacs, and
goofed...  I meant to "chown newuser:newgroup -R *".  Recall that in
"dired", the "*" means the selected set of files and directories.  But
instead, I typed "chown newuser:newgroup -R .", from "/".

It's that "I just saw my dog get run over" feeling!

Luckily, I had a second computer running the similar release of
Debian.  I wrote a "find" command that used it's printf and %
expansions to make a "|" separated file with the owner and permission
settings.  I then wrote a shell script that used "eval $(awk ...)" to
set some shell variables holding the value of each field for each line
of the file, and set the ones on the blown computer to the ones on the
reference machine, ignoring files that exist on one but not the other.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Jul 29 20:48:19 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 2002 20:48:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba connection problem - RH7.3 box to WinME

Stephen Liu said:
> When connecting to broadband I am compelled using dynamic IP address

Yeah, DHCP seems to be the norm w/ broadband services these days. FWIW,
many of these places use long lease times on the DHCP leases, effectively
giving you a static IP w/o the administrative headache for them. I use
attbi and have 92:50:54 left on my currernt lease as I write this. None of
this has much to do with what you are asking. Sorry...

> Shall I set the IP address of the LAN card as 172.34.34.38 ???

You probably want to pick a pair of private IP addresses (i.e. not routed
by core Internet routers) for the interfaces. These ought to work:

192.168.0.1  <-- Samba box
192.168.0.2  <-- Intranet interface on WinME box

Here are the ranges for the other private networks:

-----------------------------------------------------------
|         RESERVED PRIVATE NETWORK ALLOCATIONS            |
-----------------------------------------------------------
| Network | Netmask       | Network Addresses             |
| Class   |               |                               |
-----------------------------------------------------------
|    A    | 255.0.0.0     | 10.0.0.0    - 10.255.255.255  |
|    B    | 255.255.0.0   | 172.16.0.0  - 172.31.255.255  |
|    C    | 255.255.255.0 | 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255 |
-----------------------------------------------------------

> In WinME box
> There are 2 LAN cards, one for connection to Internet via broadband and
> another for Intranet

Sounds like you might benefit from having a router/firewall, if you want
to keep a home network setup more permenantly. Folks on this list might be
able to give more information if you're looking to roll-your-own solution
via floppyfw or somesuch. Several vendors (SMC, Linksys, D-link, etc.)
make these if you want to buy-and-play. Cheap too; I found a D-link for
$48 at newegg.com.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jul 30 06:56:15 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 06:56:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <1941.216.99.218.67.1028035216.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207300635480.10466-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

You shouldn't need a proxy server; iptables will do the trick for you.  
For the sake of this example, assume that

* eth0 is your external interface; its address is 123.45.67.89
* eth1 faces your LAN
* the internal host that will be serving these requests is 10.0.0.13

1. Make sure that your exposed host is setup for ip forwarding:

   sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1

2. Add some prerouting entries to your nat table for common services 
   like http, ftp, etc. Also add explicit support for these ports in 
   your FORWARD table.

   for port in 80 21 22 25 110
   do
     iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -i eth0 -p tcp --dport $port \
              -j DNAT --to 10.0.0.13:$port
     iptables -t filter -A FORWARD -i eth0 -p tcp -d 10.0.0.13 \
              --dport $port -j ACCEPT
   done

3. Make sure that traffic sent from 10.0.0.13 out to the internet gets 
   the NAT treatment.

   iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j SNAT --to 123.45.67.89

There's lots more to know about iptables than that -- but I just 
wanted to let you know that you can accomplish your packet passing 
with iptables.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> The List software probably caught that (from a subscribed individual)
> and allows the posting.
> 
> Klez forges the FROM header.

Yes, anyone who runs Outlook or Outlook Express should do a few things:

1. Turn off "preview" which shows opens the email down below when you 
single click on it. It should require a concious effort (double-click) to 
open an email and execute the code therein.

2. Run a virus checker and set it to download and install the latest 
virus definations regularly (at least twice a week).

3. Virus checker should also be set (as you mentioned) to scan each email. 
It will scan each *outgoing* email as well, protecting your friends.

3. Use a free operating system and email client -- though we should not 
get careless either. :-)


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jul 30 08:10:11 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 08:10:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <2172.216.99.218.67.1028040191.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207300759310.10466-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 30 Jul 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:

> That sounds good but won't all traffic then to the 123.45.67.89 ip
> then get forwarded to the internal machine?  I have two domains and
> would like one resolved on 123.45.67.89 and the other sent to
> 10.0.0.13.
>
> That is:
> 
> domain1.com is seen from the world to go to 123.45.67.89 and that
> linux box will handle all the request for any services.  This
> machine is also the firewall and does NAT for the internal network.
>
> domain2.com is also been seen to the world as being 123.45.67.89 but
> any request to this domain should be forwarded to 10.0.0.13.
>
> Is that still possible with iptables?

No.

In fact, it's pretty much impossible with any IP traffic except for
web stuff. HTTP 1.1 specifies that a hostname is to be passed to the
server (making name-based virtual servers possible) in the http
headers, but otherwise TCP/UDP traffic show up at a given IP address
without any care for the name that got them there.

For example, if 123.45.67.89, host.example.com, and cname.example.com 
all point to the same box, then the packets from these commands will 
all look identical when they reach the server:

  ftp 123.45.67.89
  ftp host.example.com
  ftp cname.example.com

AFAIK, there's absolutely no way to distinguish between them.

Unless I'm missing something, the only way to accomplish your goal is 
to get another real-world IP address and point your second domain name 
at it.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

"Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com> writes:

> Good Morning all,

Good morning.<musical note> <freindly informative tone/ It is
customary, when changing the topic, to begin a new thread rather than
replying to a message in an unrelated one.  The messages are threaded
by most mail user agents by "Message-ID" and "References" headers that
might not be displayed by the software you use./>

> I am trying to find out how I can go about servicing a domain from behind
> a firewall.  That is I have an exposed IP on the firewall that is a RH 7.3
> box and it resolves one domain.  Now there is a need to resolve another
> domain and that computer that will do all that work is on the internal
> network.  How do I forward all request from the firewall box to the
> internal network computer such that all services are answered by the
> internal computer?  I will need http,ftp,ssh,pop,smtp and possibly more
> forwarded to the internal computer.

Is that "internal network" a DMZ, or is it your private LAN?  You
should not run services inside your private LAN, since if the machine
is ever broken into, they'll have access to your LAN.  A DMZ (for
demilitarized zone) network is used for this purpose.  Machines on the
DMZ are isolated from both the Internet and from your internal private
LAN.

> I know that I can use apache to proxy the request but I don't know how to
> handle the other protocols and thought that there must be a way to do
> this.  I will have the second domain being resolved the the firewalls IP. 
> I have thought that a DNS server on the firewall would help but it will
> just tell all the request that the IP is (10.0.0.13) and that will not
> work for the world.  So, do I need some proxy server?  is it built into
> iptables some how?

Two possible solutions here...  You could install a commercial
firewall product.  You might like the Netule FW-I at www.netule.com,
for instance.  Another option is to install "fwbuilder", and use it to
create your iptables script.  Either solution is much easier than hand
editting a firewall script.

Dan Young <dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us> writes:

> Stephen Liu wrote:
> --snip--
> > Kindly advise how to hand-set the IP addresses on RH7.3 box.
> 
> /usr/sbin/netconfig as root is RedHat's touchy-feely curses-based
> network config tool.
> 
> 
> You'll need to do this again (to go back to DCHP) once you plug back
> into your cable modem.

For the Debian newbies out there... (complaints from others to
/dev/null please) the equivalent is to either edit
"/etc/network/interfaces" -- RTFM "interfaces" and "ifup"; it's a very
simple and easy to learn syntax -- or to install "etherconf" and then
run "dpkg-reconfigure -plow etherconf" (the standard dpkg-reconfigure
recipe we all know and love) when you need to make changes.  If you
have the "configlets" installed, there's one for etherconf that will
show up in the Gnome control panel under the "Debian" heading.

Aaron Baer <judah at opusnet.com> writes:

> You won't be using a module for this unless it's a usb mouse.. then
> it will be the usb modules that will load and not a specific module
> for the mouse alone. There is part of XFree86.
> 
> If it's ps/2 don't worry about the usb stuff if it's usb make sure
> that usb-uhci is loaded before you plug in your mouse.

For USB anything, I recommend installing the "hotplug" package, and
making sure your 2.4 kernel is built with hotplug support.  With that
running, anytime you jack in a USB device, the module is loaded for
you automaticly.  It also works with PCMCIA cards (I think) and stuff
like the "tun" module.  "tunctl -u karlheg" causes "hotplug" to run
"ifup tap0", for instance.

From flee at aracnet.com  Tue Jul 30 11:10:36 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 11:10:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207300759310.10466-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> on Tue, 30 Jul 2002 08:10:11 PDT.
Message-ID: <200207301810.g6UIAbS04332@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

"Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com>:
> I will need http,ftp,ssh,pop,smtp and possibly more
> forwarded to the internal computer.

the simplest solution is to get a second IP address.  it's
way way simpler than anything else.  that aside...

http: the domain the client is trying to talk to is sent in
the http request, so that can be handled with standard tools.

everything else...

non-anonymous ftp, ssh, pop: they all have usernames sent as
part of the protocol, so if you don't have any usernames
that clash in the two domains, you can put up proxies that
redirect based on user name.  of course, anonymous ftp and
smtp and other things can't be handled that way.

if domain1 or domain2 is used mainly from particular places,
you could do iptables routing by source address.  A request
to 123.45.67.89 from network A goes to host X, a request
from network B goes to host Y, etc.

if you can't make that distinction, you can have iptables do
random routing, which is usually for load-balancing
purposes, but in this case the effect will be that half the
time connections will go to the right place.  This is likely
to be annoying to users.

if the user base is small enough, you can tell them to use
non-standard ports to access services on the other domain.
so a connection to port 22 (ssh) will go to domain1, but a
connection to port 10022 will go to domain2, etc.

if you have control over the DNS servers for the domain, you
can try playing clever games with guessing that when a DNS
request for domain1 is shortly followed by a connection
request from sort of the same direction on the network, then
it should go to host X instead of host Y.  This is a bizarre
solution that appeals to my "oooh, neat" instinct, but it's
much more effort than it's worth.

oh, also keep in mind that externally accessible computers
should probably be isolated from your internal computers by
a firewall.  to serve two domains, I'd want a configuration
something like this:

                        |---> domain1 server
                        |
   outside <--> router -|---> domain2 server
   world                |
                        |---> firewall/nat <---> internal net

router/firewall/nat can be the same physical box.

and tell users who ssh into the external servers that they
shouldn't trust the servers to be secure.  if you do need to
provide a trustworthy server for users to login to, that's
another problem.

all this wouldn't be such a big deal if every programmer
involved had an infallible understanding of security and
complexity issues.  I expect that to happen sometime in Q4
2002, so you might just want to wait until then.
--
[ sometimes 6 has 0 working numbers ]

had also been "doubled". I called and eventually got to a real person who

> "Josh Orchard" <josh at emediatedesigns.com>:
>> I will need http,ftp,ssh,pop,smtp and possibly more
>> forwarded to the internal computer.
>
> the simplest solution is to get a second IP address.  it's
> way way simpler than anything else.  that aside...
>
> http: the domain the client is trying to talk to is sent in
> the http request, so that can be handled with standard tools.
>
> everything else...
>
> non-anonymous ftp, ssh, pop: they all have usernames sent as
> part of the protocol, so if you don't have any usernames
> that clash in the two domains, you can put up proxies that
> redirect based on user name.  of course, anonymous ftp and
> smtp and other things can't be handled that way.
>
> if domain1 or domain2 is used mainly from particular places,
> you could do iptables routing by source address.  A request
> to 123.45.67.89 from network A goes to host X, a request
> from network B goes to host Y, etc.
>
> if you can't make that distinction, you can have iptables do
> random routing, which is usually for load-balancing
> purposes, but in this case the effect will be that half the
> time connections will go to the right place.  This is likely
> to be annoying to users.
>
> if the user base is small enough, you can tell them to use
> non-standard ports to access services on the other domain.
> so a connection to port 22 (ssh) will go to domain1, but a
> connection to port 10022 will go to domain2, etc.
>
> if you have control over the DNS servers for the domain, you
> can try playing clever games with guessing that when a DNS
> request for domain1 is shortly followed by a connection
> request from sort of the same direction on the network, then
> it should go to host X instead of host Y.  This is a bizarre
> solution that appeals to my "oooh, neat" instinct, but it's
> much more effort than it's worth.
>
> oh, also keep in mind that externally accessible computers
> should probably be isolated from your internal computers by
> a firewall.  to serve two domains, I'd want a configuration
> something like this:
>
>                        |---> domain1 server
>                        |
>   outside <--> router -|---> domain2 server
>   world                |
>                        |---> firewall/nat <---> internal net
>
> router/firewall/nat can be the same physical box.
>
> and tell users who ssh into the external servers that they
> shouldn't trust the servers to be secure.  if you do need to
> provide a trustworthy server for users to login to, that's
> another problem.
>
> all this wouldn't be such a big deal if every programmer
> involved had an infallible understanding of security and
> complexity issues.  I expect that to happen sometime in Q4
> 2002, so you might just want to wait until then.
> --
> [ sometimes 6 has 0 working numbers ]
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Jul 30 13:18:16 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)

On Tue, 30 Jul 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:

> The only reason I don't want to service both domains from the same
> computer is because the other server already has all the items configured
> and was asked to but it on the network.  I thought if I could just forward
> the request to that machine then life would be easier then opening up the
> first server to another person.
> It appears that I will need another IP and then just forward all request
> for that IP to the back machine.
> Josh

If I am understanding this correctly, there might be another alternative.
If you are just trying to allow your current Firewall/DNS server to act as
a server for another domain without allowing another person to access it,
you could simply setup your current DNS server as a secondary for the
internal computer, it would then get all DNS information for the new
domain from the internal system (while retaining control over it's
current domain), and could then present it to the internet.  Then you
would just register your current Firewall/DNS as the primary for the new
domain, even though from an internal perspective it is actually a
secondary.

Did I write this in a confusing enough manner, or should I try again :-)

On Tue, Jul 30, 2002 at 01:38:53AM -0700, AthlonRob wrote:

> 
> I'm no email header guru... so the info might still be there... but the
> actual email address of the sender is in the original (non-messed up by
> the list) headers.  Not as FROM, but is reply to or something similar. 
> The List software probably caught that (from a subscribed individual)
> and allows the posting.
> 
> Klez forges the FROM header.

What Klez does with mail headers is beside the point. Mailman uses the
From: field to identify the sender, and it preserves the From: field
when it posts the message to the list.

So the From: field in the spam must have been set to the eldragon
address when Mailman received it. The question is, since eldragon is
not subscribed, how did the message get posted to the list?

Probably the message was flagged for moderation, and a list
administrator approved it by mistake.

- Aj

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Jul 30 14:56:10 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 14:56:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <15657.206.30.30.2.1028064439.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207301444001.20400-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 30 Jul 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:

> ok.  I think I'm still a bit confused here.  Are you suggesting that I
> could use a primary and secondary DNS with one IP for two domains and have
> all traffic somehow moved to the internal 10.0.0.13 box?  It seems like

Actually I was suggesting that the external box could handle the DNS
traffic for both domains, but the configuration for one of them could be
maintained on the internal box.

> that I will still need a secondary IP for the other domain and if I do
> that I should just use iptables to forward all traffic on that IP to the
> second box.  Am I wrong?
> Josh
[snip]

No, you can only have one instance of a domain name server running on the
standard port, and you can't use iptables to selectively forward requests
depending on which domain it is for (well theoretically you probably
could by analyzing the packet content, but it definitely wouldn't be worth
the effort to configure).  What you would be doing is running a single
instance of your name server on the external box, which would be
configured to handle DNS services for multiple domains, getting DNS
information for one domain from it's local config files, and the DNS
information for the other domain from your internal server.  It would then
serve as the primary DNS server on the internet for both domains.

The key here is that while you must have two IP addresses to provide
separate DNS server programs for two domains, you can run one instance of
a DNS server (which only requires one IP address) that handles services
for an arbitrary number of domains.

> read only = no
> public = yes
> 
> wins support = yes

One of these boxes needs to be the WINS server, I recommend setting the
Red Hat box, then tell the Winblowz box that the WINS server is
192.168.0.1.  If you don't set a WINS server, then you have to wait for
the "election" which can take 10-15 minutes (although you will be able
to manually "Find" the Red Hat box).  As a bonus, the smb portion of the
network will be MUCH faster if the Red Hat box is your WINS server.  I'm
assuming that the WorkGroup name is also "SEC" on the winblowz box.

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Tue Jul 30 17:12:33 2002
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 17:12:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207301444001.20400-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <15657.206.30.30.2.1028064439.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
        <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207301444001.20400-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <17383.206.30.30.2.1028074353.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>

So, if I understand you correctly all I have to do is setup DNS on my
external ip as a secondary to the internal IP as the primary and then
register the external as the primary for that domain.
Ok. I understand that part but if I ssh to a domain1.com would it still
get all the way back to the client in anywhere land?  How would the
connection hold after getting the IP which would be the same for both
domains yet the files would only exisit on one machine.  That is where I
think it all falls apart.  As pointed out by another there is no standard
that says you have to hold and send the domain name with each request and
after having the IP all traffic can travel on the number.
Correct me if I'm wrong but I do think a second IP might be the only true
solution.
Josh


> On Tue, 30 Jul 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:
>
>> ok.  I think I'm still a bit confused here.  Are you suggesting that I
>> could use a primary and secondary DNS with one IP for two domains and
>> have all traffic somehow moved to the internal 10.0.0.13 box?  It
>> seems like
>
> Actually I was suggesting that the external box could handle the DNS
> traffic for both domains, but the configuration for one of them could
> be maintained on the internal box.
>
>> that I will still need a secondary IP for the other domain and if I do
>> that I should just use iptables to forward all traffic on that IP to
>> the second box.  Am I wrong?
>> Josh
> [snip]
>
> No, you can only have one instance of a domain name server running on
> the standard port, and you can't use iptables to selectively forward
> requests depending on which domain it is for (well theoretically you
> probably could by analyzing the packet content, but it definitely
> wouldn't be worth the effort to configure).  What you would be doing is
> running a single instance of your name server on the external box,
> which would be
> configured to handle DNS services for multiple domains, getting DNS
> information for one domain from it's local config files, and the DNS
> information for the other domain from your internal server.  It would
> then serve as the primary DNS server on the internet for both domains.
>
> The key here is that while you must have two IP addresses to provide
> separate DNS server programs for two domains, you can run one instance
> of a DNS server (which only requires one IP address) that handles
> services for an arbitrary number of domains.
>

>                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
> Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering
> Applications
>   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Jul 30 21:38:36 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 2002 21:38:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] servicing a domain from behind a firewall
In-Reply-To: <17383.206.30.30.2.1028074353.squirrel@sautez.dhs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207302112390.21109-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 30 Jul 2002, Josh Orchard wrote:

> So, if I understand you correctly all I have to do is setup DNS on my
> external ip as a secondary to the internal IP as the primary and then
> register the external as the primary for that domain.
> Ok. I understand that part but if I ssh to a domain1.com would it still
> get all the way back to the client in anywhere land?  How would the
> connection hold after getting the IP which would be the same for both
> domains yet the files would only exisit on one machine.  That is where I
> think it all falls apart.  As pointed out by another there is no standard
> that says you have to hold and send the domain name with each request and
> after having the IP all traffic can travel on the number.
> Correct me if I'm wrong but I do think a second IP might be the only true
> solution.

Sorry, maybe I missed it, but I only remember seeing a query about setting
up DNS services.  If you are wanting to do other things as well, the
second IP is probably your best choice, and depending on your ISP,
shouldn't be to expensive (I think I pay about $5-$10/mo. extra for each
of my two blocks of 8 IP addresses).  Of course, for some services this
isn't necessary if you really want to avoid this, you can simply setup
many services on alternate ports on the external server.  One example
would be web services on the internal server,  setup an alternate port
on the external server to use for the service and forward that to the
usual port on the internal server, and for easy access, you could even put
a page on the external server that redirects the person to the alternate
port for those wanting access to the internal server.  For ssh, you could
setup an alternate port as well and forward it to the internal server, but
for people using this alternate port, they would need to either specify
the port as a command line option when running ssh, or set the port for
accessing the internal server in their ssh configuration file (it allows
this to be set on a per-host basis for the version I am running).  This
actually even adds a slight bit of security for the internal server, since
most probes will not be looking for ssh on an alternate port.  Of course
how practical the alternate port solution is depends on who will be
accessing the internal server.

FWIW

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jul 31 06:21:43 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 31 Jul 2002 06:21:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A Postfix regex question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207310547530.29988-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207310617430.16731-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 31 Jul 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> > What about
> > 
> > /^Subject:$/    REJECT
> 
> Does this accommodate a variable length of white space that may be
> there? I do like it, though, and I think it's safe enough to try
> without risking the loss of all incoming messages.

I don't use Postfix, so I can't answer the question directly, but I 
suspect its regex engine would have some way of tokenizing whitespace. 
Two common ways of doing this would be

^Subject:\s*$             -- Perl
^Subject:[[:blank:]]*$    -- gawk/posix

It's likely just a matter of learning how Postfix does this.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

recent postfix releases.

misconfigured Outbreak Express run the thing.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Jul 31 15:55:31 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 31 Jul 2002 15:55:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian 3.0, .deb application availability.
In-Reply-To: <20020731152056.0566f182.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
References: <1028069173.25973.3.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>
	<877kjbfurk.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	<20020731152056.0566f182.eli.stair.lists@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <873ctzfqxo.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Eli Stair <eli.stair.lists at attbi.com> writes:

> I've been meaning to ask someone who uses it, perhaps you do...

8-) I'm ONE of the people to ask.  There's a growing number of PLUG
members using the Debian GNU toolkit these days.

> How is 3.0?  My last experience was with 2.2r2, which got hosed
> by an attempted Progeny upgrade.  It was still beta, I knew what
> I was getting into so I'm not complaining.

It was probably not really all that hosed.  You should have asked for
some assistance!  It likely could have been fixed with little trouble
and no data loss at all.

> My main complaint with Debian, and a sticking point with any
> package-based distro, is that it _seemed_ that popular (read: new)
> .debs were always months behind release of the software.  There
> wasn't enough community support behind packaging apps in .deb
> format, thus no resource equivalent to rpmfind.net.

In the "unstable" branch, the new upstream release is quite often
followed very shortly by a new Debian release.  When that does not
happen is when the new upstream release represents a major change that
makes the automatic upgrade process difficult, breaks peoples systems
(library upgrades, scripts break, etc.), or is considered too unstable
to use yet (though that's usually not the big one in "unstable" unless
the upstream software is still at the alpha or early beta release
status).

So, if you must live at the bleeding edge, just change your
sources.list to point to "unstable", or, put both stable and unstable
in there, and use the "man apt_preferences" mechanism to control what
you actually install.

The thing with distribution maintenance is that you don't want to
break a million computer systems out there on the net.  When they all
trust you to provide working software systems, that they don't have to
futz around with all day to get working (so they can get on with THEIR
job), you can't go and toss a brand new and untested software release
into the mix and just hope it works.  This is why there are several
branches -- stable (woody), testing (sarge), and unstable (sid).

> Has that aspect changed much?  Other than that issue I found it to
> be superb.

The more things stay the same, the more things change.  Debian
unstable is a moving target and always will be.  It is still superb,
of course.

> Well, no big deal, provided it did not infect anyone's silly unsecured
> windows machines.
>
> To all list admins: When you go to approve unsubscriber posts, please
> check the contents very carefully.  This virus was in a MIME message,
> it contained a base64 encoded file marked as MIME type "audio/x-wav"
> (IIRC) with a file extension of ".bat".  I guess that is what makes a
> misconfigured Outbreak Express run the thing.
>
I think that ``misconfigured" is the wrong word to use, if you are
talking about the Outlook server. IIRC, there is no simple way to keep
the server part of Outlook from forwarding an infected email to one
& all. On the other hand, the Outlook client *can* be configured to at
least slow down these malignant missives: what I do is search thru
all of the menus & disable everything I don't see a use for -- java,
javascript, HTML -- & everything that I don't understand. This
instinctive mistrust of Outlook has saved me at least once.

This is bound to annoy network admins who plan on forcing you to
upgrade your Windows computers by sending you a specialy-designed
email. They deserve the aggravation for doing something stupid.

For what it's worth: when you get an infected email attachment,
the icon Outlook selects to represent the attachment looks an awful
lot like a tapeworm inside a page.

> Should we just reject or should we send them a nastygram also?
>
If someone is sending out virus-infected emails, I would think it is a
courtesy to alert them to the fact their computer has a problem. All
of us make a stupid mistake once in a while, & the sooner someone politely
informs the computer owner of the problem, the sooner the problem can be
fixed.

However, if the alerted party acts like a jerk (e.g., ``buzz off you
elitist Lin-sucks a-hole, my computer's fine"), then by all means pass
her/his name to the RBL group of your choice & let the jerk suffer.

Geoff

In either case, why are you rebooting?  If you need to restart your

If you are running as root.

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Wed Jul 31 19:37:18 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 31 Jul 2002 19:37:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Broadband detection
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20020801102003.009fbd20@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20020801102003.009fbd20@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1028169439.4423.4.camel@duron>

On Wed, 2002-07-31 at 19:20, Stephen Liu wrote:

> Should I forget to plug-in the broadband cable and start the PC, instead of 
> plugging in the cable and rebooting the PC, are there any short-cuts 
> avoiding reboot.

The only reasons I can come up with to reboot are if you install a new
kernel, do some hardware upgrading, want to test your new init scripts,
or want to power down the system.

You should be able to configure your distro to use the broadband, then
just re-run the network startup script for it.  Do you know what kind of
broadband connection it is?  PPPoE or not?  DHCP or static IP?  You'll
need that info to properly configure your Internet connection.  What
files to modify where, though, and what to run to restart the network
scripts... is totally dependent upon the distribution you are using.

-- 
Rob
"Google is your friend"

Richard M. Stallman - Free Software

Eric S. Raymond - the "Open Source" perspective

Lawrence Lessig - Intellectual property

A representative of EFF - civil liberties on the Internet

organization wants to help in some way then let me know.

contact information or make introductions -- through email would be fine.

talk or with any of the others.

Message-ID: <87ptx3xk57.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

> Another solution if you want newer versions is to "build-your-own".
> I do this with Samba, because the Debian-packaged Samba has a bunch
> of unwanted dependencies, like CUPS, last time I looked.

It's not hard to use "apt-get source PKG", make a few modifications,
then build a custom .deb from it.  The main thing is to edit the
"changelog", adding a new revision, with a point release number, then
modify "rules" as required to make it configure the software the way
you want.  After you install it, use "aptitude hold PKG" to make it
not upgrade automaticly.  (It just occured to me that I don't know if
an "aptitude hold" will apply to "apt-get" also.)

> I upgraded LyX to 1.2.0, but when I try to invoke it I learn there's

> with the -r option, but all that tells me is that there's an

Perhaps you could learn something from:

http://cvs.debian.org/boot-floppies/scripts/rootdisk/mklibs.sh

 ... or:

http://cvs.debian.org/boot-floppies/scripts/rootdisk/mklibs.py

... which are for building subset .so libraries for the binaries on
the Debian "boot-floppies" installer root filesystem image from "ar"
archives of those libraries that are built with "-fPIC" to make
creating a .so from them possible.  (That's what the "libc-pic"
package is for.)

choice of several images to boot from.  (I prefer, personally, the
"bf24" kernel.)  Documentation is on the CD.

coaster, one that has no NON-US stuff on it, and 8 with the works.

> crack legally, the list of actionable items will inevitably grow.

On Wed, 2002-07-31 at 22:48, Josh Orchard wrote:
> I would like to setup a script to ssh into a remote box and do some
> rsync'ing but I can't find an option in the ssh command line to pass in
> the password.  Is there such a thing?  If not, suggestions for the script
> to input the password after the prompt comes back?
> command I'm running is:
> 
> rsync --archive --verbose -e ssh me at remotemachine:/stuff/to/backup
> /local/backup
> Thanks,
> 
> Josh
>
You can pass a command line via ssh like this:
ssh -l user machine command
For some reason this does not work on commercial SSH on HP-UX.

To avoid the prompt, you can generate a keypair with a null passphrase,
but be sure you keep your private key private,

Doug

How do I generate a null key pair and will that always be used when I
normally ssh into the remote box?
I also found a way to do it by using expect.

for those curious here is the script I found:

#!/usr/bin/expect -f
log_user 0
spawn /usr/bin/rsync /etc -ar --delete --copy-unsafe-links -l -t -e ssh
user at remote.site.com:./expect "password: "
send "secret\n"
log_user 1
interact


Just not sure I like the password in plain text in a file.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Wed Jul 31 23:10:42 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 31 Jul 2002 23:10:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Terminal Server...  too many open files?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207312218330.4661-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0207312218330.4661-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <87ptx3w1lp.fsf@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> writes:

> I'm running a couple Linux Terminal Servers (http://k12ltsp.org) at
> work with about 24 users per server.  Occasionally users are not
> able to launch programs or do much else because the system reports
> that there are currently too many open files.  Is there a
> system-wide variable somewhere that I can modify to increase the
> maximum number of open files?

I think you can "echo NNNN > /proc/sys/fs/file-max", or, if your disto
uses "sysctl", edit "/etc/sysctl.conf" and set it there, then run
"sysctl -p".

You can read about that proc file in the Linux kernel Documentation/
directory.  (grep for it)

> How do I generate a null key pair and will that always be used when I

You'll probably find your script is a little overboard.  :-)

ssch -c /usr/bin/rsync /etc -ar --delete --copy-unsafe-links -l -t -e
ssh

(sorry about wordwrapping, I couldn't help it with this client)

Check out the info at
http://www.puddingonline.com/~dave/publications/SSH-with-Keys-HOWTO/document/html-one-page/SSH-with-Keys-HOWTO.html for a quick howto about ssh keys.  It isn't the exact page I used (I launch Mozilla on the server from my P2 266 to speed things up a little) but it looks like it'll do the job for you.  :-)

Have fun!
